webTitle: How to pick a pack to shoulder the burden

fields.headline: How to pick a pack to shoulder the burden
fields.standfirst: Ideally they should be tried before you buy, but Liz Stuart finds the argument for buying rucksacks online carries a lot of weight
fields.trailText: Ideally they should be tried before you buy, but Liz Stuart finds the argument for buying rucksacks online carries a lot of weight
fields.body:
It is the notion of carrying everything you need on your own back which makes travelling so exhilarating, but a rucksack can also make the difference between a comfortable trip and an agonising one which leaves you with more memories of sore shoulders than mountain vistas.

There is a huge range of backpacks available, depending on your priorities. The lighter, more expensive, and the most professional of rucksacks cost around £200, while a perfectly functional but slightly heavier version costs half that amount.

Ideally, packs should be tried on before purchase. What looks like a fairly simple holdall is a precise piece of engineering, and many models which appear similar differ in the way in which they fit the body and distribute the weight of the contents.

There are now several outdoor gear websites which undercut hiking and camping shops; WildDay.com, a Scottish site, claims to be up to 60% cheaper than the high street, for instance. Shop via these sites and you lose the opportunity to put the pack on your back and have an expert show you how to adjust straps and make personal recommendations. Site 9feet.com gets round this by offering exchange of goods with free postage.

The first issue to address when choosing a rucksack is size, or capacity, which is measured in litres. For travelling, standard sizes are 65 litres, moving up to 80 if it is a long trip or if you need to carry food. If you are walking, then a daysack of 25-35 litres should be sufficient. Overnighters should look at something between the two.

Next to consider is whether to go for an adjustable back system or not. The benefits are that you can fine-tune the fit and also that more than one person can use the pack and adjust it to their body shape. It is also, according to 9feet.com, preferable if you have a short back but do not want to compromise on the amount of kit you carry. They are, however, heavier than the fixed-back versions.

There are also different models for men and women. Mike Pleasants, a Duke of Edinburgh award leader from Bournemouth, says: "All the ladies I know who walk use the female-specific packs. The hip belt and shoulder straps are far more comfortable." Backpacks for women have a flared base so they do not rub against the hip belt and the straps curve so they fit round the base rather than cutting in. If you are a small man you may also find the female versions more comfortable, and the branding is normally discreet.

The final decision is whether to buy a top-loading pack, or a side loader, which unzips like a suitcase. "This depends what you are using it for," says Mr Pleasants. "If you are taking a lot of trains, then it may be better for you as you can carry it like a holdall. But if you are going to be outdoors, then I prefer the top-loading variety as if I need to get something out and it is muddy, I can just stand the pack on its base without getting the whole thing dirty."

So which bags do the experts recommend? For travelling, Blacks, the outdoor equipment shop, predictably picks one of its own, the Blacks Governor, at £89.99. Blacks' Steven Faust says that this 60-litre pack is "a large volume multi-capacity multi-purpose travel-orientated rucksack. It has a large main section with detachable day- sack and bum bag. This is also a zip-away panel which can be pulled over the straps. It also has a top grab handle."

But 9feet.com comes down in favour of Karrimor's Cougar model. The 50-70 litre L version (the extra capacity comes when all the pockets are full) is designed for women. 9feet buyer Matt Jones says: "This is a very strong buy. It is light, has good durability of fabric and fulfils all the basic needs of the backpacker. It costs £110. WildDay carries the smaller Cougar 50 at £90.

For men, Mr Jones recommends the standard version of the Cougar 50-70 product, which costs £110 at 9feet and Blacks and just £90 at WildDay. He adds that while trendy brands such as North Face and MacPac are high quality, they are overpriced.

He also favours Karrimor for travel packs. Its range is called Global and the bags feature detachable daysacks. The top of the range version has a pull-out trolley handle. Prices range from £140-£160 at 9feet and Blacks.

For hillwalking, a daysack should suffice. It should allow you to store additional clothing you may need, exterior pockets for a compass and water bottle, padded straps and hip belt and a mesh separating the back from the pack. Mr Pleasants favours the Regatta X-ert 35, which is generally classified as a rucksack rather than a daysack because of its size: "It's a bit bigger than most daysacks which means I can fit in things like a first-aid pack when I am leading a group." This costs £26.99 at Oswald Bailey and £24 at WildDay.

Mr Faust at Blacks opts for the Peter Storm Kinetic bag, at £24.99. This 20-25 litre model was recently voted best buy by Country Walking magazine and features multiple compartments, a compression system to stabilise the load, an air flow mesh back, reflective trim and a pocket which will carry a cycle helmet. Mr Jones, however, prefers the Lowe Alpine Pax 25, at £30 on 9feet.

If keeping the contents of your pack dry is a priority, a new range from Craghopper is recommended by 9feet.com. "They've had great reviews and are not much more expensive than ordinary packs," says Mr Jones. The Drypack 50 costs £80 on 9feet.com, and £87.50 on WildDay.com. It also comes in 30, 35, 45 and 65 litre varieties.

webTitle: Cannabis charge Rasta cites Human Rights Act

fields.headline: Cannabis charge Rasta cites Human Rights Act
fields.standfirst:
Special report: drugs in Britain

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: A Rastafarian charged with possessing cannabis with intent to supply has applied to have his case reconsidered under article 9 of the Human Rights Act, the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion.
fields.body:
A Rastafarian charged with possessing cannabis with intent to supply has applied to have his case reconsidered under article 9 of the Human Rights Act, the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion.

Rasta Brown made the application, believed to be the first of its kind, at Inner London magistrates court on Thursday. Brown, 38, from Stockwell, south London, originally admitted possession of a class B drug with intent to supply in August and was due to be sentenced when the application was made.

Mr Brown's counsel, Rufus D'Cruz, said that although smoking cannabis was not mentioned in the 16 fundamental tenets of Rastafarianism it was considered "an aid to worship, medicine, and as a source of income."

The religion's acceptance of it as a source of income would be the basis of Brown's claim that he was not guilty, Mr D'Cruz said. Under article 9 he did not have to establish that Rastafarianism was a religion.

"The right is for freedom of thought, conscience and religion. It is clear from case law that it is a right to be interpreted broadly," he said.

Judge Charles Gibson deferred a decision on whether the not guilty plea was acceptable. The case was adjourned until November 17.

fields.headline: Gates derides digital donors
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Bill Gates poured scorn yesterday on the computer industry's attempts to improve access to technology in developing nations.
fields.body:
Bill Gates poured scorn yesterday on the computer industry's attempts to improve access to technology in developing nations.

At a conference in Seattle, the Microsoft founder stressed the need to improve the living conditions of some of the world's poorest people before giving them internet access.

"Do people have a clear view of what it means to live on $1 a day?" he asked an audience of technology industry professionals. "There's no electricity in that house. None."

In an interview with the New York Times following the conference, he suggested that giving a typical African village a computer was pointless.

"The mothers are going to walk right up to that computer and say, 'My children are dying, what can you do?' They're not going to sit there and browse eBay or something."

The comments of a man who is estimated to be worth more than $60bn met with a mixed response at a meeting designed to address the issue of "creating digital dividends".

John Gage, the chief research officer for Microsoft rival Sun Microsystems, described Mr Gates' comments as flippant and missing the point of the conference.

Some aid organisations have also pushed for the computer industry to do more to address the so-called digital divide between the world's technology haves and have-nots.

Mr Gates said yesterday that his views had been changed by the work of the $21bn Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. When he started to give away money to the charity, he thought it should focus on donating computers.

However, health care now accounts for at least two-thirds of payments made by the Gates foundation.

fields.headline: A real breakthrough
fields.standfirst: Delyth Morgan has overcome dyslexia to help millions of women as chief executive of Breakthrough Breast Cancer; Rachel Spence talked to her
fields.trailText: Delyth Morgan has overcome dyslexia to help millions of women as chief executive of Breakthrough Breast Cancer; Rachel Spence talked to her
fields.body:
Last Wednesday Delyth Morgan woke up a happy, if exhausted, woman. After 30 days of non-stop activity, the chief executive of Breakthrough Breast Cancer could claim that October 2000 was the most successful Breast Cancer Awareness month.

"This year, we raised £500,000 the highest figure yet," she tells me proudly, citing the increased number of nationwide fund-raising initiatives, such as pink ribbon outlets and breakfasts for Breakthrough, as the key to their achievement.

But she's just as keen to stress the importance of last week's meeting - facilitated by Breakthrough - between public health minister and unofficial "cancer minister", Yvette Cooper, and breast cancer charity representatives.

"It was our first opportunity to discuss the NHS cancer plan," she explains. "This kind of interaction is essential if we're to keep the pressure on politicians to implement the policies they talk about." Such is her poise and confidence, it's hard to imagine Ms Morgan in any other career, yet her present role is far from the one she envisaged. "I grew up believing I was going to be a research scientist," she explains. "I'm dyslexic, so as a child I was very under-confident in every area except science."

Ms Morgan gained a place at Bedford College, London to read physiology and biochemistry. "I was very bored during my first year because we were covering work I'd done. So I got involved in the student union to give myself another interest."

It proved a revelation and was, she now believes, her big break. "I discovered a world where people really believed they could make a difference to society. It was the mid-80s, and there was so much energy. We organised campaigns on everything from equal opportunities to the miners' strike."

To her amazement, Ms Morgan found herself ap pointed president of the London University student union, a full-time role which required a year's sabbatical. "Suddenly there I was, a 21-year-old dyslexic person, representing 50,000 students with a staff of 50 and a full-time secretary. That's when I began to think, 'Maybe I can do all sorts of things I never dreamt of'." She suspects her dyslexia might have been an advantage at times. "Apparently, dyslexics are good at seeing the big picture and become strong, verbal communicators, definitely strengths of mine."

Graduating with a 2:1, she found herself faced with a career choice she had never expected: to remain on her original, scientific path or step sideways into charity work. "After a wobbly moment, I went for the voluntary sector. It sounds clichéd but I really wanted to do good."

Her first job was working for Shelter. After two years there, she joined childcare charity, Workplace Nurseries, as director with a handful of staff. The experience proved invaluable. "I'm glad I've been part of the childcare debate; one of the highlights of my career was helping to persuade John Major to abolish the tax on workplace nurseries."

From there, Ms Morgan moved to the National Asthma Campaign. But when, three years later, she saw a tiny Guardian advertisement for the director of a low-profile breast cancer charity, she never hesitated. "I thought: 'That's me!' It was the right time and then breast cancer had affected my own family and I cared about it passionately."

She joined Breakthrough in 1996, the year it first ran the now-famous Fashion Targets Breast Cancer campaign, in which hundreds of the fash ion industry's most celebrated bodies modelled Breakthrough T-shirts.

Today, the charity is a nationally respected authority on a disease which affects one in 10 women. It is one of several organisations who inform the Department of Health on breast cancer issues; and this year Ms Morgan spoke at the Labour Party conference.

Yet long before, Breakthrough had been quietly accomplishing a remarkable feat; that of raising £15m to open the UK's first dedicated breast cancer research centre. The charity was started in 1991 by Bill Freedman, whose own wife died from the disease. Last December, Mr Freedman's dream was realised and the centre opened.

"We aim to have the biggest concentration of breast cancer scientists in the UK," says Ms Morgan. "In five years, we want to point to the work of the research centre and say 'Look what we've done!' " she says. Watch this space.

www.breakthrough.org.uk

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Europe
fields.body:
Europe

France: Enjoy a Paris winter break with VFB Holidays (01242 240 310, www.vfbholidays.co.uk.) from £159 per person. The four-night package is valid until February 26 (excluding December 19 - January 4) and includes return travel on Eurostar departing every Thursday and returning Monday, B&B accommodation, insurance and 10% discount at the Galeries Lafayette shopping centre.

Isle of Man: Stay in a farm cottage 15 minutes' drive from Douglas for seven nights self-catering. Sample week in May based on four sharing costs £163 per person including return sailing from Liverpool or Heysham (£207 by air from Liverpool). Everymann 0870 789 6777.

Spain: Flightbookers (020-7757 2700) is offering two-night breaks to Barcelona from £159 per person with travel valid January 1 - March 31. Tickets must be booked by November 17. The package includes return flights with Iberia from Heathrow and two nights' accommodation at the Hotel Splendid.

Africa

Morocco: Work off the Christmas calories on an eight-day walking package in the Atlas mountains departing Stansted on January 26. The price of £495 per person, based on a twin share, includes return flight to Marrakech, hotel and village-house accommodation, all meals on trek and guide. Walks Worldwide 01524 262255 (www.walksworldwide.com).

Middle East

Dubai: Three- and five-night packages from The Destination Group (020-7400 7037) cost from £329 and £389 respectively valid for departures between January 1 and April 4, offering the opportunity to visit the Dubai shopping festival, which runs throughout March. Package includes return flight from Heathrow and three- or four-star hotel accommodation.

Caribbean

Dominica: Visit the largest of the Windward Islands on a seven-day package that takes in forest walks, a volcanic lake and the chance to snorkel and scuba-dive. The tour price of £995 per person includes return flight from Heathrow and hotel accommodation. It is valid for departures year round excluding the July-October hurricane season. Wildlife Worldwide 020-8667 9158 (www.wildlifeworldwide.com).

North America

Florida: America Direct (0870 789 3334) is offering reductions of around £80 per person for those who book before May 31 to stay between January 1 and September 30 at the new Hard Rock Hotel, close to Universal Studios. A sample price including discount costs from £811 per person, based on two sharing, with return flight from Gatwick and room-only accommodation.

webTitle: Who lost their heart in  Taroudant, Morocco?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in...  Taroudant, Morocco
fields.standfirst: John Mortimer
fields.trailText: John Mortimer
fields.body:
Why: I'm a creature of habit. I first went to Morocco 30 years and have been back every year: Morocco in January/February, Tuscany in July/August. We stay in the same hotel so I know everybody. I like going to shops where everybody says hello. I hate going to restaurants that I haven't been to before. In Taroudant, I know exactly what I am going to eat and drink.

The most beautiful way to get to Taroudant is from Marrakesh. You drive across the Atlas mountains, over the snow line with the almond trees in blossom. Somewhere in the middle of the mountains is a lovely French bistro with checked table cloths and vin ordinaire. Then you come down on to a fertile plain, and there is Taroudant, a nice little town with big pink walls.

You can buy a second-hand set of false teeth from the second-hand false teeth shop, dead bats for use as an aphrodisiac, as well as chameleons or wonderful spices and strange bits of old carvings.

The best thing: It is very unlike England. The landscape is full of mountains, and it is very beautiful and sunny in January. I can sit under the trees in the garden and write, with the roses and carnations already in flower. And often there is a spicy, hot smell which is very intoxicating.

My advice: Please don't go to Taroudant, because I like it so much that I don't want too many English visitors coming to spoil it.

How to get there: Panorama (01273 427777) has seven nights' half board in Taroudant from £349 including return flights Gatwick to Agadir and transfers. Best of Morocco (01380 828533) has seven nights' half board for £645 including return flights from Heathrow.

 The Summer of a Dormouse by John Mortimer is published by Viking at £16.99.
fields.bodyText: Why: I'm a creature of habit. I first went to Morocco 30 years and have been back every year: Morocco in January/February, Tuscany in July/August. We stay in the same hotel so I know everybody. I like going to shops where everybody says hello. I hate going to restaurants that I haven't been to before. In Taroudant, I know exactly what I am going to eat and drink. The most beautiful way to get to Taroudant is from Marrakesh. You drive across the Atlas mountains, over the snow line with the almond trees in blossom. Somewhere in the middle of the mountains is a lovely French bistro with checked table cloths and vin ordinaire. Then you come down on to a fertile plain, and there is Taroudant, a nice little town with big pink walls. You can buy a second-hand set of false teeth from the second-hand false teeth shop, dead bats for use as an aphrodisiac, as well as chameleons or wonderful spices and strange bits of old carvings. The best thing: It is very unlike England. The landscape is full of mountains, and it is very beautiful and sunny in January. I can sit under the trees in the garden and write, with the roses and carnations already in flower. And often there is a spicy, hot smell which is very intoxicating. My advice: Please don't go to Taroudant, because I like it so much that I don't want too many English visitors coming to spoil it. How to get there: Panorama (01273 427777) has seven nights' half board in Taroudant from £349 including return flights Gatwick to Agadir and transfers. Best of Morocco (01380 828533) has seven nights' half board for £645 including return flights from Heathrow.  The Summer of a Dormouse by John Mortimer is published by Viking at £16.99.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Flash point
fields.body:
Flash point

The annual fireworks at Alexandra Palace Park are among the biggest and best in Britain. There's also a funfair, radio roadshow, beer festival and music.

Sat 7pm. Fireworks free, indoor events £1.50/£1. Alexandra Park, London N22.

Money to burn

Watch £25,000 go up in flames at what is reputedly Suffolk's biggest firework display. Expect funfairs, entertainers, live music and plenty to eat.

Sat, 6.30pm onwards. £4 in advance, £5 at gate. Christchurch Park, Ipswich, Suffolk (01473 258070).

Playing with fire

Street entertainers, candle art and safe spectator venues make Cleethorpes' Fire Festival a popular event for families.

Sat from 7pm. Free. Cleethorpes Beach, Cleethorpes, Lincs. Tourist office: 01472 323111.

Floating lights

Spectacular, mile-long evening processions of glittering floats make their way through three of the Mendip's most historic towns as their illuminated Guy Fawkes carnivals compete for trophies.

Nov 8 (Shepton Mallet), 10 (Wells) and 11 (Glastonbury). Information: 01749 343027.

Fun run

The London to Brighton Veteran Car Run commemorates Emancipation Day (when drivers no longer had to have a man preceding the car with a red flag).

Spectators are welcome along the route - from London's Hyde Park Corner between 7.30am and 9pm, along the A23 to Gatwick, the B2036 to Pycombe and the A23 to Brighton where cars begin to arrive in Madeira Drive from about 10.45am.

Return of the hero

Admiral Nelson will arrive at Great Yarmouth tomorrow aboard the Grand Turk as part of a huge re-enactment of Nelson's Return involving over 400 actors. A day of events culminates in a Victory Celebration in the market place and a firework finale.

November 5/6 from 10.30am. Great Yarmouth, Norfolk. Some events ticketed. Details: 01493 657575.

Moor lore

Visitors to Dunster's new Exmoor Visitor Centre can focus on what makes Exmoor special, try out hands-on activities and learn about the traditional wool and timber industries and today's national park conservation issues.

Open Sats and Suns 11am-3pm until December 17. Free. The Steep, Dunster, Devon (01643 821835).

London fields

Everything you need for Christmas, be it food, toys, decorations, houseware or stocking fillers, can be found under one gigantic roof at the Country Living Christmas Fair.

Nov 8-12, 10am-6pm (Sunday, 3pm). £10 on door, £9.50/£5 in advance. Business Design Centre, 52 Upper Street, London N1 (0870 739 9111).

fields.headline: From dusk till dawn
fields.standfirst: If you want to know about clubs in Britain, then The Guide has all you need to know every Saturday. But what if you want to experience further afield? A BBC Choice series asked some of the best DJs to choose where and when to find the hottest clubs on the planet.
fields.trailText: If you want to know about clubs in Britain, then The Guide has all you need to know every Saturday. But what if you want to experience further afield? A BBC Choice series asked some of the best DJs to choose where and when to find the hottest clubs on the planet.
fields.body:
Welcome to the global dance. It started in the late 1980s with Acid House - a simple, hypnotic brand of electronic dance music formed in the underground gay discos of New York, Chicago and Detroit, mixed up with trashy Euro disco on the dancefloors of Ibiza and often enjoyed alongside a new designer drug called Ecstasy. London and Manchester were the first British cities to succumb to it, but nothing this good could stay secret for long: by 1990, there was at least one big dance club in every town in the UK, and the culture was spreading all over the world.

Once, only weird kids wanted to dress up and dance all night - now this kind of clubbing is a mainstream leisure activity everywhere: from Tokyo to Telford, Birmingham to Bali. And it shows no sign of ending. The music has evolved, adapted, spun off into endless confusing categories and sub-groups, but the basic premise stays the same: repetitive electronic beats, big smiles, and huge crowds giving it lots of hands-in-the-air abandon.

Meanwhile, the clubs have got bigger, boasting massive sound systems and extravagant decor that will shock those of you whose last dance experience was a chrome disco with swirly carpets, a few flashing lights and a mirror ball.

In the past decade, major British clubs such as Ministry of Sound, Cream and Gatecrasher have become international youth culture brands, big businesses selling CDs, magazines and clothes and organising parties all over the globe. Our star DJs earn more in one night than some of us do in a year, leading a life many jet-setters would envy: summers in Ibiza or Ayia Napa, winters playing clubs in Australia, South America or South Africa, and regular monthly gigs in New York clubs.

The scene is now a huge global business with its own stars, its own social calendar with regular annual fixtures such as the gay mardi gras in Sydney, the Love Parade in Berlin, and the Miami Winter Music conference. It has also bred a whole new kind of tourism - clubbers who travel the world less to see the sights than to experience the nights. This is a guide to some of the club capitals of the world, but search in any big city and you'll find something similar. As the record says, "Let the music take control."

Berlin

"Berlin is such a great clubbing city because there has always been an interesting mix of clubbers and music since the East and West joined together"
DJ Paul Van Dyk

Local DJs Westbam, Sven Vath, Paul Van Dyk, Timo Maas, Jazzanova.
UK/American DJs Carl Cox, Jeff Mills, Derrick Carter and any of the big Techno names.

Icon Cantian Strasse 15 / Mila Strasse
Door: Dm10, Dm20 for special events
Housed in a building that used to be a brewery, this is the oldest Drum 'n' Bass venue in the city and has played host to famous DJs such as Grooverider, Peshay,and Doc Scott.

Rive Gauche Friedrichstrasse 105
Door: Dm 20 (weekends & Special events), Dm10 (Thursdays, when they have an after-work night)
Mainly populated by people in advertising, party people. The only club in Berlin next to the River Spree, it has two dance-floors, plus a coffee bar and a swimming pool.

Stern Radio Alexander Platz 5
Door: Dm15, Dm20 for special events)
Generally local crowd. The building used to be a restaurant. A lot of famous people go there, so they keep it as discreet for them as possible.

GayMF Johannisstrasse 19
Door: Dm15
Gay-only event on Sundays at the famous WMF. Jean Paul Gaultier is one of the few non-German celebs to visit the club.

Tresor Leipziger Strasse, 126a
Door: Wednesday Dm5, Fridays Dm10,Saturdays Dm15
Techno downstairs, House upstairs, and there is a Hip-Hop night on the first Thursday of every month.

Maria Am Ostbahnhof Strasse der Pariser Kommune 8-10
Door: Dm15
Building was previously a post office. They have a DJ playing in the toilets, and there are live concerts at the venue too. Ian Pooley, DJ Shadow, DJ Empire and DJ Nova have all played here.

The practicals: (all flight quotations departing from London and inclusive of taxes) Buzz (0870 240 7070 www.buzzaway.com) flies to Berlin for £105. British Airways (0845 77 333 77 www.britishairways.com) £153.70.

Buenos Aires

"Buenos Aires is perfect for me because it's a city that sleeps during the day and comes alive at night"
DJ Roger Sanchez

Local DJs Hernan Cattaneo, Javier Bussola, Urban Groove DJ collective, Diego Ro-K. UK/European/American DJs Paul Oakenfold, Sasha, Sander Kleinenberg, Deep Dish, Darren Emerson, Tall Paul, Roger Sanchez.

Urban Groove @ K2
Door: $9, or $7 with flyer
Drag queens, ravers and clubbers alike enjoy House and Techno with a bit of Chicago/Detroit techno. There is also another dancefloor for VIPs, playing House, Garage and catering for the older crowd. Urban Groove is a collection of eight DJs: Miguel Silver; DJ Magoo; Diego CID; DJ DEE Jason; Luis Nieva; DJ Jam On; DJ L'Inspecteur; VJ Fabian Marina.

Clubland @ Pacha Costanera Norte y La Pampa
Door: varies from $10 to $25
Features: Plays host to all of the imported clubs and events. All of the big name UK/Euro DJs play here, especially when Global Underground or Cream comes to town.

Magic@ Niceto Niceto Vega y Humboldt 5510
Door: $8
Ravers and clubbers 21-35 immerse themselves in Hard Trance and House - as hard as it gets.

El Divino Avenue Cecilia Grierson 225, Puerto Madero
Door: $20
House dance, hard Trance, Hard House, Progressive in a six-room complex that includes a restaurant.

Music @ Ciudad Gotica go to Pacha parking lot between 8am - 10am to be handed flyers
Door: $15 - but free with passes and flyers
Populated by an open minded gay crowd. There are never any problems on the door, unlike some other clubs. Clientele are really up for partying and going crazy.

Quintas (various recovery or carry on parties that happen at people's houses in country) go to Pacha parking lot between 8am - 10am to be handed flyers. You will need wheels to get there and take swimming gear.

The practicals: BA £535.80; Iberia (0845 601 2854 www.iberia.com) £395.60 (via Madrid).

Cape Town

"Being a conscious black man, South Africa was always a place I was compelled to visit. Going there as a professional gave me a certain amount of personal pride as 10 years ago a black professional in South Africa would have been a contradiction"
DJ Spoony

Local DJs Darren Africa, Nick E Lauder, Ready D, Bruno Morphet.
European/ UK DJs You can find the likes of Carl Cox, Spoony, Pete Tong, Judge Jules, Paul Oakenfold.

Dockside Century Boulevard, Rylands Estate
Door: Rand20 (members) R30 (non-members); girls get in free on Wednesday
Oakie, Judge Jules, Dave Seaman, Gatecrasher & Moneypenny's have all played there. The music is UK/ Euro Trance.

The Fez 38 Hout Street
Door: R30
Longest queues in Cape Town on a Thursday night. Fez on the beach is planned for next year.

Getafix corner of Long Street & Longmarket Street
Door: R20
Opens until the last trancer goes home. Novelty machine sells loose ciggies. The music is Tribal Trance.

96 94 Long Street
Door: R30
Friendly crowd - most people know each other. Funky dresscode with no hoods. The music is Hard House Club.

169 On Long 169 Long Street
Door: R30
House party atmosphere - and the longest balcony in Long Street. Music is R'n'B.

Gijima 88 Shortmarket Street
Door: R20
The music, Kwaito, is a local slowed down House music, mixed with African vocals and chants.

Plum Crazi 94-96 Long Street
Door: R20
Beds in the chillout room for a mid-night nap. Otherwise enjoy the Funky Disco.

Unity 11 Buitensingle Street
Door: R40 (strict security on door)
VIP lounge is open to those deemed to be "friends" of the owners. The music/vibe can best be described as off-your-face/die-hard ravers.

55 22 Somerset Road
Door: free as long as you drink
This gay club is in a converted butchery.

Rhodes House 60 Queen Victoria Street
Door: R50
Themed nights every Saturday (from Bond to Latino to Masked Ball) at this gay venue.

Moomba 77 Hout Street
Door: R50
Open from 11pm until the last person leaves. Queues can be up to an hour long. Lenny Kravitz & Mary J Blige hang out there when they're in town.

The practicals: BA £662.40; South African Airways (0870 7471111) £703.40.

New York

"New York, it's got everything for everyone."
DJ Erick Morillo

Local DJs Erick Morillo, Frankie Knuckles, Funkmaster Flex, Grandmaster Flash. UK/European DJs Carl Cox, Sasha, Paul Van Dyk, Paul Oakenfold, Danny Howells, John Digweed.

Vinyl 6 Hubert Street
Door: vary with event
The music is Eclectic House & Garage. Best nights: Wednesday, "Dance Ritual" DJ Lil Louie Vega, Fridays, "Be Yourself" DJ Danny Tenaglia, Sundays, "Body & Soul" DJs Francois Kevorkian, Joe Claussell & Danny Krivit. No alcohol licence.

Drinkland 339 East 10th Street (between Ave A & B)
Door: $3
Hip-hop starts the evening off, followed by Drum 'n' Bass spun by the best of NYC's few Junglist DJs. The clientele is a mixture of trendy students and muso types.

The Tunnel 220 Twelfth Ave at 27th St
Door: $20 (ladies), $30 (guys).
Hip-hop all the way. The best night is Sunday, which features Funkmaster Flex plus guests. The clientele consists of Hardcore B-boys and B-girls.

GBH! (Great British House!) Fridays @ Cheetah, 12 W 21st St between 5th & 6th Avenues
Door: $20
Populated by model worshippers and eurotrash.

Centro-Fly 45 W 21st Street between 5th & 6th Aves
Door: $20
Basically, if you look good you will get in. The clientele is a trendy mixed crowd, while the music is Deep House.

Spa 76 E 13th Street between Broadway & 4th Ave
Door: $20 (weekdays), $25 (weekends)
High-end A-list crowd enjoyingt House, Hip-hop disco.

The Fryin' Pan lighthouse boat docked at Pier 63, North River, NY 10011
Door: $1,000 rental for Fridays or Saturdays for private party.
For people who appreciate a unique space. Past DJs include Basement Jaxx, Roger Sanchez

Twilo 503 W27th between 10th & 11th
Door: $35
Attracts everybody, with the exception of the Hip-hop crowd. Music is Euro Progressive, Trance, Techno, House. If you want to get in, be prepared for a long wait followed by a serious grilling from the door staff.

The Roxy Roller Disco 515 W18th St between 10th & 11th Aves
Door: $12 before 9pm, then $15
Diverse crowd of bladers and skaters enjoying soul funk and rare groove.

Shine 285 West Broadway at Canal Street
Door:$5-$10
Celebs not wanting to be seen, DJs, cool crowd. The music varies. Chicago house veteran Ron Trent is a regular on Mondays. The Stereophonics named their album "Performance and Cocktails" in honour of Shine. The door policy is low key and friendly.

The practicals: BA £370.40; Virgin Atlantic (01293 747747 www.virgin-atlantic.com) £222. Quotes to/from JFK.

San Francisco

"There's a club in this town for everyone. In the past it's been rock-based but now dance music has taken a serious grip."
DJ Scott Bond

Local DJs Doc Marten, Spesh, Greg Sandler, Jason Dyloot, DJ Garth.
European DJs Steve Lawler, Pete Tong, Dave Seaman, Darren Emerson, Scott Bond, Mr. C, and Gilles Peterson are among the frequent visitors.

Eklektic Cat Club 1190 Folsom Street
Door: $10 ($2 off with flyer before 11pm)
Free-styling rules the dancefloor every Saturday. Fantastic female Drum 'n' Bass DJs.

Release Ten15 Folsom, 1015 Folsom Street
Door: $20
The longest running club in the city, it attracts a mixed crowd of club kids, underground heads and beautiful people. World-class DJs, but you get the feeling that people aren't there for the music.

Nikita Ten15 Folsom, 1015 Folsom Street
Door: $10 (21 and over)
Fridays-only event that attracts kids from the 'burbs. Voted best dance club for fifth consecutive year in the San Francisco Bay Guardian's "Best of the Bay 2000". Has something for everyone: Drum 'n' Bass in the basement, Techno upstairs, Progressive House in the main room, classic disco elsewhere.

Rawhide 280 7th Street
Door: free before 10pm on Wednesday, $5 after; Saturday: $5 before 10pm, $10 after
Laid back but getting down hard on the dancefloor. There is an outdoor smoking patio (lighting up is banned in all restaurants and clubs in San Francisco).

Square @ Ruby Skye 420 Mason Street
Door: $20 (21 and over)
Dress to impress the mix of beautiful people and lads on the pull. The music is funky, soulful and deep house. Note for historians: housed in one of the few buildings to survive the 1906 earthquake that devastated the city.

Re-cycle @ 550 Barneveld 550 Barneveld Ave
Door: $20 (21 and over)
Friday/Saturday. Hip club kids get busy on the dancefloor.

The Spinjam 150 Folsom Street
Door: donations appreciated
Every Thursday night. Starts with yoga and ambient sounds and slowly builds from there. The hardcore spinners like to show up early so they can have plenty of room to operate

Spundae Ten15 Folsom, 1015 Folsom Street
Door: varies (21 and over)
Local groovers serious about their music in intimate gathering - laid back and unpretentious. Attracts big international names, resident DJ is Jerry Bonham. Also check out the record store at 678 Haight Street.

The Beta Lounge 1072 Illinois Street, San Francisco
Door: free
Thursdays. Mix of tech-heads, sophisticated clubbing crowd. Some are loungey, laid back - too cool to dance.

Universe 177 Towsend Street
Door: $10 (21 and over)
HiNRG and house featured in this Gay sweat box

Futura Kings Street Garage, 174 Kings Street Second and fourth Saturday of each month
Door: $10, $3 before 11pm with flyer (21 and over)
The majority of the crowd is made up of gay Latino men, with about 20% female while the rest are straight couples. Referred to as "The Crown Jewel of Latino Club scene in San Fran".

The practicals: BA £268.30 (outward flight from London is via Phoenix); Virgin Atlantic £249.90.

Sydney

"As everyone saw at the recent Olympics, Sydney is one of the most exciting and vibrant cities in the world, and that extends to clubbing as well. It's also a very advanced scene out there with a strong infrastructure in place, much the same as England but on a much smaller scale."
DJ Dave Seaman

Local DJs Alex Taylor, John Course, Dynamic Dynamix, and Endorphin.
European DJs the Australian club scene attracts most UK/ Euro DJ's, both superstar and amateur - the likes of Carl Cox, Judge Jules, Brandon Block, Dave Seaman, Danny Rampling, and Darren Emerson.

Blue-print The Globe, King Head Tavern, 60 Park Street
Door: $8
The crowd can best be described as Gucci meets Puma. Two floors, Drum 'n' Bass downstairs, Breaks upstairs. Check out the bubbly lift operators who keep the crowds fully entertained in the elevator between the two floors.

The Chinese Laundry 3 Slip Street, Sydney (back entrance to Slip Inn)
Door: $15
Spend Saturday night in a basement rabbit warren with several bars, secret nooks and crannies and two separate dancefloors.

Sublime @ Home Cockle Bay Wharf, Darling Harbour NSW 2000
Door: $20
Four rooms, four styles: House, Techno, Breaks, Drum 'n' Bass. The crowd are young, full-on and up-for-it.

Home Cockle Bay Wharf, Darling Harbour
Door: $20
The queues at Home are pretty serious, so either arrive early and down a few cocktails in the Terrace bar, or become a member.

Frantic various venues (check flyers !)
Door: varies
Every two weeks. Door policy: no attitude, dress relaxed - shorts, trainers, whatever.

Tweekin' Club 77, William Street, Kings Cross
Door: $10
Full-on, the most happening vibe on a Friday night. It might be a dimly lit, grungy basement on the way to Kings Cross but Club 77 gives more than any other venue to Sydney's club scene. No wonder it won best club at the Australian Dance Awards while resident DJ Phil Smart was voted the best in the business.

Sounds on Sunday Greenwood Hotel, Greenwood Plaza 36 Blue Street, North Sydney
Door: $8 noon-2pm; $12 after 2pm
Mix of dirty stop-outs and groovers out for a Sunday afternoon chill out. Big line-ups with Sydney's finest DJs spinning throughout the day, themed rooms, chill areas and a café. Headliners in the public bar do Hi-NRG, Hard-House, Techno and Trance, while the outdoor arena offers a retro, garage, disco feel. The Groove Café features old school, soul and funk.

The practicals: BA £1,013.30; Qantas (0845 7 747 767) £828.

Tel Aviv

"Tel Aviv is a rocking, very modern city full of culture: from the Museum of Modern Art to exciting ground breaking clubs. It is also a city with beaches coupled with beautiful areas such as the old port at Jaffa. It has got everything old and new, with a very receptive cosmopolitan club scene committed to finding out what key sound is driving the music scene at that moment."
DJ Sister Bliss

Local DJs Jez & Choopie, Ella Gutman, Sahar Z, Zidan.
European/UK DJs all the major players are frequent on the Israeli scene, especially the likes of Sasha, Sister Bliss, Danny Howells, Brandon Block, Dave Seaman, and Scott Bond.

Club House Pacha, Kaufman Street
Door: Israeli shekel (IS)70
Beautiful Ibiza-inspired venue is the place to get loved-up in Tel Aviv. Expect crews such as God's Kitchen with Seb Fontaine to show up for the party.

Techno Ha'oman 17 , Ha'oman 17
Door: IS80
Viewed by many as the greatest club in Israel - very Ibizan in style. Upcoming Israeli star Sahar Z is resident DJ. Every winter the club moves to Tel Aviv beach while the venue is rebuilt from scratch.

Alternative Electronica Dinamo Divash, Abarbanel Street
Door: up to IS70

fields.bodyText: Welcome to the global dance. It started in the late 1980s with Acid House - a simple, hypnotic brand of electronic dance music formed in the underground gay discos of New York, Chicago and Detroit, mixed up with trashy Euro disco on the dancefloors of Ibiza and often enjoyed alongside a new designer drug called Ecstasy. London and Manchester were the first British cities to succumb to it, but nothing this good could stay secret for long: by 1990, there was at least one big dance club in every town in the UK, and the culture was spreading all over the world. Once, only weird kids wanted to dress up and dance all night - now this kind of clubbing is a mainstream leisure activity everywhere: from Tokyo to Telford, Birmingham to Bali. And it shows no sign of ending. The music has evolved, adapted, spun off into endless confusing categories and sub-groups, but the basic premise stays the same: repetitive electronic beats, big smiles, and huge crowds giving it lots of hands-in-the-air abandon. Meanwhile, the clubs have got bigger, boasting massive sound systems and extravagant decor that will shock those of you whose last dance experience was a chrome disco with swirly carpets, a few flashing lights and a mirror ball. In the past decade, major British clubs such as Ministry of Sound, Cream and Gatecrasher have become international youth culture brands, big businesses selling CDs, magazines and clothes and organising parties all over the globe. Our star DJs earn more in one night than some of us do in a year, leading a life many jet-setters would envy: summers in Ibiza or Ayia Napa, winters playing clubs in Australia, South America or South Africa, and regular monthly gigs in New York clubs. The scene is now a huge global business with its own stars, its own social calendar with regular annual fixtures such as the gay mardi gras in Sydney, the Love Parade in Berlin, and the Miami Winter Music conference. It has also bred a whole new kind of tourism - clubbers who travel the world less to see the sights than to experience the nights. This is a guide to some of the club capitals of the world, but search in any big city and you'll find something similar. As the record says, "Let the music take control." The only club in Berlin next to the River Spree, it has two dance-floors, plus a coffee bar and a swimming pool. fields.headline: Katadyn Combi (water filter)
fields.trailText: It can filter 50,000 litres of water and remove 99.99% of all bacteria, cysts and protozoa such as giardia.
fields.body:
I've got my tickets, passport and kit and am heading out to India, but how do I avoid Delhi belly?
The growing problem of water contamination means it's worth investing in a water filter. Most fresh water in the world is contaminated with bacteria.

Are they heavy, expensive and hard to use?
Not any more. Your best bet is a Combi, which combines a ceramic and carbon filter. It can filter 50,000 litres of water and remove 99.99% of all bacteria, cysts and protozoa such as giardia.

How does it work?
You fill it up with water and pump it through a filter that removes the debris.

What about cleaning my teeth? I've heard you can get ill from something as simple as that?
Very true, but the Combi can easily be attached to a tap for instant results.

Where do I get it?
Phone 01364 631270 for stockists. The Combi costs £119.95, and the Combi Plus is £139.95.

webTitle: Kim Winter: Alarm clock | Green tea | Sarong

fields.headline: Kim Winter never travels without...
fields.standfirst: Alarm clock | Green tea | Sarong
fields.trailText: Alarm clock | Green tea | Sarong
fields.body:
A necessity: My alarm clock. I once asked for a wake-up call in a hotel, and it never happened. I woke up 20 minutes before my flight, but amazingly I did catch it.

A luxury: Green tea bags, jasmine or Chinese tea. I don't drink coffee, and English tea is usually too strong.

A memento: A bright-orange sarong I got in Singapore. It is so useful as a towel or dressing gown.

If only: I'm studying for my pilot's licence, and would love to have a private plane to ferry myself around the Caribbean.

 Kim Winter is co-editor of the Which? Hotel Guide 2001.

fields.headline: Over the rainbow
fields.standfirst: www.rainbownetwork.otc-uk.com
fields.trailText: www.rainbownetwork.otc-uk.com
fields.body:
Rainbows? Is this a site for the concerned ecotourist?
No. Doesn't the subtitle "Going Out Channel" give you a clue?

Sounds perfectly straightforward to me.
The Rainbow Network is Britain's biggest gay and lesbian travel site. How else would you find out about European Gay Ski Week in March and the exclusively gay hotels in Palm Springs, California?

Can anyone join in?
Because the Rainbow Network is produced in association with OTC, a company with its own site, holidays booked here are not exclusively gay. The Travel Guides section, however, has plenty of recommendations and first-person accounts of gay and lesbian holidays. Some are a bit obvious (gay hotels in Brighton, lesbian trips to Lesbos) but others are more imaginative.

What if I want a specialist holiday?
Go to the events and holidays page. Opportunities range from a women-only weekend in Dublin next April to the Mr Leatherman contest in Toronto.

I just want to get out of Christmas at home.
The Rainbow Network suggests Christmas in Provincetown, US, describing it as an "explosion of queerness". The Boston Gay Men's Chorus are singing, and sleighs and elves will be in attendance. Despite its deal with OTC, the Rainbow Network links to companies specialising in gay travel, so other possibilities probably exist.

The Travel Guides section, however, has plenty of recommendations and first-person accounts of gay and lesbian holidays. Some are a bit obvious (gay hotels in Brighton, lesbian trips to Lesbos) but others are more imaginative. What if I want a specialist holiday? Go to the events and holidays page. Opportunities range from a women-only weekend in Dublin next April to the Mr Leatherman contest in Toronto. I just want to get out of Christmas at home. The Rainbow Network suggests Christmas in Provincetown, US, describing it as an "explosion of queerness". The Boston Gay Men's Chorus are singing, and sleighs and elves will be in attendance. Despite its deal with OTC, the Rainbow Network links to companies specialising in gay travel, so other possibilities probably exist.

webTitle: On the trail of Grey Owl

fields.headline: On the trail of Grey Owl
fields.standfirst: Richard Attenborough's new film celebrates the unlikely life of a pioneer environmentalist. Cathy Smith explores his unspoilt wilderness
fields.trailText: Richard Attenborough's new film celebrates the unlikely life of a pioneer environmentalist. Cathy Smith explores his unspoilt wilderness.
fields.body:
Before we had even loaded the gear into the canoe, the lake had changed from gentle ripples to heaving troughs, tossing foam into the wind. I was all for unpacking the tents and creeping back into the woods, but my guide Colleen expected me to get onboard and start paddling, so I put on a brave face.

It took us six and a half hours to paddle seven miles. There isn't a word to describe how scared I was. It wasn't much comfort to know I had come all this way to find the shack of a long-dead fraud, drunk and serial bigamist called Archie Belaney.

When we finally turned into the calm, I felt as though my shoulders had converged into a painful lump at the back of my neck. But suddenly it was worth it, a true wilderness experience, and I could see what had brought Archie all the way from Hastings to northern Saskatchewan to reinvent himself as a Canadian Indian called Grey Owl.

When he first saw Ajawaan lake, Archie knew this was the place he was looking for. Here he wrote some of the books that were to make him famous as one of the world's first conservationists.

My journey to Ajawaan started at the village of Waskesiu, a pleasant resort with boutiques, restaurants, and one of the most beautiful golf courses in the province. But we decided to forego these pleasures and drove the 15 miles to where the road peters out. There, we parked the car, unloaded the canoe, and were on our way.

We began very gently along a quiet little river, the Kingsmere, lined with cat-tail reeds. This peaceful introduction to paddling a canoe was perfect for a first-timer like myself, and I soon got into the rhythm of it. However, once we reached Kingsmere lake, after about a mile and half of paddling, it was a different story - now it was time for some real canoeing.

There was also a sense of isolation, of being the only two human beings on a vast expanse of water, the horizon of our destination way out of sight.

The lake is 11 miles long straight down the middle. But forget about the middle - the golden rule is stick to the shore line, which makes the journey longer but is much safer. These lakes can be whipped up in a matter of minutes - and you're out of luck if you are caught in the centre.

Along the way, we saw bald eagles and kingfishers. Red squirrels scampered along the shore as we pulled in at Northend, the last campsite before reaching the cabin.

The campsites in the park are spartan but clean - all campers carry out their own rubbish. There's a place for a fire, a toilet - usually tucked away in the trees - and a raised platform reached by a wooden ladder where food must be stashed overnight, out of reach of the black bears. They look cuddly and friendly, but they are unpredictable and physically powerful. All they think about is food: they will eat anything from a can of beans to a tube of toothpaste. Even lipstick.

Through the open flap of my tent, I saw the great sweep of the northern lights and dozed off to the lament of loons - diver birds. Early in the morning, a plume of mist rose through the pale sunshine, rising across the lake like a white rainbow. I heard the howling of wolves in the distance and a dawn chorus of unknown songs from birds with unfamiliar names.

We walked the remaining couple of miles to the lake. The sun shone through glades of birch and aspen and the undergrowth was full of rustlings. It was a narrow trail, soft underfoot with moss and leaves, little changed since Grey Owl hauled his canoe along here.

The cabin stands by the edge of the lake, surrounded by thick forest. Built from rounded logs with a traditional caulking of moss, it incorporates the beaver lodge from which the building takes its name. The beavers, which often feature in Grey Owl's writings and whom he called "the wilderness personified", would enter the one-room cabin from the lake via an underwater entrance.

The bed he constructed from stripped pine saplings stands against the wall, as does his blackened wood-burning stove. The cabin is unlocked and unattended, and visitors are free to enter.

As we sat on the porch in the sun, the only sounds were the light plop of a fish in the lake, the chatter of the birds, and the scuttlings of squirrels. Up a nearby slope is the cabin built for Grey Owl's wife, Anahareo (real name Gertrude Bernard), when their daughter was born. Close by in a clearing are the gravestones marking the spot where all three are buried.

As we set out for the return hike to the campsite, a silver fox walked across the path in front of us; we froze, and he did too, eyes and ears quickly checking us out, then calmly continued on his way, his great silver bush of a tail disappearing into the forest.

My trip was by canoe and on foot, as this is how Grey Owl would have travelled, but you can reach the cabin entirely on foot. Park officials recommend taking at least two days to complete the 25 mile round-trip. The trail begins at the Kingsmere river and follows the east shore of Kingsmere, lake alternating between forested pathways and stretches of beach walking. The beaches are fine for sunbathing, but you need to be hardier than me to swim in these northern lakes. They are never warm enough even in the height of summer.

About eight miles along the trail is a mineral lick, a good spot to look for signs of moose, deer, bear and wolves.

To preserve the wilderness experience, the park has deliberately limited access to the trail. One of the three campsites, Chipewyan, contains only two berths, a double and a single.

The Grey Owl trail is a popular attraction, but there's much more to Prince Albert National Park. It spreads over 405,000 hectares (1m acres) in the middle of Saskatchewan and sits on the southern edge of a great forest of spruce, pine, birch and aspen. There are more nesting songbirds here than anywhere else in North America - more than 230 species - elk, badger, lynx, osprey eagle, a flock of rare white pelicans and a free-roaming herd of plains bison. It is also one of the few places left in the world where timber wolves live undisturbed.

Grey Owl would be pleased to see that his world remains largely unchanged, and, I'm sure, encouraged by its continuing ability to inspire awe in those who have chosen to follow in his footsteps.

 Richard Attenborough's film biography, Grey Owl, opened yesterday.

The practicals

Canadian Airlines (0870 524 7226) flies from Heathrow to Saskatoon via Calgary for £461 return. Vehicle rentals are available at Saskatoon Airport. See www. virtualsk.com for details. There is also a bus once a day to Prince Albert National Park. For further information, contact Prince Albert National Park, PO Box 100, Waskesiu Lake, Saskatchewan SOJ 2YO, Canada (tel: 001 306 663 4522, e-mail: panp.info@pch.gc .ca, website, www.parcscanada.gc.ca/parks/saskatchewan/prince_albert/Prince_albert_e.htm Also check out Visit Canada Centre 0891 715000.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: Ulla Stede wants to take her motorhome to the French Alps this winter for a skiing holiday. She asked for details of campsites that are open all year with good access to the slopes.
fields.body:
Ulla Stede wants to take her motorhome to the French Alps this winter for a skiing holiday. She asked for details of campsites that are open all year with good access to the slopes.

 Many resorts have campsites open in winter (Caravaneige). Try Morzine (Les Portes Soleils) with two sites, one at the end of Morzine, the other in the next viilage down the valley. You can also camp for free in the car park (near the Gendarmerie and supermarket) in the centre of Morzine.

Make sure your vehicle has maximum antifreeze and is well insulated. Take an extra electric heater for campsite use. Two years ago, just before Xmas, the temperature dropped to -28C and stayed below -8C for over a week. Make sure tyres are in good nick, and take snow chains (you may not be allowed on some roads without them).
Patricia and Guy Featherstone

Lesley Sainbury's husband comes from a large family (32 at the last count). She wants to find suitable self-catering accommodation in the UK where they can all go on holiday together.

 Plas Dolau (Lovesgrove, Aberystwyth, Ceredigion SY23 3HP, tel: 01970 617834) is a comfortable country mansion providing affordable holiday accommodation for large families. Also see the Independent Hostel Guide (Backpacker Press, 2 Rockview Cottages, Matlock Bath, Derbyshire, tel: 01629 580427) or contact Christian Camping International (tel: 024 7655 9099).
Pat Twigg

 Camping barns are ideal. In the Yorkshire Dales, one at Littondale sleeps 40 and one at Ingleton sleeps 48. Details from the National Park Centre (tel: 01756 752 774). Stonelands Farm Yard Cottages, Litton, N Yorks (tel: 01756 770293) is a barn conversion with 10 cottages and an indoor pool.
Kathleen Vittery

 The Walkers Hostel, Ulverston, Cumbria (01229 585588) provides brilliant self-catering accommodation - 30 beds in seven rooms, £300 a weekend, £720 a week.
Jean Povey

 We unfortunately omitted the last part of last week's letter from Gerry Bates on the subject of electronic mosquito deterrents. He said it had worked well but added that this was only "until the controversy over the device's efficacy arose. After that, it didn't work at all."

Rather than wishing to give an unconditional endorsement of the device, he now thinks that it only appeared to work because he believed that it did so - a placebo effect.

This week's question

Roy Lane wants to travel to North Korea. It it possible? How easy is it to obtain a visa? Would he have to travel with an organised group? How expensive is it?

If you have questions or advice, please write to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: ask.a.fellow.traveller@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: The Xmas files
fields.standfirst: Don't fancy a last-minute trudge down the high street? Joanna Israelsohn finds the most enjoyable ways to wrap up your presents
fields.trailText: Don't fancy a last-minute trudge down the high street? Joanna Israelsohn finds the most enjoyable ways to wrap up your presents.
fields.body:
London

Head for Regent Street, made trendy by cheap'n'chic new clothing arrivals Zara and Mango. Don't miss Agent Provocateur, in nearby Broadwick Street, for the sexiest smalls known to man.

Skip Covent Garden's covered market and head towards the downstairs bazaar at Neal Street East for the cheapest stocking fillers in town. Nearby Duffer of St George, Shorts Gardens, has the coolest men's labels and Neal's Yard Dairy the whiffiest cheeses. Stop to recharge and refuel at Wagamama on Lexington Street.

Of London's markets, Portobello is arguably the funkiest. Nearby you'll find Graham & Green on Elgin Crescent for homeware, Emma Bernhardt on Portobello Rd for Mexican knick knacks and the Travel Bookshop on Blenheim Crescent.

Urban Outfitters on Kensington High Street is the place for kitsch and affordable homeware, clobber, cosmetics and gadgets.

Two nights' bed and breakfast with London Travel Service (01992 456177) from £82.

Bath

"Bath is a charming place, sir, there are so many good shops here," wrote Jane Austen in Northanger Abbey. Almost 200 years later, her observation is as true as ever, the bonus for the visiting shopper being a weekend in some of Britain's most elegant Georgian crescents and squares.

Union Street, Stall Street and Southgate form the shopping nucleus, where you'll find high-street stores aplenty - choose from Hobbs, Russell & Bromley and Liberty among others. Milsom Street is the most elegant - you'll recognise Jolly's department store from the television series The House of Elliot. Stock up on Somerset cheddar from the The Fine Cheese Shop on Walcot St.

Bath has a bewildering number of antique shops - Piccadilly Antiques on London Road is one of the best - as well as the Great Western Antique Market and Bartlett Street Antique Market, facing each other on Bartlett Street.

Two nights' B&B at The Francis hotel (0870 4008 223) from £118 per person. Call the Bath tourist information centre for a full list of hotels (01225 477 101).

Paris

No cheaper than London but certainly more chic, the French capital is ideal for presents with a certain je ne sais quoi. Check out Au Nain Bleu on rue St Honoré, France's premier toyshop, a must for Eurostar train-sets and Babyfoot tables. A few blocks further down is Collette, a one-stop shop selling the latest in fashion, design and art. There's nowhere better to nibble than upmarket food hall Fauchon, Place de la Madeleine, then continue to La Comtesse du Barry, bd Haussmann, where staff will giftwrap terrines, patés and foie gras. Stock up on neutral basics for men, women and children at Agnès b on Rue du Jour and don't miss Le Marais quartiers, the Soho of Paris with quirky interiors boutiques Décalage, Rue des Francs Bourgeois, and Boutique Paris-Musées, five shops down, where all stock is inspired by Parisian museum exhibits.

Back in St Germain, you'll find Sabbia Rosa, rue des Saints-Pères, brassiere purveyor to the stars, and Diptyque, blvd Saint Germain, whose delicious candles are £10 cheaper than in the UK.

Two nights in Paris by Eurostar with VFB Holidays (01242 240 310) from £169 per person.

Boston

You get more for your dollar in New England that in New York -there's no sales tax on clothing and only 5% on other goodies compared with 8.5%. The city can be easily divided into five main shopping areas - Newbury Street, Beacon Hill, Faneuil Hall Marketplace (including hundreds of food stalls), Copley Place and Downtown Crossing.

The top end of Newbury Street is home to big name designers such as Armani - even European labels are cheaper in the States - with an almighty Tower Records at the west end. Copley Place has over 100 shops, including stateside favourites Neiman Marcus (clothing), Tiffany (jewellery) and J Crew (clothing) with a branch of Saks Fifth Avenue in the nearby Prudential Centre.

Downtown Crossing is home to Filene 's department store and its famous basement Automatic Markdown Plan, where items get cheaper the longer they've been on sale. Don't forget Boston's nearby factory outlet malls Wrentham Village and Worcester Common, both a bus ride from town, featuring the usual suspects - Banana Republic, Donna Karan, Timberland, Calvin Klein, The Gap etc.

Four nights' B&B in Boston with Thomas Cook (01733 418 100) from £359 per person.

Christmas markets

Nuremberg, Vienna, Munich, Cologne and Salzburg are the favourites, but the smaller markets in Brussels, Bruges, Antwerp, Ghent, Strasbourg, Luxembourg, Hamburg, Stuttgart, Innsbruck and Gothenburg are also well worth a visit.

Travelscene (020-8427 8800) features 20 Christmas market destinations including two nights' B&B in Salzburg from £258 per person.

Marrakech

The Djemaa el Fna, the city's central market place and surrounding souks, sell everything you could want and more. Haggling is a must; if you really think you need a hand, ask your hotel for a guide or go to Ensemble Artisanal, a fixed-price craft shop on Mohammed V. Babouches, soft slippers in suede or leather, can be picked up in the Souk des Babouches and kids will love Star Wars-style hooded djellabahs - try Karsan Ahmed, Souk Defa ou Rabaa. Plain white-cotton kaftans are a better bet for adults; Maison du Kaftan Marocain, rue Sidi El Yamani, has the biggest range. Buy carpets from Bazar Jouti, Souk des Tapis and lanterns and ironwork from Souk Dylaouine. If you want to spend a little more, try Khalid Art Gallery, rue Dar el Bacha, for beautiful antiques at surprisingly reasonable prices. Don't forget the spice market for bags of saffron, jars of harissa and juicy olives.

Four nights' B&B in Marrakech from £359 per person with Thomson Breakaway (0208-210 4210).

Lille

Only two hours from London, Lille is fast building a reputation as a shopping haven. And with nearly every designer label on sale in the enormous Euralille mall with branches of Kookai, Morgan, Naf Naf (all cheaper than in the UK), and a McArthur Glenn discount outlet half an hour out of town, it's not hard to see why.

The pedestrian area to the south of Grand Place has high-street names in art-déco streets decorated with hanging baskets; try Authentic Licence for menswear and Bidule for streetwear and denim, both rue de Béthune. In Vieux Lille, try Michel Ruc for local designers such as Anne Demeulemeester.

Don't miss the famous Wazemmes Sunday market where you can bargain hunt and snack at food stalls serving paella and couscous. Lille is great for foodies; the Carrefour hypermarket for regional specialities; Philippe Olivier on rue du Cure Saint Etienne for cheese and La Cave d'Annie Paule, rue de l'Hopital Militaire, for wine.

Three nights' B&B by Eurostar with Cresta Holidays (0870 161 0920) from £169 per person.

Don't forget Boston's nearby factory outlet malls Wrentham Village and Worcester Common, both a bus ride from town, featuring the usual suspects - Banana Republic, Donna Karan, Timberland, Calvin Klein, The Gap etc. Four nights' B&B in Boston with Thomas Cook (01733 418 100) from £359 per person. Christmas markets Nuremberg, Vienna, Munich, Cologne and Salzburg are the favourites, but the smaller markets in Brussels, Bruges, Antwerp, Ghent, Strasbourg, Luxembourg, Hamburg, Stuttgart, Innsbruck and Gothenburg are also well worth a visit. Travelscene (020-8427 8800) features 20 Christmas market destinations including two nights' B&B in Salzburg from £258 per person. Marrakech The Djemaa el Fna, the city's central market place and surrounding souks, sell everything you could want and more. Haggling is a must; if you really think you need a hand, ask your hotel for a guide or go to Ensemble Artisanal, a fixed-price craft shop on Mohammed V. Babouches, soft slippers in suede or leather, can be picked up in the Souk des Babouches and kids will love Star Wars-style hooded djellabahs - try Karsan Ahmed, Souk Defa ou Rabaa. Plain white-cotton kaftans are a better bet for adults; Maison du Kaftan Marocain, rue Sidi El Yamani, has the biggest range. Buy carpets from Bazar Jouti, Souk des Tapis and lanterns and ironwork from Souk Dylaouine. If you want to spend a little more, try Khalid Art Gallery, rue Dar el Bacha, for beautiful antiques at surprisingly reasonable prices. Don't forget the spice market for bags of saffron, jars of harissa and juicy olives. Four nights' B&B in Marrakech from £359 per person with Thomson Breakaway (0208-210 4210). Lille Only two hours from London, Lille is fast building a reputation as a shopping haven. And with nearly every designer label on sale in the enormous Euralille mall with branches of Kookai, Morgan, Naf Naf (all cheaper than in the UK), and a McArthur Glenn discount outlet half an hour out of town, it's not hard to see why. The pedestrian area to the south of Grand Place has high-street names in art-déco streets decorated with hanging baskets; try Authentic Licence for menswear and Bidule for streetwear and denim, both rue de Béthune. In Vieux Lille, try Michel Ruc for local designers such as Anne Demeulemeester. Don't miss the famous Wazemmes Sunday market where you can bargain hunt and snack at food stalls serving paella and couscous. Lille is great for foodies; the Carrefour hypermarket for regional specialities; Philippe Olivier on rue du Cure Saint Etienne for cheese and La Cave d'Annie Paule, rue de l'Hopital Militaire, for wine. Three nights' B&B by Eurostar with Cresta Holidays (0870 161 0920) from £169 per person.

webTitle: Travel: Confidence still high on the Channel

fields.headline: Confidence still high on the Channel
fields.trailText: The horrors of last Sunday night/Monday morning, when 6,000 passengers were trapped on board ferries by gales, will not stop the pre-Christmas cross-Channel stampede. As a P&O Stena spokesman put it, "People's desire to travel does overcome their fears."
fields.body:
The horrors of last Sunday night/Monday morning, when 6,000 passengers were trapped on board ferries by gales, will not stop the pre-Christmas cross-Channel stampede. As a P&O Stena spokesman put it, "People's desire to travel does overcome their fears."

The French hypermarkets are gearing up for the annual onslaught, with Calais hypermarket openings extended to include Sundays.

Cross-channel operators are offering evening trips at below £20, allowing just enough time to shop and eat, and overnight trips at under £60. Hoverspeed, which is trail blazing with home delivery of duty-paid goods, has even added washing powders to its stores' ranges.

But the recent chaos does pose questions. It was not, insists P&O, that the weather made crossing unsafe, although both SeaFrance, with smaller ferries, and Hoverspeed, with catamarans, did cancel. For P&O's superferries, which remain relatively comfortable even in gales, the problem was that the Dover Port Authorities took the almost unprecedented decision to shut down.

Two of Dover's 16 berths were unusable, and manoeuvring in port was difficult. Ferries were already at sea when the decision was finally made, and because of their size, the ferries cannot use any other south-coast or French port. The rarity of the event seems to have taken everybody by surprise.

In the circumstances, all operators are bending over backwards to ignore their own small print and offer alternatives to inconvenienced travellers, even when they are not liable. P&O is offering a free ticket to all passengers who were booked last weekend, and Eurotunnel, which was unaffected, is offering exchange tickets to passengers who missed trains, even those on non-refundable tickets.

They all say, too, that they try to help where passengers are worried about travelling in storms, even if means missing unchangeable booked crossings, and to offer creature comforts. "We have run soup kitchens for lorry drivers during French strikes," P&O pointed out. "We want happy customers who will come back."

 Eurotunnel (0345 303030 www.eurotunnel.com) and P&O Stena (0870 600 0600, www.posl.com) offer evening trips at £15 for a car and up to five people. Hoverspeed (0820 003 555) has an overnight £59 ticket, for a car and nine people. Eurotunnel's Netsaver website special, available when it has unsold capacity, is three days for £75, non-refundable (five days for £101 - £149, depending on crossing times). Other special offers abound, giving discounts, free booze or hotel deals.

fields.headline: Heart of stone
fields.standfirst: Roly Smith ponders the origins of the rock formations at Brimham in north Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Roly Smith ponders the origins of the rock formations at Brimham in north Yorkshire.
fields.body:
Eighteenth-century antiquaries could not believe that the fantastic natural collection of gritstone rocks and tors at Brimham, overlooking Nidderdale in north Yorkshire, were not the remains of some ancient, long-forgotten civilisation.

The pioneer archaeologist Major Hayman Rooke, nicknamed the "Resurrection Major" by his contemporaries for his prodigious programme of barrow-digging, actually concluded in a paper presented to the Society of Antiquaries in 1786 that they were the work of "artists skilled in the power of mathematics".

Inevitably, it was the mysterious priesthood of the Druids who were favoured as the "builders" of this amazing natural sculpture park, although we now know that they emerged relatively late on the British scene during the pagan pre-Roman, Celtic period, around 2,000 years ago.

The truth is that during the 18th and 19th centuries, just about every freak of nature and prehistoric monument, especially the celebrated stone circles and henges such as Wiltshire's Stonehenge and Avebury, and Castlerigg in Cumbria, were attributed to the Druids. As an 18th century parson commented: "On no subject has fancy roamed with more licentious indulgence than on the Druids and their institutions."

So it comes as no surprise to find that many of Brimham's bizarre rock formations were named after those white-robed and bearded priests of the oak groves. There's the Druid's Writing Desk, a flat, table-topped tor which overlooks Nidderdale towards the distant heights of Great Whernside; the Druid's Coffin, a body-shaped crevice; the astonishing Druid's Idol, a massive 200-ton boulder perched precariously on a tiny, 12-inch diameter pedestal; and the Pulpit, which stands awaiting a preacher brave enough to clamber up to its vantage point. And hidden away among the fallen boulders and lacy birches under the rocky escarpment beneath the moor's western edge is the Druid's Cave.

The imagination of the early explorers of Brimham's rock garden was not confined to Druidism, however, and other rocks go under such fanciful zoological names as the Sphinx; the Turtle; the Dancing Bear; the Eagle; and the Camel. Some names are more recent: Donald Duck and General de Gaulle.

Brimham Rocks are normally reached by taking the minor road north from Summerbridge, and our walk starts from the extensive National Trust car park to the south of the rocks themselves.

A broad sandy ride leads fairly directly through the rocks towards Brimham House, originally built as a shooting lodge by Lord Grantley in 1792, but now providing refreshments for visitors and an interesting exhibition that attempts to answer: "How on earth were these extraordinary rocks formed?"

In simple terms, they are the result of aeons of natural erosion by wind, frost and rain which first exposed and then gradually worked on the weaker joints of the millstone grit rocks to create the amazing shapes we see today.

The panorama from the balcony of Brimham House is rightly celebrated, extending from the comical shape of the Flowerpot past the Turtle and Eagle, round to Crown Rocks and the Cannon, pointing menacingly out across Nidderdale.

There are hundreds of paths to explore, but be sure that you don't miss the beaked Turtle, which seems to be standing improbably on its hind feet in front of and to the east of the House, nor the Druid's Idol, an extraordinary feat of natural balance that stands behind the House on the northern edge of the moor, close to the Druid's Writing Desk.

Once you have exhausted Brimham's wonderland - and you should allow a good hour for this - a pleasant way to explore a little more of Nidderdale is to take the waymarked path which leads north from the rocks, zig-zagging down through the trees past the farmstead of North Pasture to reach the B6265, which is then followed left to reach the hamlet of Fell Beck.

From Knoll Top, at the western end of the hamlet, take the path left which leads through the extensive birches beneath Knoxstone Crags and follows the eastern bank of Fell Beck for about a mile, joining the Nidderdale Way to eventually reach the village of Smelthouses.

This charming little group of buildings takes its strangely industrial name from the fact that it was once the site of the mills which smelted the lead ore from the Yorke family's mines higher up in the upper part of Nidderdale, where limestone is the dominant rock. Many of the "highly desirable" cottages in the village started life as miners' and smelters' houses.

After following the minor road for a short distance, turn left following the Nidderdale Way signs onto the beautiful, broad green way known as the Monk's Road. This lovely byway takes its name from the fact that it was used by the white-robed Cistercians of Fountains Abbey, just five miles away to the east, to link with their sheep farms and lead mines in Upper Nidderdale.

The Monk's Way climbs steadily through the meadows and back towards Brimham Rocks, which now appear on the horizon ahead, until it reaches the minor road at Maud's Farm. It is now a short walk back to the car park, and perhaps a further exploration of those fascinating rocks.

The practicals

Brimham Rocks is about 10 miles north-west of Harrogate, and three miles east of Pateley Bridge, off the B6165 Ripley to Pateley Bridge road. The rocks are reached by taking the signposted minor road north from Summerbridge.

The walk described is about 5 miles and should take about three hours, but you should allow at least another hour to explore the rocks. It covers fairly easy terrain, but suitable footwear should be used.

The best map of the area is the Ordnance Survey's new 1:25,000 Explorer No 26, Nidderdale, but the larger scale map in the National Trust's leaflet, An introduction to Brimham Rocks and Moor, will show you where to find the featured formations. A convenient pub is The Half Moon at Fell Beck (tel: 01423 711560) but for first-class real Yorkshire ham, egg and chips in various combinations, try the Dry Gill Café in the Main Street at Summerbridge.

The nearest Tourist Information Centre (summer season only) is in the High Street at Pateley Bridge (tel: 01423 711147). Off-season, ring the TIC in the Royal Baths Assembly Rooms at Harrogate (tel: 01423 537300).
