webTitle: Los Angeles Black community hails its departing hero

fields.headline: Clinton stretches out to help Gore
fields.trailText: Los Angeles Black community hails its departing hero
fields.body:
The sun was setting over the black middle-class Crenshaw district in Los Angeles as he arrived to loud cheers from a crowd estimated by police at 8,000. They had been waiting patiently for around two hours to catch a glimpse of their hero and they chanted "four more years!" as he took the stage against a back-drop of palm trees and the hint of a pale November moon.

Here was the man they wanted to see elected to the presidency next Tuesday and he bathed in the warmth of their affection like the pro he is. The only problem was that this was not Al Gore receiving the blessing of black LA, but Bill Clinton bidding his long goodbye to the most loyal of his supporters.

The mood was upbeat in the Baldwin Hills plaza as the afternoon began. This was clearly not George W Bush territory: people sported badges proclaiming "I didn't vote for his daddy either" and joined in chants of "no son of a Bush!"

As befitted a star, there were countless support acts. The Reverend Cecil Murray asked everyone to pray: "Lord, thank-you for the wisdom to make wise choices."

Wyclef Jean, who first came to fame with the Fugees, had composed a special song:"If you want to know who I'm going to vote for, I'm going to vote for Al Gore", which somehow seemed unlikely to make it on to his next CD.

The Crenshaw high school marching band and the Montgomery high school steel band from San Diego strutted their stuff.

Mr Clinton finally arrived in a blue sports coat and red tie, punching the air and giving his best commander-in-chief salute to the seated elders - "the chronologically-gifted", as they had been described earlier, this being California.

He managed to pick up on both the religious theme and the feeling that he was the headlining act at the end of a very long tour.

"I know I'm sort of preaching to the saved," he said. "But thank you, California, Los Angeles and Watts for the support you have given to me and Al Gore."

Like a road-weary rock star, he had slightly misplaced his location because Watts is a few miles down the road but no one was rushing to consult their street maps and he could have said "thank you, Hemel Hempstead" and they would still have forgiven him.

Mr Clinton has supposedly been hurt by the failure of the Gore campaign to involve him more. He has come to Los Angeles, San Francisco and Oakland at the request of the Democratic Governor Gray Davis, who has watched Mr Bush creep up in the polls to within seven percentage points of Mr Gore in a state that the vice-president must win to succeed next week.

The enthusiasm Mr Clinton engenders, the clear affection in which he is held, makes Mr Gore's decision to keep him at least at arm's length seem an odd one.

The president reminded them of when he and Mr Gore had come seeking their votes in 1992 and how much life had changed since then.

"The economy was in turmoil, society was divided, there were riots in Los Angeles," he said. "This election is just as important."

He told them that "the people of Watts feel they have as much say in the White House as my friends in Beverly Hills".

"We tried to give you one America," he said.

Perhaps remembering his mission, he told the crowd: "I want to say something about Al Gore: he has experience, he understands the future, how it will be shaped by the internet and the global economy."

It was not perhaps the most convincing of endorsements - a little like saying of someone that they have lovely eyes - but he made it clear that everyone had a duty to get their friends out to vote and preserve "fairness for all legal immigrants ... a woman's right to choose, and civil rights and human rights".

Since there were many who had done well in the audience, he carried on his theme of inclusion. "With Al Gore and Joe Lieberman and the Democrats, the rich folks keep getting richer and so do the middle class and working people. We're all going forward together!"

He ended on an even more enthusiastic note about the man who has been his deputy for eight years.

"Al Gore is a good man who makes good decisions and with your help he will be a great president of the United States."

His speech was brief and his farewell a poignant one: "I can't thank you enough for how good you've been to me. Thank you and God bless you all!"

The sounds of the Four Tops singing "Reach Out, I'll Be There" blasted out as cannons fired red, white and blue confetti over the retreating crowds and the security men on the rooftops packed away binoculars the size of cider flagons and gave the all clear.

But the problem for the crowds streaming home was that Mr Clinton won't be there for very much longer.

"I'm a Clinton fan," said Florence Dyer, who, like the president, had grown up in Little Rock, Arkansas. "If he was running again, I'd vote for him again. I can remember when my parents couldn't vote because they were black and that's why it's important that people vote now. But a lot of black people have been so beaten down they think their vote doesn't count. I think Al Gore's style throws people off some, but you can't ask a man to change and as for George Bush - he's like a cock rooster."

"He's a motivator," said Ruthie Cook, 68, who runs a nearby cleaning services business. "And he sure did bring more of our people into government than anyone else in the history of my life."

"I'm sad he's leaving," said a young investment banker, Tianna Quarles, who said that she had benefited through affirmative action educational policies. "He preaches inclusion, he still believes in affirmative action. He's my hero."

Ms Quarles said she would happily have voted for him for a third term if such a thing existed and was uncertain as to whether Al Gore would win her over next Tuesday.

But as her words trailed off in thought, the president was off in his motorcade to visit his friends in Beverly Hills. Then it was on to the Bay Area where yesterday he was once again trying to preach to the saved and save his vice-president.

fields.headline: A dot in the ocean
fields.standfirst: Fishing nets outnumber fridges, but a group of remote Pacific islands are making millions from the internet. Margaret Hebblethwaite hears the roar of the surf on an unspoilt palm-lined beach
fields.trailText: Fishing nets outnumber fridges, but a group of remote Pacific islands are making millions from the internet. Margaret Hebblethwaite hears the roar of the surf on an unspoilt palm-lined beach.
fields.body:
The global superhighway is so congested that many companies are unable to register their name with the dot.com suffix. Many television companies are finding it easier to use the .tv domain.

This may seem a million miles from the west Pacific, except that the .tv name is the property of a tiny group of Micronesian islands, Tuvalu.

Last year, the 10,000 islanders made £10.5 million from licensing their domain and look set to earn a great deal more. They have few other sources of income - the sale of fishing licenses in their extensive territorial waters raises £4 million a year, but there is no industry, negligible agriculture and tourism is virtually nonexistent.

The windfall will come in handy as the advent of global warming has brought the fear that the islands, which seldom rise more than 4m above sea level, may not be able to survive the coastal erosion. The population lives with the possibility that they may have to move within 50 years if they are not to be washed away. The scientific evidence is at present ambiguous, but the government is already moving to buy a plot of land in Fiji a quarter the land size of Tuvalu, as a precaution in case of evacuation.

In September, Tuvalu became the 189th member of the United Nations, and the government hopes this will give it a stronger platform from which to bring its concerns about global warming to the attention of the international community.

Wherever you are on Tuvalu's main island of Funafuti, you can hear the roar of the ocean. Pacific it may be in name, but pacific it is not in nature. On the eastern side of the narrow strip of island, the waves thunder in over the stony beach, while on the western side there is a calm lagoon suitable for swimming. The space between is, in places, barely more than the width of a motorway. Nowhere does it take more than five minutes to walk from coast to coast.

A bumpy track runs from one end of the island to the other, a primitive thoroughfare lined by palm trees and pandanus with their decoratively-complex roots. On the lagoon side, there is a verge of just a few feet before the dip down to the beach; on the ocean side, one, or sometimes two, simple houses can fit in before the Pacific coast is reached. There are pigs, mostly confined to pens, and chickens running around, but no cattle or sheep. The soil is not rich enough to grow much beyond coconuts and bananas, but the sea produces plentiful amounts of fish. Fishermen weigh huge tuna on scales in the street; small boys carry them cradled proudly in their arms.

The reason for Funafuti's long, thin shape is that it is part of the rim of an old submerged crater, with the circumference completed by a dotted line of uninhabited islets. Several hours by boat beyond these islets are the eight other islands of Tuvalu (which means "eight standing"). Only Funafuti has an airstrip, just as only Funafuti has a public electricity network. This summer, the boat that travels between the islands has been in New Zealand for repairs, and one of the country's half-dozen doctors has been stranded on an outer islands for months awaiting its return.

Tuvalu is a haven of beauty and simplicity. You can have the beach to yourself for as far as you can see in both directions; The sun shines brightly and hotly - the country lies only 8 degrees south of the equator - and yet the sea breeze brings constant relief. Most water is good to drink because it is rainwater coming straight off the roof. Malaria is non-existent and there is comparatively little nuisance from insects other than mosquitoes. And as a former British colony (the Ellice Islands), everyone speaks English as well as Tuvaluan.

It is not a rich island - even on Funafuti more people have fishing nets than have fridges (46% to 43%). But the culture is rich and unspoiled by tourism. Asked if they ever have tourists, the receptionist in Tuvalu's one hotel shook her head in a puzzled way, as though it were a strange idea. Rather the hotel caters for a slow trickle of technicians and government advisers.

Yet once or twice a year tourists do arrive, in a load of a hundred or so from a cruise ship. They sleep on the ship, but by day they are all over the island, offending the locals by walking down the road "half naked" - that is, in bikinis. Then, after a couple of days the ship moves on and the Tuvaluans sigh with relief.

The government takes a different attitude: it would like to promote the tourist industry for obvious financial reasons, although it believes their facilities would have to be upgraded to meet the requirements of "fussy" foreigners.

The Tuvaluans are gentle, black, beautiful if a little buxom, and wear flowers in their hair. The children wave at you as you pass and cry out "bye bye", proud of the English they learn in school, while the adults appreciate being greeted in their own language with "Talofa" ("Hello").

The Tuvaluan phrase book was brought out in 1945 and includes among its useful phrases for visitors: "This is our gift which we have brought you. It is only a trifle and not at all fitting for you, but our island has nothing of value to offer, only talo and eggs and a few fowls." "Lift up the screens and let the fresh breeze fan the patient." "He grabbed at the rooster and its tail feathers came out." "Is the post straight or is it leaning towards the sea?" And: "Don't you know that the forequarters of the turtle are taboo for they are reserved for the chiefs."

Christianity is very influential, and 96% of the people are Congregationalists, members of the Ekalesia Kelisiano Tuvalu (Tuvalu Christian Church). Bells ring out every evening calling the families to prayer, and it is common to see people walking around with bibles in their hands.

The main church on Funafuti is the largest building on the island, on Sundays filled with people sitting cross-legged on coconut matting. The women wear shimmering white dresses, and sit on the right-hand side, and the men put on their Sunday best - shirts, ties and sulus (skirts) - and sit on the left. The singing is hauntingly beautiful.

Everyone seems to be the cousin of someone else you have met, and everything is on such a small scale that you soon feel at home. There is only one newspaper, Tuvalu Echoes, and it comes out once a month, in English and Tuvaluan. The prison has just five inmates, including the former general secretary of the Church, imprisoned for fraud.

The governor-general's house faces the airstrip adorned with a little outside wall some six inches high. In the square by the air terminal are all the central facilities: the craft shop, bank, post office, telecom, police station, broadcasting house and the hotel. Few buildings have notices up, as the local people know which battered, unlocked door leads into which office. Two-storey buildings are rare and are treated as landmarks.

There is only one mini-roundabout, while the pitted road destroys a vehicle's suspension in a matter of months. As a consequence, most people travel on foot, on bicycle, or motorbike. There is only one "Stop" sign, where the road reaches the air terminal, and it is painted by hand.

The airstrip, built by the American forces during the second world war, is used for more purposes than landing the two scheduled flights per week. Given the state of the road, it provides a better base for parades and football, and even for sleeping out at night, the open space attracting the wind from the sea that brings relief from the oppressive heat.

Tuvalu is a little Garden of Eden, with its long palm-lined beaches, its unspoilt culture, its colourfully dressed, flower-adorned, friendly people, and its relaxed pace of life, which makes one feel like never moving on. A US state department report last year described it as: "egalitarian, democratic and respectful of human rights".

One is tempted to ask: what is the catch? Well, there are plenty of problems that sap energy and demand patience. There is insufficient capacity in the electricity network, so there are power cuts for approximately one third of the time. Another problem is that the salty sea-wind, for all its welcome breeze, spells death to machinery, for rust is endemic. Drought can also strike between April and November, when those with larger roofs to collect rainwater have to supply the smaller homes with buckets of water.

But despite the frustrations, those who have once heard the sound of Tuvaluan children, united in song, piercing the night darkness with their vigorous harmonies, will fall in love with the islands' simplicity and beauty. They will understand the people's sense of foreboding over sea-level rise, threatening to make Tuvalu a third-world victim of first-world greed. No wonder UN secretary-general Kofi Annan described climate change on Tuvalu as "trouble in paradise".

The practicals

Key Travel (0161-819 8900, www.keytravel.co.uk) sells BA World Discovery tickets London-Suva, Fiji for £1.380 in December, £985 January-March, and Air Fiji Suva-Funafuti, Tuvalu for £215 return, although schedules for the latter service is erratic.

Vaiaku Lagi hotel, (tel: +688 20500, fax 688 20503) is government-owned and modern but lacks character, £35 a double room, (all prices plus 10% tax and plus breakfast). Su's Place (tel/fax +688 20612) is cosy with lots of character, £10-£18, some air-conditioned, lower prices negotiable on longer stays.

Filamona Lodge (tel: +688 20983) is pleasant and airy, £13-£17, some air-conditioned. Hide-Away Guest House (tel: +688 20365, fax: +688 20835) is in the north of the island, where the beach is better, but transport needs arranging into the centre, £11-£21 a room. Motorbikes can be hired for £3.75 a day. Tuvalu has a website: members.xoom.com/tuvaluonline).

fields.headline: Coast-to-Coasting: Eight walks crossing Britain
fields.standfirst:
By John Gillham and Ronald Turnbull
Published by David & Charles, £19.99
fields.trailText: Coast-to-Coasting/Eight walks Crossing Britain by John Gillham and Ronald Turnbull, published by David & Charles £19.99
fields.body:
Buy it at BOL

This is a lusciously illustrated and well researched list of fantastic routes that all start at the sea and end at the sea.

Walks range from the classic Wainwright's Coast to Coast (across from St Bees in Cumbria to Robin Hood's Bay) to one from the Bristol Channel to the Irish Sea and another from the Scottish side of the Solway up and across to Edinburgh.

The photographs, of course, are all taken with everything looking beautiful. But it is also very practical with, apart from the lyrical bits which go on a bit, lists of essential information, maps and guides, and tourist info numbers. The maps are fine as a general guide but you would need OS maps to make it work. And anyway, you would not take this book with you - it's too heavy and glossy. Leave it on the coffee table.

fields.trailText: If you haven't got a clue what's being said to you, smile. This indicates that, ignorant though you may seem, you're a warm and generous human being, who, in different circumstances, it would be a pleasure to know.
fields.body:

webTitle: Where to camp in the French Alps

fields.headline: Where to camp in the French Alps
fields.standfirst:
We want to go skiing in the French Alps this winter and plan to stay in our motorhome. Does anyone know of campsites that are open all year, with good access to the slopes? Advice on taking a motorhome to the Alps in winter would also be welcome.
Ulla Stede
fields.trailText: We want to go skiing in the French Alps this winter and plan to stay in our motorhome. Does anyone know of campsites that are open all year, with good access to the slopes? Advice on taking a motorhome to the Alps in winter would also be welcome.
fields.body:
Many resorts have campsites open in winter (Caravaneige). Try Morzine (Les Portes Soleils) with two sites, one at the end of Morzine, the other in the next viilage down the valley. You can also camp for free in the car park (near the Gendarmerie and supermarket) in the centre of Morzine.

Make sure your vehicle has maximum antifreeze and is well insulated. Take an extra electric heater for campsite use. Two years ago, just before Xmas, the temperature dropped to -28C and stayed below -8C for over a week. Make sure tyres are in good nick, and take snow chains (you may not be allowed on some roads without them).
Patricia and Guy Featherstone

fields.headline: Don't even go there
fields.standfirst: Big commercial sites rarely satisfy the sceptical and sensitive traveller. Here are a few alternative perspectives
fields.trailText: Big commercial sites rarely satisfy the sceptical and sensitive traveller. Ros Taylor offers a few alternative perspectives.
fields.body:
www.holidaycomplaints.com
Rather like Watchdog, holiday complaints.com accentuates the negative and eliminates the positive, making it a rather depressing read. However, it's encouraging to learn that the hapless tour companies involved are taking an interest in the site and even (in the case of Thomas Cook) posting a response.

Note that only the major package operators are covered: this is not the place to come if you simply want to complain about a Spanish beach or a crime-ridden town.

VirginNet Resort Finder
Virgin's brochure-style front page gives no hint of the uncompromising write-ups beneath it, which were originally written for travel agents.

We learn that Sharm el-Sheikh in Egypt "has lots of genuine Arab bazaars and local shops... which may all be too 'ethnic' for some delicate Western tastes". (Smelly butchers, one assumes.) More usefully, the hilltop to the east "is an absolute mayhem of building sites".

Greek Island Postcards
Probably best avoided if you have already booked a fortnight on Skiathos, Greek Island Postcards is unmerciful in its judgments on the major islands. The round-up of other views (from Cadogan, Which? and the Rough Guides) and the author's penetrating verdict on each beach make interesting reading: "The sands were strewn with plastic bags and bottles while an obnoxious film of turd-yellow scum anchored itself along the shoreline..."

If you want to take a bike on holiday, this forum, set up by contributors to a cycling newsgroup, reviews their experience on various airlines, train networks and explores the various shipping opportunities.

Fodors.com miniguides
Fodor's own guides can be a little pompous and predictable, but their city coverage is much more wide-ranging than Time Out's and their bulletin boards are extremely helpful. Particularly useful if your accommodation and food budget is generous.

Gapyear.comWith the rare phenonomenon of lively bulletin boards and very useful features (including visa information and advice on insurance), this is probably the best source of help for students planning a gap year.

Foreign Office travel advice
Perils lurk everywhere for the British tourist - from volcanoes to bandits - and this site is the best place to anticipate them.

Uganda's ebola epidemic may not affect your holiday plans, but WHO's site reports plenty of other outbreaks of disease this year - including cholera in South Africa and Micronesia, West Nile fever in Israel and yellow fever in Brazil, as well as food poisoning in France. Worth a look if you are travelling off the beaten track.

fields.headline: Bravo Two Zero, written and read by Andy McNab
fields.standfirst:
HarperCollins, 150mn, £8.99
Buy it at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: For lovers of an exciting, horrifying yarn, this story of botch-up, capture and torture flows best from the man himself Hear an audio clip
fields.body: The bickering over this SAS mission into enemy territory during the Gulf war continues as rival accounts still trickle out. McNab's advantage was getting his bestseller out first. Military geeks may prefer the written text, conventionally studded with army acronyms and slang. For lovers of an exciting, horrifying yarn, this story of botch-up, capture and torture flows better from the man himself. McNab has the rare gift of naturalism that many broadcasters would kill for. It's as if he's telling you his story quietly in the corner of the pub. The voice - soft-spoken, Londonish - makes it more human and engaging, as does the inspired insertion of descriptions, spoken by McNab's wife, of her agonised waiting back home. After weeks of no news, an officer knocked on her door and bluntly told her her old man was probably not coming back.

fields.headline: Eleven Didsbury Place, Manchester
fields.trailText: Rooms are modern without being minimalist. All different in shape and size but sharing the same warm colours.
fields.body:
Address: Didsbury Village, Manchester M20 5LH.

Tel: 0161-448 7711

Web address: www.eleven.didsburypark.com

First impressions: Exquisitely-designed interior. Tasteful beiges, blues, greens and fawns decorate the lobby/bar/lounge area, which has an attractive sandstone fireplace as its centrepiece.

What are the rooms like? Modern without being minimalist. All different in shape and size but sharing the same warm colours.

The bed test: Big and firm with ample covers and pillows, so soft your head just melts right into them.

The bathroom test: Spotless, white-tiled en suites with bath and luxurious showers.

The restaurant: No restaurant unfortunately, but the accommodating owners will drive you to and from nearby Didsbury if you fancy eating out. For quick bites there is a deli menu available from 7pm with dishes priced £4-9. Breakfast is extra, but the full Irish version is worth every penny.

What is there to see within walking distance? The bars, restaurants and shops of Manchester's highly fashionable Didsbury Village, a botanical gardens and some neighbouring parks.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? Rusholme and the Curry Mile, Manchester United's Old Trafford ground, and the city centre, which has just about everything - the Manchester museum, the Science Museum, the contrasting Contact and Royal Exchange theatres, the Bridgewater Hall, the bars of Canal Street and Castlefield - the list is endless. Ten minutes in the other direction is the airport.

How much a night? Monday - Thursday, doubles are £99.50, Friday - Sunday £69.50. Add £10 for a Queen- and £20 for a King-size bed. No single rooms available.

Would you go back? Definitely, if I needed somewhere to stay in Manchester.

webTitle: Snowboarding at Europe's largest indoor slope - in Milton Keynes

fields.headline: Milton Keynes Snozone: a bridge to the real thing
fields.trailText: You're going snowboarding, my friends said. Where? Then I told them and they didn't look so jealous. "Milton Keynes."
fields.body:
You're going snowboarding, my friends said. Where? Then I told them and they didn't look so jealous. "Milton Keynes."

OK, it's not as exciting as saying you're off to Chamonix, Whistler or Mammoth but - now that Europe's largest indoor real snow slope has opened there - Milton Keynes could well become a breeding ground for tomorrow's skiers and snowboarders.

About one hour after getting on the train from London, I was there at the top of Snozone's two 170m slopes (there's also a 135m training slope), boots strapped to the board, jacket zipped up tight, breath visible in the -2 C air, trying to remember how the hell to do it.

There's 1,500 tonnes of the white stuff on these slopes and it felt good, just like real snow in fact, which was fortunate because I took a spectacular tumble - or faceshot, to use the correct boarding term - halfway down and was glad of a soft landing. At the foot of the run, the two 170m slopes are served by button tows, always a tough one for boarders, but good practice nevertheless.

No one's ever going to say an indoor ski-slope is as good as the real thing. I mean, no Frenchman ever gets up out of bed in Chamonix on a clear, crisp winter morning and says: "Let's fly to Britain and try an indoor slope." But that's hardly the point. Snozone is a tool, a bridge to the real thing. And there was nothing artificial about the ache in my muscles after an hour of shaky turns, so it's also a pretty good work-out.

I thought it was good value, and the slopes were fairly quiet - although with snowboarding now Britain's fastest growing sport, it's unlikely to stay that way for very long.

 Healthland Snozone is at the Xscape Centre, 602 Marlborough Gate, central Milton Keynes MK9 3XS (info and bookings: 01908 230260, www.snozone.co.uk). By car, it is five minutes from the M1, junction 14. By rail, it is on the London to Glasgow line, 40 minutes from London Euston, 70 minutes from Birmingham New Street. From the station, Snozone is then only five minutes by taxi, 10 by bus.

The slope is open daily from 9am-11pm. Off-peak period is Monday-Friday, 9am-6pm. Off-peak prices: adults (16+) £15/hour, junior £10, family (two adults, two children) £45. Peak period is Monday-Friday, 6pm-11pm, 9am-11pm at weekends and bank holidays. Peak prices: adult £20, junior £14, family £55. Prices include skis, boards, boots, poles and head protection. Group lessons are available: learn to snowboard in a weekend (Sat-Sun, 9am-5pm) for £200, juniors £160.

The Tamworth Snowdome, Britain's other indoor slope, is at Tamworth, near Birmingham. Details on 01827 67905, website currently being updated.

webTitle: Few tears for trendy who turned tough

fields.headline: Few tears for trendy who turned tough
fields.standfirst:
After Chris Woodhead's sudden departure, the Guardian asks former teaching colleagues and educationalists where Ofsted goes from here
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: At the west country school where he taught during the 1970s Chris Woodhead is remembered as a pleasant member of the staff room who had what in those days appeared an almost trendy approach to his work.
fields.body:
At the west country school where he taught during the 1970s Chris Woodhead is remembered as a pleasant member of the staff room who had what in those days appeared an almost trendy approach to his work.

How times have changed. There were no tears at Gordano yesterday for the abrupt departure of a former colleague whose conservative, confrontational rule at Ofsted alienated teachers across the country.

"Thank goodness it is over," said Mike Stanley, head of psychology, one of the few members of the current 93 teaching staff to have worked alongside the school's one-time head of English.

"It feels like a weight has been removed. We are not going to have to put up with that sniping any more. I don't think there are going to be many teachers in this country who are disappointed that he has gone."

Like others at the 1,400 pupil school, Mr Stanley, who has been teaching at Gordano for 30 years, acknowledged that Ofsted has a job to do.

But he hoped for a change of culture in the wake of Mr Woodhead's departure, with a successor who would be seen to be more supportive of what teachers were doing.

The school, at Portishead, near Bristol, went through two inspections during the 1990s, most recently in December 1997 when inspectors found that the overall quality of teaching was good, and in two thirds of lessons was good, very good or excellent.

Significant progress was noted in a number of matters raised during the first inspection almost four years earlier.

Despite the plaudits, Bob Sommers, Gordano's head for the past nine years, is critical of the way Ofsted inspections have been carried out. He is looking for change.

"The atmosphere in schools when Ofsted inspectors are inspecting is stressful and sometimes fearful. It does not have to be like this," he said.

"Schools want to be good schools and they want to be accountable. But inspections should be shorter and less bureaucratic and they should involve dialogue."

He said that although Mr Woodhead was clearly committed to education and had retained an interest in the school where he once taught, the good work Ofsted had achieved under his leadership had been obscured by public statements that had alienated the very people who were the key to school improvement.

Paul Crossthwaite, Gordano's head of science, who has been a teacher for 28 years, believed the Woodhead years represented a missed opportunity. "What he was doing was applying an outdated, discredited method of management and I am surprised he managed to stay as long as he did. He thought he could improve the education system by criticism and hard nosed, robust judgment and I think he failed entirely.

"What he succeeded in doing was to undermine the confidence of teachers in general and alienate himself from the profession as a whole."

Looking back to Mr Woodhead's time at Gordano, Mr Stanley said he found it hard to reconcile the teacher he recalled from the 1970s with the man who had damaged confidence in the profession by talking publicly of 15,000 bad teachers in Britain's schools.

"From my recollection his approach here was quite trendy and go ahead. He had a lot of ideas that would not have been considered traditional methods at that time and it surprises me that someone who was quite radical in his approach turned out with such a conservative attitude when judging other teachers later in his career.

"Ofsted has a job to do and that is fair enough. But when it is coupled with the things that have been said about teachers and the constant sniping at the profession it does not give people confidence to face an inspection.

"I just hope his successor will be seen to be much more supportive of what teachers are doing and realise that we are trying our best to get the best out of our kids."
'We need a modest chief inspector who quietly does job'

Phil Taylor, headteacher of Stamford high school, Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester

"Schools have to become more involved in evaluating themselves and each other. We need to ensure that people inspecting schools are practitioners themselves.

"Most Ofsted inspectors have either long since left the classroom or have limited experience of the schools they are inspecting. The selection process has to change. In many ways we would be better returning to the days before Ofsted where inspectors were properly trained and selected. Instead of farming out inspection to private contractors, teachers in the field should be seconded to work with Ofsted.

"We need a modest chief inspector who quietly gets on with the job and does not make unhelpful public pronouncements about education matters outside their area. Much of Woodhead's comments, for example about A-levels, were unsettling and demoralising.

Alan Smithers, professor, Liverpool University

"Ofsted needs to develop what it has already achieved without the head using it as a platform for making general statements about education.

"The area where it will need to develop its methodology most is for 16s to 19s. We need a good, solid figure who will command respect and ensure that all the achievements are sustained - but do not have the same public prominence - a bit like the Bank of England that you can rely on but you don't hear about every day.

"Woodhead was helpful because the education system needed to be shocked out of its complacency and some hard questions needed to be asked and who better to do that than the chief inspector? But we probably need a change of style - somebody who is a much more conciliatory figure - operating more behind the scenes than in front of the stage."

Kate Amis, parent and former teacher, south London

"I would like to see Ofsted getting more involved in picking up the pieces afterwards. The schools are left floundering.

"All the teachers I know dread of Ofsted coming - it just seems to blight every day. They seem to spend so much energy preparing - energy they should be spending on teaching.

"Inspectors use very negative terms - it never says "this has been absolutely brilliant" it just says "satisfactory". That makes it very inaccessible to parents."

Ted Wragg, professor, Exeter University

"I wouldn't mind if the new chief inspector is a character - I think that too many public servants are boring - as long as what they say is based on the evidence. You either close it down or have a new body with a fresh start, or there is going to need to be a two year period of very hard work so we can say we believe in it again.

"I'd scrap this ridiculous language. One teacher said to me 'one inspector said I was on the sound side of satisfactory, one inspector said I was on the satisfactory side of sound'. I'd bury forever the inspector speech dictionary.

"I'd go for a combined local and national inspection. When it was done entirely by national inspectors they often didn't have local knowledge and when it was only a local inspection some strong minded individual would want to impose a single style of running schools."

Doug McAvoy, general secretary, National Union of Teachers

"We've got to get the balance right between inspection and internal evaluation. Lots of countries - Canada, Australia, some in Europe - have a system where an inspector inspects how schools evaluate themselves. They make sure that the school has an adept quality assurance system. There is some sympathy with the self-assessment arrangement within the department for education although I suspect the prime minister wouldn't want to loosen up the inspection framework.

"Currently the inspection system is just about criticism, not about what you do next. That is why the Ofsted inspection is considered to be punitive rather than supportive."

webTitle: Woodhead pledges all-out attack on education policy

fields.headline: Woodhead pledges all-out attack on education policy
fields.trailText: David Blunkett, the education secretary, is attempting to limit the political threat from the resignation of the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, by asking his deputy to step up until the general election and beyond.
fields.body:
David Blunkett, the education secretary, is attempting to limit the political threat from the resignation of the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, by asking his deputy to step up until the general election and beyond.

Mike Tomlinson, 58, the deputy head of Ofsted, has already agreed to take over the running of the inspection service for three months when Mr Woodhead effectively departs at the end of the month.

One source familiar with negotiations, which continued yesterday, said Mr Tomlinson had been asked to take charge for a year, with a view to extending for a further two years beyond that.

Mr Woodhead gave notice yesterday that he would become a persistent thorn in Mr Blunkett's side when he stands down to join the Daily Telegraph and Bell Pottinger Public Affairs in the spring.

But he would find it much more difficult to attack the new regime at Ofsted if his old deputy and friend was at the helm.

Mr Woodhead told BBC Radio 4's Today programme yesterday: "The position I have held has meant on more than one occasion that I have had to frame my words very carefully.

"Look in three months' time when I have worked out my notice. Look what I intend to say. I want to speak out because I have become increasingly frustrated with some aspects of policy and I have found it increasingly hard to defend them."

He added: "I am not a Tory, no. I simply believe in children getting a decent education. Surely all of us want our children to be taught in ordered classrooms."

Mr Blunkett moved to reassure parents who regarded the chief inspector as a bulwark against teachers by pledging that the drive to raise standards would go on.

Mr Woodhead insisted yesterday that it had been his decision to quit, rejecting a Guardian report that Mr Blunkett had hurried him into going after learning of his negotiations with the Telegraph. "My understanding anyway is that David Blunkett and the prime minister wanted me to stay on and that they are disappointed that I am leaving," he told Today. Mr Blunkett had told him he was sorry he was going, Mr Woodhead said, but added: "You'd have to ask him whether he meant it or not."
fields.bodyText: David Blunkett, the education secretary, is attempting to limit the political threat from the resignation of the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, by asking his deputy to step up until the general election and beyond. Mike Tomlinson, 58, the deputy head of Ofsted, has already agreed to take over the running of the inspection service for three months when Mr Woodhead effectively departs at the end of the month. One source familiar with negotiations, which continued yesterday, said Mr Tomlinson had been asked to take charge for a year, with a view to extending for a further two years beyond that. Mr Woodhead gave notice yesterday that he would become a persistent thorn in Mr Blunkett's side when he stands down to join the Daily Telegraph and Bell Pottinger Public Affairs in the spring. But he would find it much more difficult to attack the new regime at Ofsted if his old deputy and friend was at the helm. Mr Woodhead told BBC Radio 4's Today programme yesterday: "The position I have held has meant on more than one occasion that I have had to frame my words very carefully. "Look in three months' time when I have worked out my notice. Look what I intend to say. I want to speak out because I have become increasingly frustrated with some aspects of policy and I have found it increasingly hard to defend them." He added: "I am not a Tory, no. I simply believe in children getting a decent education. Surely all of us want our children to be taught in ordered classrooms." Mr Blunkett moved to reassure parents who regarded the chief inspector as a bulwark against teachers by pledging that the drive to raise standards would go on. Mr Woodhead insisted yesterday that it had been his decision to quit, rejecting a Guardian report that Mr Blunkett had hurried him into going after learning of his negotiations with the Telegraph. "My understanding anyway is that David Blunkett and the prime minister wanted me to stay on and that they are disappointed that I am leaving," he told Today. Mr Blunkett had told him he was sorry he was going, Mr Woodhead said, but added: "You'd have to ask him whether he meant it or not."

fields.headline: Good riddance
fields.standfirst: So Chris Woodhead is going to the Telegraph. It's the best place for him Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: So Chris Woodhead is going to the Telegraph. It's the best place for him
fields.body:
The Daily Telegraph considers Chris Woodhead quite a catch. He will probably even be paid for a job he'd have done for nothing. What else can he realistically do? He could write for the Mail but is too much of a snob. The Daily Telegraph is for those who can quote Latin phrases. The Mail is for those who don't know much about Latin but think: "At least the Romans made the chariots run on time." Both papers are for those who mourn the fact that political correctness has outlawed the harmless tradition of owning slaves.

I suppose there will be plenty of gravy-train consultancies for Mr Woodhead. Disgraced people usually saunter from one trough to another. He could probably be a European commissioner or win a rail franchise; it is unlikely that he will ever do anything useful. He had the chance to do that when he was a teacher but failed and gave up. The Telegraph, announcing their new signing (who next - Sir Jimmy Savile? Edwina Currie?), says that Tony Blair showed courage in retaining the services of Mr Woodhead in 1997. Er, no. He showed that he is incapable of joy or glee, like a person who wins the lottery but decides to stay on as a store detective. Anyone with fire in their belly and a sense of fun would have summoned Mr Woodhead and told him: "Chris my boy, I've got big plans for you. I'm setting up a new abattoir watchdog called Offal. You'll get some wellies, a funny hat, £10 a year and your job is to drink the cerebrospinal fluid of cows to make sure it's safe."

Perhaps cowardice made Blair keep Woodhead on, but it is hard to see what he was scared of, other than a national mood for change. Perhaps he sought to dampen hope as he did when he invited Lady Thatcher to tea. But it seems likely that the main reason for not sticking Woodhead's head on a ruler and parading it through the streets (treason is still a capital offence covering almost anything, and anyway, who would object?) was that there is no gap between New Labour and the Tories on the matter of education.

Neither believes that absolutely no one should ever be afforded opportunities that are not the birthright of their class. But both have such a narrow and pessimistic view of human potential that they believe rigorous selection will identify the few who might prove useful to the economic system.

So children are tested as young as possible to save time later on. And entry into secondary school increasingly depends on the ability to do puzzles. Puzzles are fine if one is hospitalised, a eugenicist or has Asperger's syndrome. They are the entry requirement for Mensa, that bizarre club for extremely rightwing people who will never be asked to babysit. And I suppose if one wants an ordered society, puzzles are another way of labelling people.

Anyhow, when Thatcher moved out of No 10, Blair kept so much of her junk that one could imagine he offered her five quid for the ironing board. So we are left with the grotesque spectacle of John Prescott and Gerald Corbett joshing with each other about rail safety when most of us would like to see the Railtrack board in prison for manslaughter. We see arms contracts fulfilled and renewed. And we see testing continue to replace education.

Had Woodhead gone in 1997, he would have long ceased to be a serious nuisance. He might have become one of those people who shamble along the street shouting the c-word but are generally considered harmless. He might have joined Talk Radio, yelling: "If you like schools so much, why don't you try living there?" at insomniac callers. He might have been selected as a Conservative candidate. Or he might have gone to the Telegraph early and by now been just another foot soldier among its vast phalanx of "Am I the only person who mourns the passing of obscure points of grammar and proper respect for St George's day?" columnists.

He might perhaps deny parliamentary ambitions. I distinctly heard him on the wireless saying: "I am not a Tory." I think the rest of us should be the judge of that. He might not be a paid up member but he will have a hard time convincing St Peter he is anything else. I suppose he might be a Melanie Phillips Liberal or a Jack Straw Labourite, in which case, "Tory" will do fine, whether as a definition or an insult.

Perhaps he means: "I'm not a Tory" in the way that a person says, "I'm not a racist," when all their views and actions point to the contrary. If so, he will be very happy at the Telegraph. When Woodhead says that most teachers do a good job, it is obvious that he means something else. When one reads in the Telegraph the sentence: "The majority of black people are law-abiding," it translates as "Crime's in their blood, so it's a mystery why more of them aren't arrested."

fields.headline: The last word on   Weather
fields.standfirst: We shall never be content until each man makes his own weather and keeps it to himself -    Jerome K Jerome
fields.trailText: We shall never be content until each man makes his own weather and keeps it to himself - Jerome K Jerome
fields.body:
Floods, gales and blizzards alarm as well as harm us now because they seem to be incontrovertible proof of global warming. Even a small rise in the prevailing temperature of the world's atmosphere changes the geography and severity of weather events, increasing the risk of floods in such low-lying areas as the Ganges and Mekong deltas and some European coasts, while threatening to shift the flow of ocean currents which govern continental climates, triggering droughts elsewhere.

Residents of countries with stable weather patterns, manifesting the same quanta of temperature in summer and winter, and with identifiable sap-ascending springtimes and leaf-descending autumns regular enough to set a watch by, once had little call to discuss the subject. It was only in places with unreliably changeable weather, like Britain, that the art of earnest and endless debate about it was fully developed. Now everywhere people squint at the sky and comment on the unusual quantity or dearth of rain, or the increased ferocity of winds and the rising height of tides.

Small changes have big effects. Britain was once part of the European land mass, and the Thames was a tributary of the Rhine, whose mouth was the English Channel. Climate-induced changes in sea levels inundated the shallow plains once continuous between the fenlands of East Anglia and the Low Countries. For some time after the initial flooding there was a large island between Britain and continental Europe, where the Dogger Bank now lies under the North Sea's cold waters. That too sank, and historians say that the peoples of Britain, once they had been separated from their mainland brethren, lapsed two thousand years behind them in agricultural, technological and military development. There is a stern modern moral in that fact.

Global trends in weather seem remote until unusual storms demolish our woodlands and drown our village streets. But daily weather is intimately present, affecting moods and hopes, like a member of the family. "A cloudy day, or a little sunshine," remarked Addison, "have as great an influence on many constitutions as the most real blessings or misfortunes." Drawing back the curtains gives a first frame to the day for people who answer Addison's description; from what they see outside they deduce their feelings. Most think that a sparkling sun in a cerulean sky is a prompt for happiness, whereas weeks of cloud make one feel trapped as if inside a Tupperware box. But Gissing's observation, in his essay on winter, can correct this view: "For the man sound in body and serene of mind there is no such thing as bad weather; every sky has its beauty, and storms which whip the blood do but make it pulse more vigorously."

The Irish call a day of cloud and drizzle a "soft" day; the description supports this thought that every weather is lovely in its way. Gissing's mention of storms reminds one that our recent misadventures are not, in fact, unusual for these islands, even though their increasing frequency suggests a sinister trend. Shakespeare gives us tremendous storms in Lear and Macbeth, and although the tempest in the Tempest is Prospero's own, and occurs in foreign parts, the idea for it was home-grown. There are storms likewise in the novels of Hardy and Dorothy L Sayers, the latter describing an actual one in the 1930s which flattened woods and decapitated houses across southern England.

These events - like the Victorian earthquake that shook Suffolk - seem improbable in the usually moderate fluctuations between degrees of coolness and wetness affecting these islands, occasionally teased by glimpses of sun; until we remember the droughts of the last quarter-century, and reflect on the tornado that startled Bognor's burghers last weekend.

The well-worn saying "Every cloud has a silver lining" is especially apt in this connection for, as EB White wrote, "Extreme cold" [from which generalise "extreme weather"] "when it first arrives seems to generate cheerfulness and sociability. For a few hours all life's dubious problems are dropped in favour of the clear and congenial task of keeping alive."

webTitle: Climate change may be down to farming

fields.headline: Climate change may be down to farming
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Until Thursday, when her house in Shrewsbury was flooded for the first time in 60 years, Denise Jones had barely considered global warming as a scientific theory, let alone a reality.
fields.body:
Until Thursday, when her house in Shrewsbury was flooded for the first time in 60 years, Denise Jones had barely considered global warming as a scientific theory, let alone a reality.

"I know my kids and Friends of the Earth go on about it but I thought it just meant nice warm summers and I was quite in favour. I didn't know it meant floods and storms and what we have got now," she said, craning to hear Tony Blair who was visiting the drowning Shropshire town.

Mrs Jones's new understanding of climate change follows a series of ever stronger statements in the past 10 days from government and opposition, the environment agency and green groups, all of whom have been quick to give the public a geography lesson and link extreme weather in Britain with lifestyle and global change.

The need to prepare people for climate change may be as much fuelled by political expediency - the weather is seen by some as fortuitously deflecting some attention from the fuel and transport crises - as by alarming new UN and EU reports in the last 10 days.

The most worrying leaked out from the UN-sponsored intergovernmental panel on climate change, a grouping of 200 of the world's leading climatologists.

In their first big report in five years they linked the warming climate of the last 20 years with man made carbon emissions, and predicted rapidly accelerating global warming with increasingly severe weather.

A European commission report warned of a more extreme, stormier world. It specifically said Britain would have mild winters with rain in very heavy bursts, but with hot summers and droughts, too.

The reports confirmed government studies which say that flooding is now twice as frequent as 100 years ago and that we can expect to see a tenfold increase in flood risk over the next century. A flood that might now happen on average once in 100 years could occur as frequently as every 10 or 20 years in future.

"There have been floods somewhere every month in Britain for the last 32 months. Up to 5m people live in flood risk areas in England where there are 1.8m properties valued at over £200bn," said Geoff Spence, the agency's director of water management.

He added: "The lesson to be drawn from the past month, which has seen six times average rainfall in parts, and more than one inch falling in an hour, is that we must educate ourselves, prepare and adapt."

New policy guidance will be published next month on developments on flood plains, giving planners authority to decide what should and should not be allowed.

The government estimates global warming could mean spending an extra £12bn on flood defences in the next 50 years, but has only committed an extra £30m. Yesterday the environment agency said: "We argued for an extra £100m. There has been under-investment in the past."

How flood money is spent is likely to be the subject of debate between ecologists and engineers in government. Traditionally, the Ministry of Agriculture has favoured big sea defences, big engineering and more field drainage. This is criticised for increasing the run off from fields and pushing water downstream where it can flood communities. The environment agency and the Department of the Environment are moving to a more sensitive, holistic approach.

Yesterday John Boardman, head of the environmental change unit at Oxford University, played down the influence of global warming, saying that the recent floods were caused largely by changes in farm practices.

Extensive cultivation of winter wheat sown in September, leaving the land bare in the wettest parts of the year, together with overstocking of sheep on the uplands which leads to erosion, is the cause of much flooding, he added.

Mr Spence said: "The run off of water from bare fields is 10-100 times greater than from a field with grass. It has led to increased property damage."

He called for the government subsidies to be targeted at specific problem areas and more schemes and grant money to help communities, and farmers. The farmers would then be able to construct small dams using special payments.

"There are many places in the southern Netherlands, Belgium and northern France, with histories of property damage by runoff, where radical approaches involving cooperation between local communities and farmers and EU funding have started to make progress in providing protection", Mr Spence said.

"Since the war the drainage system has been geared to get water off the fields faster. Because of the switch to winter cereals we have lost the big plough furrows that used to collect the water. We should be trying to keep water in the catchment areas, treating the cause of floods rather than the symptoms."

He also said he would like to see the development of "porous cities", where pavements soak in water, drains run into tanks and water is prevented from immediately running into rivers.

Ecologist Chris Baines, who has worked with Mr Meacher and farm minister Elliot Morley on the rural white paper, said: "We should consider blocking the drains in upland moors to let the peat bogs saturate again. These giant sponges regulate the run off, but they also slow the rate of climate change."

webTitle: US fears Ireland is drug traffic haven

fields.headline: US fears Ireland is drug traffic haven
fields.standfirst:
Cannabis coast Report says smuggling is channelled via remote inlets
Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Ireland is becoming a key transit centre in supplying Britain's growing number of drug users with thousands of kilograms of smuggled hashish, cannabis and cocaine, according to an intelligence agency report obtained by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Ireland is becoming a key transit centre in supplying Britain's growing number of drug users with thousands of kilograms of smuggled hashish, cannabis and cocaine, according to an intelligence agency report obtained by the Guardian.

Drug smugglers are using yachts, trawlers and cargo ships to land huge quantities of hashish and cocaine destined for Britain and Europe in remote coves and inlets on the west coast of Ireland. Ships make for Ireland's west coast from Panama, Venezuela, Morocco and Pakistan, taking advantage of the lightly policed waters of the Irish Republic in the south west of the country.

The report reveals that the Irish authorities are struggling to stop the smuggling and admits that the area chosen is "nearly impossible to patrol". The Bere peninsula in Co Cork - thought to be one of the main centres of the smuggling operation - is better known as a remote tourist spot for its prehistoric stone circles, and opportunities for pony trekking and sea angling. It has many small inlets and beaches where drugs could easily be unloaded without detection, only one small port, Castletownbere, and a scattering of villages.

Ireland's growing role in drug smuggling is revealed in an intelligence report released by the US drug enforcement administration to the Guardian under the US Freedom of Information Act. The report says: "Ireland's isolated coasts are ideal for shielding illicit offload operations. The country's internal role as a transit point will accelerate as drug trafficking organisations continue to favour using the island for continental and Britain bound cocaine and hashish shipments."

It points out that vast quantities of hashish seized in recent years "point toward Ireland's growing role as a transit point for hashish destined for the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe. Hashish shipments are imported into Ireland by recreational yachts or fishing trawlers, often directly from Morocco.

"Once in Ireland, the hashish can be moved more easily to other European destinations, considering Ireland's inclusion in the European Union. According to the US defence attache's office in Dublin, cannabis transited through Ireland also may be destined for North America." The report says that ships target Ireland because of the limited role taken by customs, the Irish navy and the Garda to tackle the problem.

"The ministry of justice is proposing legislation that would give naval authorities limited drug enforcement powers. At present, the Irish navy may detain suspect vessels for safety reasons or for fishery protection, but they are not allowed to make arrests."

The Irish were alerted to the problem in 1995 when the Garda seized over 15,000 kilograms of hashish from a container in Urlingford, Co Kilkenny. The street value of the hashish was thought to be about £16m, and the Garda found it had been brought ashore on the Bere peninsula. The ship involved - known as both the Tropic Moon and the Master Star - came from Pakistan. In November last year customs officials seized a con verted fishing trawler, the Posidonia, off the west Cork coast with an estimated £15m of cannabis resin on board. Three British men were arrested and charged with smuggling offences.

The cocaine trade is also growing following a series of seizures in 1996 and 1998. One shipment was only discovered after the trawler - originally from Venezuela - sought the safety of Cork harbour after a storm blew up. The crew of the ship admitted the cocaine had been airdropped to the trawler while she was sailing the Caribbean. The other shipment was discovered in a raid at Kinsale, further along the coast.

The growing drugs trade has led the Garda to set up an anti-smuggling operation, sharing intelligence with the Royal Ulster Constabulary, and Strathclyde and Dumfries to halt the movement of drugs across the Irish sea to Scotland. Ironically the three biggest successful hauls this year at Stranraer have involved Scottish drug dealers smuggling hashish and ecstasy tablets from the mainland to Belfast.

Last night the Garda described the US findings as "rubbish". A spokesman said: "We have had spectacular successes recently in seizing large hauls of drugs which have been shipped to Ireland. We do have an extremely rugged coastline with numerous inlets on the west of Ireland but we don't believe they can be used that easily by boats because of the rough Atlantic seas. We have, however, set up an operation to share strategies to tackle European drug smuggling and are cooperating with police forces in the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe."

fields.headline: Art or product?
fields.standfirst: It may be pointless to say Hollywood is dumb, argues Peter Bradshaw, but vitality and variety are under threat
fields.trailText: It may be pointless to say Hollywood is dumb, argues Peter Bradshaw, but vitality and variety are under threat
fields.body:
It was The Onion, the online satirical chronicler of America's "dumb century", which ran a deadpan editorial entitled "We need more movies where monkeys give the finger". An arguable surfeit of such movies, or a suspected cultural climate of cynicism and exhaustion in which they will be increasingly tolerated, is where the fashionable "dumbing down" debate applies to the cinema.

In many ways it is obtuse to fling accusations of "dumb" at Hollywood or individual Hollywood products. After all, isn't film a populist art? Haven't its most glorious and compelling works derived their brilliance from their creators knowing what a mass audience wants? Doesn't the energy and exuberance of their work depend to some degree on their exclusion from the simpering civilities of high art?

Brilliant films come off the Hollywood production line all the time. But the dangers of dumb reside not merely in the kind of movies made, but the way they have come to be distributed, exhibited, criticised and understood. Hollywood's colonisation of world markets and national cultures is now all but complete, and like all colonisation, depends on a degree of collaboration with and admiration - covert and overt - for the victor. (With some honourable exceptions, the British lottery-funded film has unfortunately become a byword for dumb, with many a substandard script taken out of the bottom drawer to take advantage of the cash bonanza, with the presiding authorities now apparently seeking to redeem the situation by aping the American industry.)

This is not simply a naive matter of political correctness or art-buff snobbery, of believing that Hollywood is always schlock or that there is no such thing as a bad Iranian film. Some quintessentially bad films can be middlebrow art movies saturated with their own sense of superiority.

Rather, it is a question of vitality, variety and choice. Repertory cinema, where serendipitous discoveries can be made, is disappearing in favour of multiplex conformism. Increasingly, the work of film-makers like Kiorastami, Ozu, Fellini, Bergman, Ray, Powell and Antonioni is omitted both from what we can see on the big screen and from any discussion of cinema's history.

As far as postwar Hollywood is concerned, a distinctively political case for the prosecution on the dumbing charge focuses on the terrified response to the McCarthyite bullying of the early 50s. This capacity for cowardice and self-dumbing is alleged to have resurfaced in the 70s with the Spielberg-inspired trend for "juvenilisation" of the movies. In the 80s, Hollywood president Ronald Reagan concealed his native shrewdness in favour of projecting a down-home, aw-shucks innocent who invoked Rambo in support of US interventionism, a Hollywood archetype who attained his apotheosis in the insidious Forrest Gump - whose moral superiority lay in his low IQ. And in the 90s, Paul Fussell identified "dumb" movies as the summer blockbusters subservient to their own hype: movies which take up less cultural space than their publicity. The apogee of this species of dumbness is the calamitous The Phantom Menace.

Even in this Hollywoodised context, moreover, Hollywood seems not to have a history now. A creeping amnesia is setting in. Gilbert Adair suggests that cinephilia, as it is conventionally understood, has given way to a retail ubiquity of movie images, denuded of history and context. Put simply, students have posters of Marilyn Monroe with her skirts billowing round her waist, but how many can name the movie from which that image is taken?

The other factor is the explosion of movie discussion on the web. This is in one way a thrilling, historic democratisation of film criticism. Now the old adage "everyone's a critic" is literally true. The one-party state of critical journalism is broken: anyone can publish their views on the net and get a global readership for them.

But there is the gloomy question of quality control: critical discourse is supplanted by anorak fan-speak and chat-room argument. The giant Internet Movie Database has become a wildly popular reference resource all over the world, but as it is managed by Amazon.com with an eye to marketing its videos and DVDs, it entrusts its "plot summary" for each film to any punter who cares to file one, on the basis, presumably, that the customer is always right.

But there are anti-dumbing forces ready to promote the cause of what, a little reductively, is known as World Cinema. The dynamism of Bollywood challenges the Los Angeles hegemony and acts as an antidote to dumbness and uniformity. Then there is the inexorable growth of festival culture: already, the Martell Tour of French Cinema is very popular and has led to French movies being picked up for distribution. It is at these festivals that world cinema can be seen, unencumbered by the pressure of distribution. Maybe it is here that a grassroots revolt against multiplex dullness, and dumbness, can begin.

 Peter Bradshaw is film critic of the Guardian
