webTitle: Report on the Food Standards Agency

fields.headline: Sacred cow
fields.standfirst: Following the recent damning report into BSE, the Food Standards Agency is once   again under the spotlight. But is it delivering the goods? Joanna Blythman reports
fields.trailText: Following the recent damning report into BSE, the Food Standards Agency is once again under the spotlight. But is it delivering the goods? Joanna Blythman reports
fields.body:
The Food Standards Agency (FSA) was set up by the government after the BSE debacle to "protect our right to expect food that is safe and of a high quality". And after the publication of the Phillips Inquiry into BSE, the promises made by government for the FSA seem even more pertinent. It was to be independent, open and "run by people with expertise in food safety and without any hidden agenda". It has now been in operation for eight months, and already disillusionment is rife. Eyebrows were first raised when its government-appointed boss, Sir John Krebs, appeared on Newsnight shortly after coming into the job. Sir John is a distinguished zoologist and authority on badger culling, with no particular "expertise" in food. Nevertheless, after being grilled by Jeremy Paxman, it was apparent that he had quite firm opinions that were supportive of genetically modified food, and was critically unconvinced of the benefits of organics.

In February, he again demonstrated his interest in biotechnology by chairing an Organisation For Economic Co-operation And Development (OECD) conference on GM food in Edinburgh. Then, last month, Sir John made a surprise attack on organics: "[People are] not getting value for money . . . if they think they're buying extra nutritional quality or extra safety [when they buy organic food], because we don't have the evidence to support these claims." The Soil Association, which campaigns for organic farming, was somewhat miffed. Its policy director, Patrick Holden, says, "Sir John has been badly advised. There are some 150 studies that demonstrate significant qualitative nutritional differences between organic and conventional food, and we have asked the FSA to fund more research into this area. Sir John is displaying bias by rubbishing the only system that is actually addressing consumer concerns."

On the enhanced safety of organic food, the Soil Association is happy to give chapter and verse - for example, that 43% of conventional fruit and vegetables contain pesticide residues, whereas the organic equivalents do not. But one fact is particularly persuasive: no fully organic cattle have contracted BSE, while 177,263 conventional ones have. At the Food Commission, an independent food watchdog that welcomed the setting up of the FSA, concern is now mounting over the FSA's handling of BSE. "We were looking for an agency that would be more open than MAFF [Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food] and make fewer blunders," says the commission's Dr Tim Lobstein. "What we've got is an agency that is a bit more open, but is still making blunders. About half the representation at its BSE 'stakeholder' meetings has come from the meat industry. As a result, the agency was actually considering lifting the ban that prevents cattle over 30 months going into the food chain. Following research showing how the disease could be transmitted through blood transfusion and the increase in human deaths from vCJD [variant CJD], it had to drop the idea."

On its ability to combat food poisoning, the FSA is also found wanting. "The FSA is a complete charade," says Dr Richard North, food poisoning authority and research director for Europe of Democracies and Diversities. "The FSA has been sidelined by the European Commission, which has quietly taken over control of food safety policy and enforcement. Sir John is effectively the head of a branch office of the new European Food Authority, and is left playing around with trivia in areas not covered by the commission's initiatives." For an illustration of this point, look no further than the FSA's recent revelations that 30% of frozen chickens contain more water than is legal. It is an old food scam that has been exposed repeatedly over the years by independent organisations such as the Consumers' Association and Food Commission, and numerous trading standards departments. It is politically safe territory, though - unlike the contamination of farmers' conventional seed with GM seed, urgent information that the FSA sat on for five whole weeks. So, the question now needs to be asked, is the old Machiavellian MAFF culture that brought us BSE in the first place now reasserting itself in the FSA?

"So many of the civil servants are ex-MAFF or Department of Health, and the board is loaded with people without a relevant background in food policy," says Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley University. North agrees: "Sir John is coming like a baby to an intensely political subject and being made to stick to the old MAFF orthodoxy by civil service minders." And Dr Lobstein goes even further: "Sir John's lack of experience in food leaves him open to manipulation by civil servants and the food industry." The FSA, meanwhile, denies that any of this is the case: "Sir John is coming from a position of independent, objective scientific assessment with no predisposition to one view or another," a spokesperson says. But if the FSA is to be anything more than a useless and expensive clone of MAFF, it needs to represent informed consumer opinion. Post-BSE, consumers have shown very clearly what kind of food they trust: it's no coincidence, after all, that our supermarkets are now brimming with organic food, while GM food is being forced off the shelves. Yet the FSA seems to be pursuing a curiously contrary agenda with its annual budget of £140 million, most of which is financed from the public purse. What's the point of a consumer watchdog that's totally out of step with what consumers want?

www.greenpeace.org.uk has a guide on GM supermarket foods.

webTitle: Jonathan Glancey on the brightest designs for contemporary housing

fields.headline: Beautiful strangeness
fields.standfirst: Should we all be living in similar-shaped boxes with a roof on top - or is there another way? Casting his eye over the brightest designs for contemporary housing, Jonathan Glancey argues that many of the best modern ideas have been drawn from our ancient past
fields.trailText: Should we all be living in similar-shaped boxes with a roof on top - or is there another way? Casting his eye over the brightest designs for contemporary housing, Jonathan Glancey argues that many of the best modern ideas have been drawn from our ancient past
fields.body:
Why don't more people live in radical, experimental, cutting-edge, call-them-what-you-will ultra-modern houses? Answer: Ask a five-year- old child to draw a house. Whether from a rich or poor background, whether born in a council flat in Glasgow or a mock Tudor mansion in Weybridge, the result will almost always be the same. A funny little box-like house with a pitched roof, smoking chimney, centrally placed door, a window on either side downstairs and two windows more or less symmetrically arranged above them. Quite often there will be a big sun shining above the roof and in the green crayon strip of garden below a stick mummy, a stick daddy and perhaps a cartoon-like cat.

I was gently challenged on this very subject a few months ago by fellow journalist John McCarthy, when he was making a BBC radio series on the nature of house and home. Even if they lived in a flat, he asked? Even if they were from single-parent families? Yes. McCarthy checked up on the theory by visiting an inner-city school and asking a class of children to draw a house. The theory did indeed hold up. McCarthy was astonished - but only until he had thought the notion through with me and other people for whom the history of house and home (not the same thing) are compelling subjects.

What the children are drawing, more or less, is a portrait of the human face. The first thing a child sees, or tries to focus on when born, is its mother's face. Well, breast maybe, but the mother spends a lot of time looking into her baby's face. When a young child draws a house, it puts a door where the mouth or nose is on its parent's face and windows for eyes. In the child's mind's eye, the house is home, a kind of anthropomorphic building-being, a sanctuary that is (or should be) as cosy and as reassuring as its mother's arms.

Home, then, is a notion as old as the human species. It is hardly surprising that the vast majority of people - whether they live in caves, as many still do in Guadix and Cappadocia; in mud, stone or straw huts; or in flats or houses - experience the home as a kind of replacement for the womb. Most like it to be a fixed point in their lives both emotionally and physically: old- fashioned, comforting, familiar. In Britain, although we like the idea of a groovy, modern studio-type apartment in a city centre, many people still share a dream of coming back, somehow, to the equivalent of a cosy cottage with perhaps a walled garden - a thing of inglenooks and log fires, of dogs damp after a long walk, of roast Sunday lunches and nips of sloe-gin in winter. Human beings tucked up as snug as bugs in rugs in the brick-and-stone arms of a friendly building-being.

Nicolas Pople, an architect and senior lecturer at London's South Bank University, has published a book called Experimental Houses, about buildings that are as far removed as can be imagined from the ones that children draw. Why? Because, as Pople says in his introduction, "experimentation is an inherently conscious act and is never innocent. The gesture of the experimental is expansive, moving beyond the known and immediately comprehensible, but with a clear set of objectives in view".

One of the new experimental homes in the book, an elegant concrete, aluminium and glass affair near Bordeaux, is designed by the influential architect Rem Koolhaas. As self-conscious as a Hollywood starlet, this is the house as box of tectonic tricks - a whole room acts as an elevator, linking all three floors - a clever game for fashionable architects to play as they get to grips with the ambitions and vanity of the wealthy, artistic bourgeoisie - and fail to respond to those for whom such a house is a magazine dream.

In terms of making nice images in hard-to-read architecture and la-la design magazines, Koolhaas's decidedly cool house has been a winner on the grandest scale. Unlike the traditional home represented guilelessly in children's drawings, this place is as much public relations exercise as experiment, a clever concatentation of forms designed to excite those brought up in a world of architecture refracted in the lenses of cameras or shone through slide projectors in design schools.

It is a house that seems to follow you around the globe: here it is, in model form, in an exhibition on modern homes in New York; here again in another handsome book touching down among a library of others on my desk, at least four of which show pictures of this very same building. If home is where we return for shelter and solace, to hide away from the uncertainties of the everyday world, to close the door and soak in the bath a million miles from the public stage where our hair is brushed and faces painted, then Koolhaas's creation is the opposite of home. It is a glamorous film set playing all the latest architectural games. It would be great fun for a holiday or a surprise weekend away, but, like so many experimental houses, not a place most people would consider living in.

I hate to sound conservative or as if I am putting the dampers on architectural experimentation, for the story of architecture at its best has been one of adventure and game-playing. Often this has been no more than the equivalent of rearranging deckchairs on an ocean liner, but there have been revolutions, both aesthetic and technological. These have pushed both the design of homes and the ways we experience them into futures that on the one hand have given us the flushing lavatory, and on the other the Rem Koolhaas dwelling near Bordeaux.

Intriguingly, most of the major revolutions came very early on. Recently I stayed in a beautiful courtyard house, rebuilt countless times since it was first raised by Spanish Moors in the 14th century. Its design - solid walls keeping the world beyond at bay, colonnaded courtyards, an ancient underfloor central heating system and a wind tower for distributing cool air during the hottest Mediterranean months - dates back way beyond the arrival of the Arabs in Spain in the eighth century, back beyond the Romans who gave us their "hypocausts" (underfloor central heating), to the beginnings of civilised housing. This house - television, fridge and other mod cons aside - would be familiar to the residents of Ur, capital of Sumerian civilisation, between five and six thousand years ago. This is a sophisticated house - more complex than a child's drawing - yet it embodies nearly everything that we could possibly want in a city home.

Short of technology, then, have all the experiments in rural and urban housing since Ur and Sumerian civilisation been no more than architectural conceits and the vanity of riches?

To an extent, yes. Most of the types of homes we live in were invented a long time ago. Even the high-rise apartment block that we tend to think of a post-second world war horror (for the poor if not for the rich who have taken to it in Manhattan, as in Manila, as eagles to their mountain eyries), was a Roman invention. At its crowded, intensely noisy height in about 200AD, the centre of imperial Rome was ringed around with five- and even eight-storey apartment blocks (insulae).

These tended to be shoddily built and many deaths were caused by the Roman equivalent of chip-pan fires, but you would find yourself more at home here than you might imagine. The smartest Roman homes, for instance, as in homes from earlier Mediterranean and Mesopotamian civilisations, boasted various forms of lavatory that would be acceptable to most of us today.

Air-conditioning? It gets hot in Rome, doesn't it? Yes, but responsibly and sensually designed homes throughout the world have never needed refrigerating; instead, the best have made use of wind as well as deep eaves, fountains, colonnades, shutters and other simple architectural devices to keep extreme heat at bay. In any case, Arab domestic architecture featured effective air-conditioning centuries ago. In the heart of medieval Cairo, you can visit old merchant houses cooled by air that is caught by funnels rising like those of ships above the dense roofscape.

Double-glazing, then? Again, that goes back a very long way, too. Open-plan living? Didn't that come in just about a century ago with Frank Lloyd Wright in Chicago? Well, yes, but it was also a feature of cave dwellings, of the grass skerms of Kung Bushmen, of the Inuit igloo, of the great communal dwellings of the Yanomamo Indians of the Orinoco river basin, of Arab tents, Kazakh yurts . . . of the beautiful cluster dwellings of the Awuna people of Ghana or the sophisticated multi-cylinder homes of the Mesakin Quisar people of Sudan.

Alright, clever clogs, what about the mass-produced modular house invented by Le Corbusier (1887-1965) and made possible by 20th-century war-time and Fordian conveyor belt technology? I'm sorry. Try going back to Kahun, the 20-acre, 27th-century (BC) new town built to house the workers engaged on building the Illahun pyramid for Sesostris II. Here, rows of mass-produced worker's homes sharing near identical plans have been identified. In some ways, these fast-track dwellings were more sophisticated than their 20th-century counterparts, because internal walls were clearly arranged, or perhaps even moved, as and when a particular family needed more or fewer rooms. This 5,000-year-old idea was to be one of the revolutionary selling points of the Millennium Village currently being built on the North Greenwich peninsula, London, in the long shadow of the Dome. The ancient Egyptian workers' dwellings also featured roof terraces and were built of 100% recyclable materials.

Even so, few architects have proved to be as adventurous as the imaginations of, say, Marco Polo (Travels) or Italo Calvino (Invisible Cities), both of whom have created gloriously experimental houses in their respective mind's eye. Nicolas Pople quotes Polo's compelling description of Kublai Khan's pavilion: "let me tell you how these two halls and the chamber are constructed. Each hall has columns of spicewood very skilfully carved. On the outside they are all covered with lion-skins of great beauty, striped with black and white and orange. They are so well designed that neither wind nor rain can harm them or do any mischief. Inside, they are all of ermine and sable which are the two finest and costliest furs there are... and the chamber where the Khan sleeps... is also of lion-skins without and ermine and sable within, magnificent in workmanship and design."

Today, few of us wish to kill such rare and magnificent animals for their skins, yet Polo captures for us a dreamy and sensual home - an experiment in imaginative living - that few radical modern architects with their clumping concrete, insistent brick and deterministic steel can hope to match in the wonder stakes. Although modern architecture has become fashionable over the past 20 years, few architects have been able to shake the vast majority of people from their simple and possibly innate dream of a house that looks like a child's drawing and which, for better or worse, was invented with humankind

 Experimental Houses, by Nicolas Pople, is published by Lawrence King at £45. To buy a copy for the special price of £40 (plus 99p UK p&p), call Guardian CultureShop on 0800 316 6102 or send a cheque, payable to Guardian CultureShop, to CultureShop, 32-34 Park Royal Road, London NW10 7LN.

These have pushed both the design of homes and the ways we experience them into futures that on the one hand have given us the flushing lavatory, and on the other the Rem Koolhaas dwelling near Bordeaux. Intriguingly, most of the major revolutions came very early on. Recently I stayed in a beautiful courtyard house, rebuilt countless times since it was first raised by Spanish Moors in the 14th century. Its design - solid walls keeping the world beyond at bay, colonnaded courtyards, an ancient underfloor central heating system and a wind tower for distributing cool air during the hottest Mediterranean months - dates back way beyond the arrival of the Arabs in Spain in the eighth century, back beyond the Romans who gave us their "hypocausts" (underfloor central heating), to the beginnings of civilised housing. This house - television, fridge and other mod cons aside - would be familiar to the residents of Ur, capital of Sumerian civilisation, between five and six thousand years ago. This is a sophisticated house - more complex than a child's drawing - yet it embodies nearly everything that we could possibly want in a city home. Short of technology, then, have all the experiments in rural and urban housing since Ur and Sumerian civilisation been no more than architectural conceits and the vanity of riches? To an extent, yes. Most of the types of homes we live in were invented a long time ago. Even the high-rise apartment block that we tend to think of a post-second world war horror (for the poor if not for the rich who have taken to it in Manhattan, as in Manila, as eagles to their mountain eyries), was a Roman invention. At its crowded, intensely noisy height in about 200AD, the centre of imperial Rome was ringed around with five- and even eight-storey apartment blocks (insulae). These tended to be shoddily built and many deaths were caused by the Roman equivalent of chip-pan fires, but you would find yourself more at home here than you might imagine. The smartest Roman homes, for instance, as in homes from earlier Mediterranean and Mesopotamian civilisations, boasted various forms of lavatory that would be acceptable to most of us today. Air-conditioning? It gets hot in Rome, doesn't it? Yes, but responsibly and sensually designed homes throughout the world have never needed refrigerating; instead, the best have made use of wind as well as deep eaves, fountains, colonnades, shutters and other simple architectural devices to keep extreme heat at bay. In any case, Arab domestic architecture featured effective air-conditioning centuries ago. In the heart of medieval Cairo, you can visit old merchant houses cooled by air that is caught by funnels rising like those of ships above the dense roofscape. Double-glazing, then? Again, that goes back a very long way, too. Open-plan living? Didn't that come in just about a century ago with Frank Lloyd Wright in Chicago? Well, yes, but it was also a feature of cave dwellings, of the grass skerms of Kung Bushmen, of the Inuit igloo, of the great communal dwellings of the Yanomamo Indians of the Orinoco river basin, of Arab tents, Kazakh yurts . . . of the beautiful cluster dwellings of the Awuna people of Ghana or the sophisticated multi-cylinder homes of the Mesakin Quisar people of Sudan. Alright, clever clogs, what about the mass-produced modular house invented by Le Corbusier (1887-1965) and made possible by 20th-century war-time and Fordian conveyor belt technology? I'm sorry. Try going back to Kahun, the 20-acre, 27th-century (BC) new town built to house the workers engaged on building the Illahun pyramid for Sesostris II. Here, rows of mass-produced worker's homes sharing near identical plans have been identified. In some ways, these fast-track dwellings were more sophisticated than their 20th-century counterparts, because internal walls were clearly arranged, or perhaps even moved, as and when a particular family needed more or fewer rooms. This 5,000-year-old idea was to be one of the revolutionary selling points of the Millennium Village currently being built on the North Greenwich peninsula, London, in the long shadow of the Dome. The ancient Egyptian workers' dwellings also featured roof terraces and were built of 100% recyclable materials. Even so, few architects have proved to be as adventurous as the imaginations of, say, Marco Polo (Travels) or Italo Calvino (Invisible Cities), both of whom have created gloriously experimental houses in their respective mind's eye. Nicolas Pople quotes Polo's compelling description of Kublai Khan's pavilion: "let me tell you how these two halls and the chamber are constructed. Each hall has columns of spicewood very skilfully carved. On the outside they are all covered with lion-skins of great beauty, striped with black and white and orange. They are so well designed that neither wind nor rain can harm them or do any mischief. Inside, they are all of ermine and sable which are the two finest and costliest furs there are... and the chamber where the Khan sleeps... is also of lion-skins without and ermine and sable within, magnificent in workmanship and design." Today, few of us wish to kill such rare and magnificent animals for their skins, yet Polo captures for us a dreamy and sensual home - an experiment in imaginative living - that few radical modern architects with their clumping concrete, insistent brick and deterministic steel can hope to match in the wonder stakes. Although modern architecture has become fashionable over the past 20 years, few architects have been able to shake the vast majority of people from their simple and possibly innate dream of a house that looks like a child's drawing and which, for better or worse, was invented with humankind  Experimental Houses, by Nicolas Pople, is published by Lawrence King at £45. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Even though Crete produces horrible wine, you can save your holidays with a good vintage selection, writes Malcolm Gluck.
fields.body:
The worst aspect of any holiday in Crete, I have found, is the wine. Indeed, the ugliest wine I have ever tasted in my entire life was Cretan (ahead of the red from Crimea, which smelt of Domestos and the white from the Czech Republic which tasted as if chrysanthemums had been raised in it). The Cretan horror was a red retsina, highly oxidised and redolent of creosote, and it came complete with a verbal warning from the maker's daughter, which unwisely I chose to ignore in an act of bravado.

To the rescue of Crete, however, has come Oddbins and Mirambelo IIeza Creta Olympias 1998, a marvellous grouping of syllables announcing a generous red wine of chewiness and richness - dry, fruity, warmly tannic, with a hint of the exotic - and, at £3.99, something of a bargain. It rates 16 points out of 20.

The Co-op, too, has some bargains, on promotion until the November 12. Bright Brothers Viognier Reserve 1999 (15 points, £4.99, superstore branches only), from Argentina, carries hints of ripe peach and honey to the dry fruit which finishes softly. Puglia Primitivo Sangiovese 1999 (16 points, £2.99), from Italy, combines a medley of fruit and fresh acidity in compelling combination with perfect, soft tannins. This is an absurd price for such a performance since it has substance and style. Terramater Malbec 1999 (15.5 points, £3.99, superstores only), from Chile, has subtly spicy cherries and blackberries, a touch of herbs, a suggestion of earth - plus a backing group of tannins.

Chevalière Réserve Grenache Vieilles Vignes 1998 (14 points, £2.99) is soft and ripe, full of fruit, and is far from subtle. Rhône Valley Red 1999 (14.5 points, two for a fiver) is very juicy and fruit-packed but does have tannins to tighten the finish. This wine has a white partner, Rhône Valley White 1999 (14 points, two for a fiver) which is decently textured and displays gently earthy, under-ripe fruit.

At Sainsbury, there is Wild Pig Shiraz Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (16 points, £3.99) which has a lovely dry herbiness with plummy fruit with a slight cassis edge. It has a rugged feel yet it isn't too deep or rich so much as rustically elegant and gently spicy. Grander, more pompous altogether in truth, is Ochoa Gran Reserva Navarra 1993 (16 points, £10.99, 80 branches only) from Spain. This is a distinguished, slightly world-weary grandee of a bottle: tobacco-edged, rich, very dry, figgy and raisiny. It is an unusually mature wine to find in a supermarket and it is not the sort of stuff I would drink without a robust dish to set it against.

Tesco has Château Haut-Bourcier Premières Côtes de Blaye 1999 (16 points, £4.99), which is a stunningly well concentrated, superbly tannic claret of depth and daring and great class. It is in limited distribution at selected branches. As is Jaboulet Côtes du Rhône Villages 1998 (16.5 points, £5.99).

This red parades beautifully evolved tannins and fruit, which develop wonderfully on the tongue, showing complex fruits and herby earth well knitted together. Even more complex is Gallo Sonoma Barrelli Creek Cabernet Sauvignon 1995 (17 points, £11.99, limited distribution) made by the granddaughter of the late Julio Gallo, Gina Gallo, from a magnificent vineyard in the Alexander Valley in California. This wine offers a virtuoso attack of plums, blackcurrants, ripe damsons and hugely warm and spicy tannins. This is a very sensual wine which lovers of claret from great vineyards in extraordinary years will find rewarding, extra-special, and compellingly well priced. It is a wine of great class and superior breeding.

Well bred also is Majestic's Amarone Valpolicella Tedeschi 1996 (18 points, £12.99), from Italy, one of the more extravagantly delicious specimens of this unique style of wine. Lively, serious, hugely amusing and concentrated, it unites the commonplace elements of wine (sugar, acid, tannin) into something joyously original and very fine-showing liquorice, prunes and a variety of hedgerow fruits. It even dares to throw in a suggestion of coffee. Of course, I could be mistaken about this last component. I only spotted it when the bottle was nigh empty.

fields.headline: How to
fields.standfirst: ...have big ears.
fields.trailText: ...have big ears.
fields.body:
Having big ears is one of the oddest peculiarities to have because no one quite knows what it means. For example, if you're a man with big ears, women don't titter in the street, wink knowingly and say, 'Look at the size of his ears!' Or they might do, but that's the end of the conversation. Women don't really have a big-ear problem, as they can grow their hair over them. All you have to remember is to go for big hair all over. Simply growing hair over the affected area will make you look as though you're wearing earmuffs.

Some lobally-challenged people refer laughingly to their big ears as love handles. This is not meant to be taken literally and if, during carnal transport, they are handled excessively, the big-eared may well feel that their lover is fantasising about making love to a hobbit.

There comes a time in the life of every big-eared football player when his friends will decide he resembles the FA Cup. This is okay, as far as it goes, but when the whole teams decide to tie coloured ribbons on the handles and parade 'The Cup' around the pitch, then the amusement factor tends to tail off, especially for the person between the ears.

Some famous people have been known to glue back their ears in order to make themselves seem more streamlined. The trick here is to make sure the glue is strong enough. There's nothing worse than making a big social entrance with your nicely flush ears, only to have one suddenly break free and fly open like a taxi door.

Big-ear wearers, like Battle of Britain pilots, are constantly aware of the position of the sun. When the sun gets behind your ears it gaily shines straight through them, making you look as though you've got a couple of Chinese lanterns attached to your head. If a group of people are laughing unexpectedly at you and you know you've got a big pair of rubbery flappers, check the sun.

When night falls, the trials of the big-eared are far from over. Turning over on your pillow requires as much attention to the positioning of the ears as a pilot would give to the positioning of the undercarriage on landing. If you accidentally fold an ear over and spend the night with the weight of your head on it, not only will it stick out in the morning, but there's a very good chance that it will be pointing forward. And that's a distinction you don't need on a crowded bus. Especially if it's on its way to the Cup Final.

webTitle: The net addict: Tanya gets new age

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya gets new age
fields.body:
'Paul doesn't want to delay our wedding any longer, dear,' Mum said coyly, 'but I need to know if he's really right for me, and that our marriage will work. Can you find me an astrologist, please?' Dozens of sites came up ('Unlimited Psychic Readings for $2.95! Email readings, tarot readings, psychic chat, dream interpretation, horoscopes, biorhythms...' at www.getpsyched.net seemed good value), but, as is often the case, the more interesting sites were not directly related to the subject in question. I thought that www.ecrush.com might come in handy one day.

If you develop a crush on someone whom you don't dare approach directly, you subscribe and give them the email address of your unreachable dream. They ask by email whether impossible dream has a crush, and if the recipient could be kind enough to let them know the first name of that person. If the name is yours, you are notified and everything is roses. In love, as in everything else, Americans are so clever and inventive.

More useful (it could be helpful when planning a dinner party) was www.russianfoods.com/horoscope, which recommends what to eat or avoid, depending on your star sign. Apparently, Cancerians are voracious foodies who must keep to a strict diet, but they can eat as much watermelon as they want. Almost as fascinating as the astral implications of food is the English used on the site: 'Don't get despaired, there is a thing you can eat at no allowance...'

I found myself reminiscing about Igor, my fiery Russian. This broody mood may have had to do with the fact that I had bought a mini-disc player on the net just before I discovered www.toobo.co.uk, which compares prices and shows you the cheapest alternatives. I would have saved 7%!

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.trailText: 'All this blushing is exhausting. I'll need more blood now I'm a Scottish heiress'.
fields.body:
'All this blushing is exhausting. I'll need more blood now I'm a Scottish heiress'.

'No! That's mine, actually, Gordon!" Snatch envelope from ex-spouse's fingers. "Billet-doux from the demon lover, eh?" he sneers.

"Mind your own business!" Blush - and it's a double blush. Treacherous instinct to deny Umbrian fling with Fred, but more urgent need to lie about the envelope, which contains a cheque made out to me from Aunt Elspeth. I have reason to believe it might be big bucks, though what exactly big bucks means to a Scottish Presbyterian remains a mystery. Possibly venison.

Unfortunately, by blushing and acting suspiciously, I have interested ex-spouse in the envelope much more than if I'd just said, "Well, it is a letter from Fred, actually. Excuse me while I lock myself in the bathroom and devour every passionate page." All this blushing is exhausting. I'm going to need more blood now that I'm a secret heiress.

"It's a quotation for a conservatory, if you really must know," I snap, resorting to ludicrous lie. Wonder what the gunpowder plotters came up with when caught rolling barrels about in cellars: "Er, they're going for an atrium and deck ... it's okay. It's one of Grinling Gibbons' makeovers." Hold on tight to my envelope. It can't be very much. Aunt's already sunk £50,000 in this house. Try hard to think in hundreds. Meet aunt in doorway.

"Dulcie's thinking of having a conservatory!" Ex-spouse announces. A sweet smile lights up her face.

"Well, if that would give you pleasurrre, why not, dearrr?" she pats my arm affectionately. Hey! If she thinks I can suddenly afford a conservatory, it must be thousands. "They do say, though, that burrrglarrrs like conserrrvatorrries."

"It's all right, Auntie, I don't want one."

"Yes she does!" persists ex-spouse. "She's got a quotation and everything." The big issue, though, is not whether I am going to have a conservatory. It's whether ex-spouse will get half the dosh. After all, he is her flesh and blood, and he does take her to Scotland occasionally. Should I ask her, in private? Should I just give him half? Could I get away with keeping it all myself? Oh God! I'm deeply corrupted already and I haven't even opened the envelope! If he finds out I've got the lot, there will be fireworks. On the other hand, he did leave me and beget anew. And I'm the one who deals with the aunt's old Damart undies.

"Dulcie, dearrr, I want a worrrd with you." Aunt looks meaningfully at me. Ex-spouse recoils. Usually her private words and meaningful looks revolve around indelicate ailments. "Fine, let's go to your room, then," I smile, hustling her into her tartan den.

"I don't quite know what to do about Gorrrdon, dearrr. Arrre you and he, well, are you togetherrr?"

Huge blush pours down out of my hair, leaving my brain pale and struggling. Are we together? Except as co-parasites of hers? But never mind the truth - what does the aunt regard as desirable? Whatever she wants, I'll do it with him. No, wait! I draw the line at renewing vows. I don't think we ever did vows in the first place, actually. It was a register office affair in the early 70s. Not so much Forsaking All Other as Open Marriage please apply in triplicate. Although we didn't have many takers.

"I don't know where I am with him, Auntie." Shrug in what I hope is a heroic and picturesque fashion.

"The thing is, dearrr, I wouldn't mind Gorrrdon having a bit of my money, and I wouldn't even mind Elaine, but that horrrrrrid plumberrr chap she's living with now - what was his name?" "Tom." With this practice, I could blush for England.

"I wouldn't want him to get his hands on it. Between you and me, I didn't like the way he was always hanging rrround you. Oh dearrr! Wasn't he awful?" Aunt shudders at the thought of the one person who did adore me, once.

Dimly aware of a phone ringing and ex-spouse answering it. Then there's a knock on aunt's door. "Dulcie! Phone! It's the demon lover!"

"Which one?" I quip uneasily. Aunt does not smile. Jest was a damp squib. She is obviously considering giving me a rocket. I'm already knee deep in treason and plot. It can only be a matter of time before the lot goes up.

It's the demon lover!" "Which one?" I quip uneasily. Aunt does not smile. Jest was a damp squib. She is obviously considering giving me a rocket. I'm already knee deep in treason and plot. It can only be a matter of time before the lot goes up.

fields.headline: A spice  odyssey
fields.standfirst: Their place in world history is assured, but you should also try  to find a place for them in your cooking, too. Jeremy Lee goes potty for cinnamon and cloves
fields.trailText: Their place in world history is assured, but you should also try  to find a place for them in your cooking, too. Jeremy Lee goes potty for cinnamon and cloves
fields.body:
Okay, own up. Who has tried smoking the ultimate roll-up, a cinnamon stick, instead of Anne Widdecombe's least favourite recreational drug? How many had their faces contorting as they tried to get something of a hit? The plain truth is that the spices freshly ground are so potent as to render even the innocent quite dizzy. Not that the shenanigans of those who pioneered the spice trade aren't spicy enough in their own right.

Our own colonial history was propelled by the desire to monopolise the spice trade, competing with the French and the Dutch. In those days, much like today, imperial conquest was privatised, and the business of securing the colonies, trades and routes delegated to such companies as the East India Company.

But before all that, it was spices, and the fabulous prices they fetched, that drove European sailors and merchants to explore the rest of the world. Why, America might have remained undiscovered for many more years, had not Christopher Columbus, a native of Genoa financed by the court of Spain, not gone looking for another route to the Spice Islands of the East. How much art and vainglory owed its existence to cinnamon and cloves?

Cinnamon, cloves, pepper and nutmeg are possibly the most important of all the spices, and are among the earliest to be used. Native to the Moluccas in what is now East Indonesia, cloves are mentioned in China as early as the third century BC. The worth of these spices became incalculable, for, not only did they give a fine flavour to foods, but their medicinal properties were considered potent indeed. Cloves were used to sweeten the breath and later, counteract BO. Oil of cloves is an antiseptic, and is still used to deaden toothache, and so it is not surprising that it crops up in brines and pickles, both methods of preserving foods. Alan Davidson's The Oxford Companion To Food explains that the name clove derives from the French clou de girofle, literally nail of clove, which aptly describes the bud in its dried form. When used sparingly, most notably in stews, braises and soups, it adds a most pleasing richness and depth to the finished dish.

The history of cinnamon goes back even further- to 2500BC, in fact, when the ingenious Chinese recorded its use. The search for true cinnamon, as opposed to wild cinnamon and cassia - curiously known to pharmacists as senna pods - has a history as long as it is strange. In his fascinating book on spices, Dangerous Tastes (British Museum Press), Andrew Dalby tells that cinnamon was considered as great a prize as gold, and that the legend of La Canela was as powerful as that of El Dorado. Gonzalo Pizarro led a 2,000-strong expedition to exhaustion and death in the forests of Ecuador in search of it. Only 80 men returned. But in spite of their popularity in the cooking of India, Arabia and North Africa, we don't use cinnamon and cloves with the enthusiasm we used to. The use of cinnamon has waned from the days when it flavoured desserts and creams before being cast aside in favour of vanilla. Indeed, that loathsome brew, mulled wine, a recipe to put anyone off spice, wine and Christmas simultaneously, is a last bastion of recognised spice in the contemporary kitchen.

All recipes serve six.

Spiced potatoes and spinach

1.5kg fresh spinach
3 medium onions
1 thumb-sized piece fresh ginger
8 cloves garlic
1 fresh hot chilli
8 tbsp vegetable oil
2kg good, large waxy potatoes
1 medium cauliflower 1 stick cinnamon
7 whole cloves
7 whole cardamom pods
2 bayleaves
2 tbsp ground coriander
1 tbsp ground cumin
1 tsp ground turmeric
1 large tomato
2 tbsp plain yoghurt
Sea salt
1 tbsp garam masala

Remove any excess stalk and damaged leaves from the spinach. Bring a large pan of lightly salted water to the boil, plunge in the spinach and leave to cook for one minute. Transfer it to a bowl of iced water, or lay on flat trays to drain and cool. Squeeze the spinach dry. Peel and rinse the potatoes. Cut them into large wedges and rinse again.

Separate the cauliflower into florets. Blanch and peel the tomato, then roughly chop. Peel and roughly chop the onions, ginger, chilli and garlic. Put them in a liquidiser, with five tablespoons of water, and whizz to a paste.

Place a large, heavy-bottomed pot over a medium heat and pour in the vegetable oil. Add all the whole herbs and spices, fry for 10 seconds, then add the paste, lower the heat and fry for 10 minutes more, until darkened slightly. Add the ground spices and fry for a further five minutes, adding a drop of water now and then if the mixture sticks to the base of the pan. Tip in the tomato and yoghurt, stir, then add the potatoes and cauliflower, and stir until coated. Roughly chop the spinach, and add this to the pot, too. Pour in enough water to come just below the surface of the vegetable mass, and cover with a lid. Turn off the heat and leave to cool for 40 minutes, keeping the lid on, then remove the lid and simmer again, not too gently, until most of the liquid has reduced and the sauce is thickened. Dust the surface of the stew with garam masala and stir in, taking care not to break up the vegetables.

Chocolate chinchilla

Culled from Elizabeth David, cheering the match of cinnamon and chocolate.

7 egg whites
60g unsweetened cocoa powder
90g caster sugar
1 heaped tsp ground cinnamon

Pre-heat the oven to 160C/325F/gas mark 3. Butter a ring mould or, even better, a kugelhopf mould or, better still, a steamed pudding mould with a central funnel and clip-on lid. Sieve together the cocoa, sugar and cinnamon into a big bowl. In another scrupulously cleaned bowl, whip the egg whites until peaked and stiff.

Tip in the sugar mixture, and fold in with care until well combined. Fill the prepared mould with the resulting mixture, and stand in a tray filled with enough water to come half-way up the sides of your chosen mould.

Cook in the middle of the oven for 45-50 minutes. It will rise in a spectacular manner and, upon cooling, sink in even more spectacular a fashion unless, the moment you take it from the oven, you leave the mould to cool in a warm place well protected from draughts and any sudden changes in temperature. When cold, the pudding, although shrunken from its just-baked glory, will have become compact enough to turn out easily. It is best served with just-whipped cream enlivened with a little sugar and rum.

Cinnamon ice cream

Cinnamon flavours ice cream very well - and makes a perfect partner for plums in tarts or crumbles.

520ml double cream
280ml good milk
2 cinnamon sticks
1 ball allspice
1 clove
120g caster sugar
4 egg yolks

Roughly break up the cinnamon and add it to the milk, along with the clove and allspice. Heat the milk, but do not let it come to a boil. The milk can then sit for an hour or so, to infuse the spice flavours, if time permits - at the very least it needs 15 minutes. In a bowl, whisk the egg yolks and sugar together, then pour in the warm milk. Mix thoroughly, then return the mixture to the pan. Stir gently but constantly over a gentle heat until the custard thickens - on no account allowing it to reach a boil. Once cooked, remove the pan from the heat and pour in the cream. Mix and strain the custard, then freeze in an ice-cream machine according to the manufacturer's instructions. The custard will keep for several days in the fridge, but the ice, once made, is best eaten within hours of churning.

Crab apple and clove jelly

Most comforting through chill winter months. I have said it before, but imperial measurements seem to make the best jam, and I stand firm on that.

1 big heap crab apples
Caster sugar
Cloves
1 vanilla pod

Thoroughly clean the apples, then cut them up, skin, pips and all. Put the prepared apples in a big pan, and add enough water to barely cover them. Bring to a boil, and simmer gently until the fruit has softened.

Set up a jelly bag over a pot or bucket, tip in the apples and leave to drip through the night. Measure the result and for every pint of liquid add one pound of caster sugar. Stir well, tip into big pot, along with a whole vanilla pod, and bring to the boil. Skim off any scum that appears on the surface and boil for 45 minutes more. Pour into individual glass jars that have been thoroughly cleaned and dried, adding two whole cloves to each pot.

Steamed crab apple, clove and orange pudding

Butter, for greasing
1 jar homemade crab apple and clove jelly (see above)
220g self-raising flour
1 tsp baking powder
180g caster sugar
180g unsalted butter
3 very fresh eggs
Grated zest of 2 oranges
Grated zest of 2 lemons
30ml lemon juice
30ml orange juice
Salt

Take a large pot with sufficient capacity to hold a pudding basin, fill it with water and bring to the boil. Generously butter the pudding basin, then place a square of greaseproof paper large enough to cover the base on the bottom. Plonk a couple of generous spoonfuls of jelly on the paper, then set the basin to one side.

Sift the flour and baking powder into a bowl. In a mixing bowl, beat together the sugar and butter until pale and increased in volume. Crack the eggs into a jug, mix with a fork, then pour a little at a time into the mixing bowl, stirring constantly. Continue until all the egg is incorporated. Add the citrus zest, then add the flour/baking powder mixture and fold in until the ingredients are thoroughly combined. Carefully stir in the fruit juices. Decant the resulting batter into the pudding bowl and seal with tin foil, if required.

Place the pudding basin into the big, simmering pot and cover with a lid. Leave to simmer for two hours or so, checking the water from time to time to make sure it has not evaporated. Remove the pudding bowl from the water, allow it to sit for a few minutes, then unmould and serve with plenty of fresh homemade custard

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

webTitle: Isabel Fonesca on her brother Bruno

fields.headline: Dear Brother
fields.standfirst: For Isabel Fonseca, her elder brother Bruno was the one who saved her from drowning as a child, the one who inspired her to 'walk into her fears' as an adult. He was also a remarkable artist. And after his appallingly early death, it is his work  - perhaps the best and truest part of him - that is left behind. Here, she celebrates a life fulfilled
fields.trailText: For Isabel Fonseca, her elder brother Bruno was the one who saved her from drowning as a child, the one who inspired her to 'walk into her fears' as an adult. He was also a remarkable artist. And after his appallingly early death, it is his work  - perhaps the best and truest part of him - that is left behind. Here, she celebrates a life fulfilled.
fields.body:
December 25, 1989. We sat on tall stools at a bar with no name, "Bruno's local", downstairs from his studio on the corner of calle Reina Amalia in Barcelona's Barrio Chino, the red-light district. Along with everyone else in the place - a handful of souls brought together by their loose-endedness that Christmas Day - Bruno and I stared up at the wall-mounted black-and-white TV, riveted by an incredible transmission: the execution of Elena and Nicolae Ceausescu, here played out to the surreally corny soundtrack of Feliz Navidad, sung by children and blaring from some scratchy PA system in the street.

The bar is now closed - indeed, it has been walled up with cement blocks. Gone too, of course, is the incandescent pulse of possibility belonging to those amazing days of upheaval. But for Bruno and for me - both of us in every sense far from the action of our peers in Eastern Europe - something of that possibility remained, and propelled each of us into our own discoveries.

It doesn't seem even vaguely surprising that most of the moments in my life that have emerged as "significant" were witnessed, influenced, or even engineered by Bruno Fonseca, my older brother. For me, those days in Barcelona turned out to be the beginning of a five-year journey among the Gypsies of Eastern Europe (and by the end of that five-year journey Bruno would be dead). But Bruno had more to do with my launch than did the Ceausescus or the students of Bucharest's University Square. I'd long wanted to quit my job and travel to convulsing Eastern Europe (from which during earlier convulsions, some of our family had emigrated). But I was scared. I was interested in Gypsies and fluent on such topics as minorities and democracies, exclusion and deracination; the uses of exoticism; the outsider in the European imagination . . . But Bruno was more fluent. "If you're interested in Gypsies," he put to me that night, "don't you think we'd better go and meet some?"

And so we did. Somehow (and somehow of course) Bruno knew about a group of Gitnos camped at Gava Playa, a beach just outside of Barcelona's city limits. We set out for the camp one evening, just a few days after the executions. For that night on the beach, I would have worn something "neutral", that is something "poor". But Bruno, with his superior instincts, chose his most elegant garment (his only elegant garment), an enormous dark blue cashmere overcoat and he wore it loose, hanging from his broad coathanger shoulders. Down in the street he bought and stashed under his arms a couple of bottles of Ballantine whisky and a carton of cigarettes. He also happened to have in his inner pocket a deck of cards, but our most important provision was the ready supply of Bruno's emollient, inimitably casual charm, the perfect antidote to my own rather worried and earnest presence.

Bruno had a belief that you had to "walk into your fears". (As a teenager his unfortunate motto was "Try anything at least once".) Walk into your fears: now this was hard to do. Not for the usual reasons but, at least for his little sister, because it was just impossible to be afraid in his company. Fear didn't come up. Ethical considerations, yes, always: Should we be even doing this? What is our real motive? If anything Bruno was unduly freighted with such concerns (often working them out, pros and cons, in endless lists). But he rarely paused over his own safety. Here again his instincts were uncommon and, at least this time, they were also right. We spent most of the night with those Gypsies by their fire. Though wary at first, they very soon took their cue from us: the tone was good, the night was fine, the mood was gay. Over the next five years I went on my own to dozens of Gypsy camps, many much rougher than the one at Gava Playa. But after that night, and I believe, because of it, I never again was distracted by considerations of fear - nor did I ever meet with any real danger. To many of his admirers, Bruno seemed a heroic example of the Greek idea that character is fate - a picture complicated, we must admit (and struggle to comprehend), by his early death which was such an affront to his virtue.

Yes, virtue. After Bruno's death I received one particularly encouraging letter of condolence, from the poet Hugo Williams. "Death can be useful," he wrote, "because we inherit the virtues of those we love." Despite Bruno's obvious handicaps (severe dyslexia, staggering disorganisation) he had more than his share of virtues. Prominent among these were his hopeful instincts and his irresistible good influence, including his generosity. He was generous with his money and his time. But Bruno also had a more unusual virtue, that of full empathy. Even as an adolescent, when most of us are particularly, even rightfully solipsistic, Bruno was able to step into your shoes with your feet - that is, to imagine not what was right for you but what was right from your point of view (seldom the same thing).

Imaginative sympathy continued to be his first reaction to any difficulty. The difficulty, say, of beginning a life with someone when you are dying (Shakespeare might have written for Bruno the sonnet which reminds us that "love is not love which alters when it alteration finds"). Five weeks before he died, Bruno was due to marry his beloved Anke, the young German painter who was herself a kind of pupil of Bruno's and his last companion.

A chapel in downtown New York had been booked - Anke had always wanted a church wedding - but as the day approached it was clear that Bruno was too sick to move. So the wedding was to be held in the East 10th Street loft of our brother, Caio (the betrothed were living in an apartment upstairs).

On the day, Bruno was unable to stand. With what must have been a tremendous effort, as he entered in a wheelchair to greet the crowd of friends and relations, he was smiling, gracious and seemingly light-hearted. When the minister began the service, the hot sunshine was interrupted by a storm of cracking New York thunder and lightning. Through the pounding, a woman in black sang a plangent Ave Maria; Anke's father read out Corinthians 13, and more in German. The bride wore grey - which sounds almost comical, but she looked wonderful and simple, and solemn in a childlike way. A wedding should be solemn, I think; certainly for all the intensity of feeling, for all the tears that flowed from each distinct tear group - tears of joy, grief, and love - this was a wedding that obviated the need for a funeral.

At long last, the minister pronounced Bruno and Anke man and wife, and at that moment a bolt of lightning exploded in a deafening clap; the storm ended and the sun came out again. Bruno's cool comment as he turned his face to his bride was, "I had a word with Zeus." And then, as everyone was laughing and moving in to congratulate, Bruno nodded in my direction. I wheeled him behind a borrowed screen where he vomited on to a paper plate and wiped his face with a champagne-moistened paper napkin before going back out to his guests.

Bruno was not, in fact, an easygoing person - he worked and he worried very hard - but the characteristic, apparently effortless approach prevailed in his work. There, too, it represented some degree of suppression, even triumph over real difficulties. Our mother claims that, as a young child, Bruno was not a "natural", that of her four children he was the least fluent with a crayon. But he pushed himself. For example, over many winter weekends in Connecticut, Bruno aged, 14 or 15, would stay in his room painstakingly copying the drawings of Michelangelo while the rest of us went skiing. Later on, he was not fazed by the hundreds of little decisions each painting demands of the painter. He trusted his talent. And his personality allowed him to take risks. Indeed from early on, Bruno demanded it of himself.

As a painter he was most interested in formal problems, but he instinctively understood that every painting must begin with an emotion, that the work would be cold without a true and personal investment. If this end of being an artist or just of being Bruno was all pretty exhausting and time-consuming for him it wasn't easy for onlookers either. You had to worry about Bruno. But like many others I was in awe not only of his famous "eye" - Bruno missed nothing - but of his truly open mind.

On Bruno's famous eye: he was an unbelievably successful street scavenger, dragging home in the daylight or the dark any likely specimen for his lab of possibilities. It was in the course of this secondary pursuit that he hit on the ultimate, foolproof method for determining just how good a modern painting is: if you found it in the street, would you drag it home? And then, having dragged it home, would you hang it up? Or paint over it? But Bruno also had an educated eye for objects, for form, for the authentic. From the antiquities to kitsch, his loose collection of found and bought and bargained-for things was vast and original. He shared with our father a passion for the Egyptian, the pre-Columbian, the Greek and (perhaps especially) the "provenance unknown". He was the only collector among the children - of Roman coins, of small Mayan ceramic figures and heads. He and Papa would spend hours discussing the possible origin of some found piece, researching through Papa's library guessing at stylistic affinities.

Still, Bruno was not interested in "fine things", or indeed in aesthetics per se - you could even accuse him of a slightly perverse anti-taste for exquisite goods and "luxuries" of all kinds. This meant he might not bother to get his heating fixed, but also that he preferred old objects, old clothes and old junk, as well as the sorts of places you were likely to find such things and the slightly foxed people who traded in them. Despite his own almost excessive good looks, he was at ease, seemingly for the first time in his life, in the Barcelona he found when he arrived in 1976 - a city full of people with one eye or a club foot, where little old black-clad Catholic ladies and flamboyant transvestites shared the same raffish boulevard, the Ramblas. A year after the death of Franco, Barcelona was unusually buoyant. Bruno trusted his talent as a painter, but also as a person on the street - everyone loved Bruno, especially the little old black-clad Catholic ladies. He was almost anachronistically gallant, the prince who danced with the wallflowers. But if his elaborate good manners and, above all, his openness - to ideas, to experience - meant that he struggled constantly against distraction, there was not much he could do about it. This is just the way he always was - long before the arrival of self-consciousness.

Covered every summer, year after year and from head to toe (even between his fingers, I seem to remember, even around his mouth) in putty-pink calamine lotion for all his intimate adventures with poison ivy, scarred at the knees as from an awful initiation, both for his amazed siblings and his anxious parents, Bruno was a child to watch. Bruno would walk into the sea and just keep going. Bruno would climb a tree always with the aim of getting to the highest branch.

When we played with blocks (and it does seem to be what we mainly did), my sister, Quina, and I, would, I'm afraid, lay out a perimeter of domestic spaces in which to enact our familial fantasies: Caio would build solid fortresses with thick ramparts; and inevitably Bruno would be standing on a chair, at work on a tower. Down it would tumble and he would start again. And again and again and again. Caio remembers Bruno's persistent attempts to construct an "upside-down Empire State Building".

Once, on a trip to the tropics with our grandparents, Bruno saved my life. I had drifted out to sea, and as the tide receded, I was being thrashed between two volcanic boulders, trapped and gulping seawater. I can still remember the sprung silhouettes of my grandmother and the babysitter frozen on the shore. And then there was Bruno, sprinting across the shallows, a 100-yard dash over a field of sea urchins, plucking me up and carrying me back. That evening, still on the beach, in yellow candlelight and a held-in-breath silence, local fishermen worked to burn the five o'clock shadow from the soles of Bruno's feet - the deeply embedded spines of dozens of sea urchins. What seemed like hours passed and Bruno didn't make a sound. He was 11 years old.

For Bruno the liberation of 1989 did not come in the form of communal enterprise but of a gathering in, a consolidation of many of his preoccupations, both painterly and personal. It was partly the events themselves - universal, we all love to imagine: David and Goliath, live in Eastern Europe - but it was also the immediacy and seeming intimacy with which they were brought to our attention, primarily by CNN. This dimension of participant observation, the way we were all somehow implicated - literally witnesses at an execution - interested Bruno as a painter. He found it allowed him a fresh way into the kind of great narrative painting he'd always loved: Paolo Uccello, Piero della Francesca, Tintoretto, Giovanni Battista Tiepolo - paintings but also recordings, also news. For Bruno, this kind of storytelling was utterly vivid. He had no difficulty, never did have any difficulty, with a translation of sensibilities between the centuries.

The War Murals - Bruno's four larger narrative paintings inspired by the anti-communist upheavals - represent his greatest synthesis of abstract and representational painting, something he had struggled for throughout his working life. And he put everything in. As a painter, as a witness, as a boulevardier (or Ramblista); as the boy who had endlessly copied versions of Christ's descent from the cross, as a young man under the shadow of a terminal disease; as a lifelong reader of Homer and Gibbon (and Nabokov and Camus); and as a passionate admirer of womankind. Visual inspiration also included photographs from other wars - boy soldiers torn from the pages of the International Herald Tribune (Sudan? Sierra Leone?) and tacked around the studio. These were selected for their universal theme but also for their hints about composition, their plastic qualities, their paintability.

When I say he put it all in I don't mean he didn't know what to leave out. Bruno put in all that was essential - as Einstein said, "Things should be as simple as possible but not any simpler" - and that is what gives this series its particular humanity and universality. To those who knew Bruno his achievement is the more impressive for seeming so unlikely - though not because of doubt about his talent. In contrast to the spectacular chaos of his days - the cluttered studio, the piled knots of his clothes, the troubled emotions, the ambitious, still-formulating ideas, the dozens of competing projects and demanding friends, the collective, haphazard approach to the treatment of his disease - despite all this, Bruno was an unusually direct and meticulous worker. Unlike my other painter brother, for example, whose patches of paint on ankle, wrist, hand and toe have become, indelibly, a part of his skin, Bruno was a clean painter. On Bruno a white shirt stayed white.

I said it doesn't surprise me that Bruno was importantly present at all the significant turns in my life. Perhaps this is the reason: he was uncommonly able to suppress the general chaos in favour of immediate concerns, whether of a friend in need or of a critical moment in a painting. He couldn't deal with airlines, fax machines or banks but, finally, he didn't need to. Unexpected only because of his legendary impracticality, his was a practical, and enviable, solution to the ever more pressing demands of life and work in the middle of our lives, at the end of our century.

The War Murals are important not just for their significance to Bruno's oeuvre. I think his intense preoccupation with these works over several years (and no other among his paintings had so protracted a parturition) gave him added impetus to fight the disease that was not only killing him but was also annoying and boring him almost beyond his ability to cope with it. Bruno had little talent as a patient; he had no knack for taking care of himself. He'd never had to. Always outrageously strong and healthy, muscled and lean and unacquainted with anything like an exercise regime, Bruno was a natural athlete who didn't need to train, the high school track star who only did it once a year, on field day. He should have died several times before he did. For example, over Christmas in Germany in 1992, when he had pneumonia and, though perhaps the most vulnerable person in all Schleswig-Holstein, he was kept in the infection ward of a small provincial hospital on the Baltic coast. He should have died there - not because he was the first Aids patient the hospital had ever seen and the first patient of any kind for the newly certified doctor who alone was willing to treat him (by correspondence with a hospital in Hamburg). Bruno should have died that Christmas in Germany because in those early days, as Aids became a reality for Bruno and Anke, the terrified twosome refused all medication ("There is no guarantee," a panicky Anke reasoned, that the antibiotics for the pneumonia wouldn't have "side effects").

Eventually Caio and I and then, crucially, our mother flew to Germany to bring Bruno home. But we couldn't bring him home. For several days Bruno did not even allow us to visit him (there was, indeed, "no guarantee" that we didn't want to brainwash him with "Western medical propaganda"). And so we waited in the hospital cafeteria with its tilting artificial Christmas tree and its slow-flickering multicoloured Christmas lights and listened to the booming artillery fire which signalled the start of New Year celebrations. When Mom joined us and went in to see Bruno, I stood in the doorway behind her. The look on Bruno's face - a look of fear and bewilderment subsiding into exhausted relief - is one that I have seen again only on the face of my own child, on being gathered up from a nightmare. But even our mother was subjected to the fearful exclusionary policy of Bruno and Anke. And so we all waited.

Mom filled the time trying to find acceptable ways to make Bruno more comfortable. For example, she decided Bruno should have apple sauce; Bruno loved apple sauce. But the stuff we found had to be doctored: we had to get some cinnamon. The three of us went around that hateful harbour town in the dead of winter, bent in hysterical, tearful laughter, trying with our nonexistent German to extract cinnamon from stout kiosk vendors. Caio came up with "braun Pulver, gut mit Apfelmus", and after he'd said this all three of us would start chanting all the other words for cinnamon we could think of: "canelle, canella, scortisoara, cinnamon, cinnamon, CINNAMON". "Zimt?" one appalled kiosk lady replied. "Yah, Zimt," we figured. And so Bruno got his Apfelmus mit Zimt. But mostly we sat in the cafeteria, watching his window across the frozen courtyard, waiting for a sign.

And finally, on one of those days of mainly silent waiting (the happiest moment of my life, I sometimes think), Bruno himself appeared in the cafeteria, an apparition in a huge blue overcoat. He looked almost fine. The gesture (or did I dream it?) cost him a few extra days in bed, but as it happened there were no beds free in New York City. And so we waited some more. There were no beds and there were no seats, not for someone as sick as Bruno. Lufthansa wouldn't fly him. Or not until our mother "explained", in the tone of the mother of a very sick child (an international language): "My son will not die in Germany!"

Eventually Bruno did fly home with Jost, the young doctor, by his side as well as Anke (preoccupied that her entire suitcase of homeopathetic unguents and oils had lost all their "information" when airport security insisted that she put them through the X-ray machine). And he got better, and he went back to work. The War Murals were executed mainly in the period that followed this episode.

Over the next two years, in different hospitals and under different doctors, there were similar crises and reprieves, with the expectation of death at any time. Despite the general hopelessness, we felt incredibly lucky to have found Dr Joseph Sonnabend, a pioneering research doctor who understood Bruno, who seemed more like a sculptor than a doctor, and who became and remained a friend of the whole family, including Anke, with whom he could play Bach duets - his piano to her flute: the best medicine for his reluctant patient.

Bruno was rightly sceptical of the treatments then on offer (much of what he was fed would be unthinkable now) but he, at least, was never fatalistic. In his final push to fight the disease - which at that point, in late 1993, was represented by an egg-size brain tumour pressing excruciatingly against his skull - there was defeat in the air, at home, on the wards. Bruno was "failing" and it seemed far from clear even to Sonnabend that the violent treatment was worth any brief reprieve. But Bruno again submitted, trudging down the street each day for six weeks from the house where we grew up to St Vincent's Hospital and what he called his "X-ray class" - the radiation treatment for the tumour. He got better - the egg became an acorn, and he went back to Barcelona and said goodbye to his life there. Above all, he put back on the agenda an exhibition of The War Murals in New York.

Early in 1994, these four pictures were at the centre of a show that launched the John McEnroe Gallery in Soho. It was the first time the paintings had been publicly displayed, and no one was more excited than Gonzalo Fonseca, Papa. Most people, when posed the idle question of what death they would have - Mack truck or slow, disfiguring disease? - perfunctorily go for the Mack truck. But in addition to the rapprochement of father and first son, Bruno's drawn-out death involved our family in an extraordinary drama of compressed living.

I have already said that one of Bruno's gifts was his irresistible good influence, and it is the best possible light you can put on his awful death that again he pulled us together as a family and at the same time brought out the best in each of us.

During his final five weeks we were all together for the last time as a family. Together again in the childhood place, in the house called The Big House, the house that had belonged to our grandparents, beloved and now both dead, too. There, in the tight formation of our relatively small family (without the additional childhood voices of many cousins and aunts and uncles and friends), we fell into what felt like our natural roles. Bruno was installed in a downstairs bedroom off the dining room - gloomy, shuttered, wood-panelled, library-like - with the bed facing a big fireplace over which hung, a strange, primitive painting on wood of an aerial view, or plan, of Dartmoor Prison. Tacked on the wall above his bed (who put it there?) was a postcard of Donatello's exquisite wooden John the Baptist whom Bruno, with his sallow skin and his beautiful bald head, now closely resembled. Papa sat through each day, cross-legged or cross-ankled, keeping a vigil by Bruno's bed or sometimes outside his door, reading the New York Times, the entire section neatly folded down to one fourth or even one eighth of the broadsheet whole. Our stepfather, Dick Cornuelle, showed his solidarity mainly by hanging back, even though he was in many ways closer to Bruno, and to all of us, than our real father. When she wasn't preparing yet another delicious meal ("It's just as easy to cook a good dinner as a bad one," she protested when we protested), my mother was usually at Bruno's bedside as well, drawing. Her sketches of her dying boy are among the most moving and perceptive portraits I've ever seen. Caio, the brother who more than anyone had shared Bruno's whole life: their room with its stacked beds, their life together as students in Spain and later as colleagues bound, and isolated, by their unique training - Caio stood by, mostly speechless. Speechless, particularly after Bruno lost the ability to speak. But their communication didn't depend on words.

Quina and I fell into an easy division of nursely duties - washing and changing and rolling over our heavy brother; soothing and smoothing and rearranging his pillows, protecting him against too many visitors, or visitors staying too long. Quina constantly reset the whirring pump that kept Bruno hydrated, manned the tubes, and cleaned inflamed punctures in his arm. I found, when Bruno started having seizures, that I could unsqueamishly give him shots of phenobarbital in the buttocks (Dr Sonnabend told me where and how over the phone) and, later, doses of morphine. I read a lot to Bruno, as did others. Kafka's A Hunger Artist was good almost too good - or, along with The Metamorphosis, too apposite. We got through most of Mary Renault's Persian Boy, which was terrible, but perfect in the way it transported Bruno, who was only intermittently listening anyway, back into the world of the ancients.

Anke was just there, which, as Bruno's yellow-haired muse, was precisely her job and she became closer to me, which I think Bruno noticed and which would have pleased him. And, as one treatment after another failed, as we realised that no one had the information that could save Bruno, we all moved closer to Anke. Bruno's last words to me came about a week before he died, while she and I sat on his bed. "You look so much alike," he said. We don't, but perhaps what he saw was what a long way we had come from that German Christmas of "no guarantee" to our sharing of my grandmother's huge double bed, listening through the night to Bruno's breathing on the baby monitor. This was the last time in that place of the calamine lotion and the Big Lawn and the enormous trees - copper beech and elm, each with its one, famous "highest branch". This was the last time our family sat down together at that 15ft dark wood table in the brilliant blue dining room, and we were all painfully, unhungrily conscious of the confinement, a testing mix of nostalgia and claustrophobia. One morning, Papa tried to escape to the city and came back by bus the very same day.

The last night, when Bruno was clearly dying - his skin colour and skin smell changed as his organs began to fail; his breathing had begun to climb in slow crescendos - we were all hovering in his room. And then, for no particular reason, everyone filed out. Everyone except Papa. And that is when Bruno died.

Days later, the funeral parlour returned his ashes, or "cremains", as they insisted on calling them. They arrived in a shiny little shopping bag, as if from a smart shoe store. Inside was a small parcel, about the size of a five-pound bag of flour and just as densely packed, wrapped in newspaper (the funnies, no less). For the hell of it we put it, or him, on the kitchen scales: six pounds four ounces, his birth weight exactly.

In a pink twilight we scattered his ashes from the jetty of what we called the Pink Beach. It was the same beach where, as children, we had laboured passionately under our father's expert command; ferrying buckets of water and wet sand, carefully cutting crusty sand slabs, we built with him the most fantastic, sepulchral sandcastles, in the mood and (we imagined) on the scale of the Egyptians. It was the last time for us as that family in that house. The Big House is now the regional headquarters of the Nature Conservancy in the South Fork.

Six months or so after Bruno's death, Mom and I returned to his vast studio in Barcelona to begin, with Anke, to go through his things and specifically to identify whatever work we might find: paintings, sculpture, notebooks, drawings, wooden pieces, models for monuments. We didn't necessarily want to take it away (take, it where?). We didn't really want to touch his world. We might have left it as a kind of diorama of a vanished life. But we also wanted to climb into the display (which extended to Bruno's immediate neighbourhood), to be with him, to be with all the him there was ever going to be.

Around that time our mother decided, comically, that Bruno was not dead after all. "He's just in Barcelona." She would say. "I never saw him anyway. He's just in Barcelona." Like everyone else in the family, Bruno was a hoarder. Whatever hadn't been lost in the street would be here, five floors up a steeply coiled staircase, many of the treads completely worn away to reveal the vertigo-inducing caracole elevation below. One category of Brunoiana that I had expected to find, and did find in wholesale quantities, was his letters: written in a romantic, looping, leaning, hard-to-read 19th-century hand, each one customised (and therefore made uniformly, unmistakably, instantly recognisable as his product) with endless figures and doodles in the margins. Most were unfinished and without any apparent intention of being sent to the addressee. These letters were really a place to try out ideas, to weigh the escapades of the heart, no different from letters written to oneself (indeed there are some in Bruno's notebooks frankly addressed, "Dear Notebook" or "Dear Letter").
