fields.bodyText: December 25, 1989. We sat on tall stools at a bar with no name, "Bruno's local", downstairs from his studio on the corner of calle Reina Amalia in Barcelona's Barrio Chino, the red-light district. Along with everyone else in the place - a handful of souls brought together by their loose-endedness that Christmas Day - Bruno and I stared up at the wall-mounted black-and-white TV, riveted by an incredible transmission: the execution of Elena and Nicolae Ceausescu, here played out to the surreally corny soundtrack of Feliz Navidad, sung by children and blaring from some scratchy PA system in the street. The bar is now closed - indeed, it has been walled up with cement blocks. Gone too, of course, is the incandescent pulse of possibility belonging to those amazing days of upheaval. But for Bruno and for me - both of us in every sense far from the action of our peers in Eastern Europe - something of that possibility remained, and propelled each of us into our own discoveries. It doesn't seem even vaguely surprising that most of the moments in my life that have emerged as "significant" were witnessed, influenced, or even engineered by Bruno Fonseca, my older brother. For me, those days in Barcelona turned out to be the beginning of a five-year journey among the Gypsies of Eastern Europe (and by the end of that five-year journey Bruno would be dead). But Bruno had more to do with my launch than did the Ceausescus or the students of Bucharest's University Square. I'd long wanted to quit my job and travel to convulsing Eastern Europe (from which during earlier convulsions, some of our family had emigrated). But I was scared. I was interested in Gypsies and fluent on such topics as minorities and democracies, exclusion and deracination; the uses of exoticism; the outsider in the European imagination . . . But Bruno was more fluent. "If you're interested in Gypsies," he put to me that night, "don't you think we'd better go and meet some?" And so we did. Somehow (and somehow of course) Bruno knew about a group of Gitnos camped at Gava Playa, a beach just outside of Barcelona's city limits. We set out for the camp one evening, just a few days after the executions. For that night on the beach, I would have worn something "neutral", that is something "poor". But Bruno, with his superior instincts, chose his most elegant garment (his only elegant garment), an enormous dark blue cashmere overcoat and he wore it loose, hanging from his broad coathanger shoulders. Down in the street he bought and stashed under his arms a couple of bottles of Ballantine whisky and a carton of cigarettes. He also happened to have in his inner pocket a deck of cards, but our most important provision was the ready supply of Bruno's emollient, inimitably casual charm, the perfect antidote to my own rather worried and earnest presence. Bruno had a belief that you had to "walk into your fears". (As a teenager his unfortunate motto was "Try anything at least once".) Walk into your fears: now this was hard to do. Not for the usual reasons but, at least for his little sister, because it was just impossible to be afraid in his company. Fear didn't come up. Ethical considerations, yes, always: Should we be even doing this? What is our real motive? If anything Bruno was unduly freighted with such concerns (often working them out, pros and cons, in endless lists). But he rarely paused over his own safety. Here again his instincts were uncommon and, at least this time, they were also right. We spent most of the night with those Gypsies by their fire. Though wary at first, they very soon took their cue from us: the tone was good, the night was fine, the mood was gay. Over the next five years I went on my own to dozens of Gypsy camps, many much rougher than the one at Gava Playa. But after that night, and I believe, because of it, I never again was distracted by considerations of fear - nor did I ever meet with any real danger. "Death can be useful," he wrote, "because we inherit the virtues of those we love." Despite Bruno's obvious handicaps (severe dyslexia, staggering disorganisation) he had more than his share of virtues. Prominent among these were his hopeful instincts and his irresistible good influence, including his generosity. He was generous with his money and his time. But Bruno also had a more unusual virtue, that of full empathy. Even as an adolescent, when most of us are particularly, even rightfully solipsistic, Bruno was able to step into your shoes with your feet - that is, to imagine not what was right for you but what was right from your point of view (seldom the same thing). Imaginative sympathy continued to be his first reaction to any difficulty. The difficulty, say, of beginning a life with someone when you are dying (Shakespeare might have written for Bruno the sonnet which reminds us that "love is not love which alters when it alteration finds"). He should have died there - not because he was the first Aids patient the hospital had ever seen and the first patient of any kind for the newly certified doctor who alone was willing to treat him (by correspondence with a hospital in Hamburg). Bruno should have died that Christmas in Germany because in those early days, as Aids became a reality for Bruno and Anke, the terrified twosome refused all medication ("There is no guarantee," a panicky Anke reasoned, that the antibiotics for the pneumonia wouldn't have "side effects"). Eventually Caio and I and then, crucially, our mother flew to Germany to bring Bruno home. But we couldn't bring him home. For several days Bruno did not even allow us to visit him (there was, indeed, "no guarantee" that we didn't want to brainwash him with "Western medical propaganda"). And so we waited in the hospital cafeteria with its tilting artificial Christmas tree and its slow-flickering multicoloured Christmas lights and listened to the booming artillery fire which signalled the start of New Year celebrations. When Mom joined us and went in to see Bruno, I stood in the doorway behind her. The look on Bruno's face - a look of fear and bewilderment subsiding into exhausted relief - is one that I have seen again only on the face of my own child, on being gathered up from a nightmare. But even our mother was subjected to the fearful exclusionary policy of Bruno and Anke. And so we all waited. Mom filled the time trying to find acceptable ways to make Bruno more comfortable. For example, she decided Bruno should have apple sauce; Bruno loved apple sauce. But the stuff we found had to be doctored: we had to get some cinnamon. The three of us went around that hateful harbour town in the dead of winter, bent in hysterical, tearful laughter, trying with our nonexistent German to extract cinnamon from stout kiosk vendors. Caio came up with "braun Pulver, gut mit Apfelmus", and after he'd said this all three of us would start chanting all the other words for cinnamon we could think of: "canelle, canella, scortisoara, cinnamon, cinnamon, CINNAMON". "Zimt?" one appalled kiosk lady replied. "Yah, Zimt," we figured. And so Bruno got his Apfelmus mit Zimt. But mostly we sat in the cafeteria, watching his window across the frozen courtyard, waiting for a sign. And finally, on one of those days of mainly silent waiting (the happiest moment of my life, I sometimes think), Bruno himself appeared in the cafeteria, an apparition in a huge blue overcoat. He looked almost fine. The gesture (or did I dream it?) cost him a few extra days in bed, but as it happened there were no beds free in New York City. And so we waited some more. There were no beds and there were no seats, not for someone as sick as Bruno. Lufthansa wouldn't fly him. Or not until our mother "explained", in the tone of the mother of a very sick child (an international language): "My son will not die in Germany!" Eventually Bruno did fly home with Jost, the young doctor, by his side as well as Anke (preoccupied that her entire suitcase of homeopathetic unguents and oils had lost all their "information" when airport security insisted that she put them through the X-ray machine). And he got better, and he went back to work. The War Murals were executed mainly in the period that followed this episode. Over the next two years, in different hospitals and under different doctors, there were similar crises and reprieves, with the expectation of death at any time. Despite the general hopelessness, we felt incredibly lucky to have found Dr Joseph Sonnabend, a pioneering research doctor who understood Bruno, who seemed more like a sculptor than a doctor, and who became and remained a friend of the whole family, including Anke, with whom he could play Bach duets - his piano to her flute: the best medicine for his reluctant patient. Bruno was rightly sceptical of the treatments then on offer (much of what he was fed would be unthinkable now) but he, at least, was never fatalistic. In his final push to fight the disease - which at that point, in late 1993, was represented by an egg-size brain tumour pressing excruciatingly against his skull - there was defeat in the air, at home, on the wards. Bruno was "failing" and it seemed far from clear even to Sonnabend that the violent treatment was worth any brief reprieve. But Bruno again submitted, trudging down the street each day for six weeks from the house where we grew up to St Vincent's Hospital and what he called his "X-ray class" - the radiation treatment for the tumour. He got better - the egg became an acorn, and he went back to Barcelona and said goodbye to his life there. Above all, he put back on the agenda an exhibition of The War Murals in New York. Early in 1994, these four pictures were at the centre of a show that launched the John McEnroe Gallery in Soho. It was the first time the paintings had been publicly displayed, and no one was more excited than Gonzalo Fonseca, Papa. Most people, when posed the idle question of what death they would have - Mack truck or slow, disfiguring disease? - perfunctorily go for the Mack truck. But in addition to the rapprochement of father and first son, Bruno's drawn-out death involved our family in an extraordinary drama of compressed living. I have already said that one of Bruno's gifts was his irresistible good influence, and it is the best possible light you can put on his awful death that again he pulled us together as a family and at the same time brought out the best in each of us. During his final five weeks we were all together for the last time as a family. Together again in the childhood place, in the house called The Big House, the house that had belonged to our grandparents, beloved and now both dead, too. There, in the tight formation of our relatively small family (without the additional childhood voices of many cousins and aunts and uncles and friends), we fell into what felt like our natural roles. Bruno was installed in a downstairs bedroom off the dining room - gloomy, shuttered, wood-panelled, library-like - with the bed facing a big fireplace over which hung, a strange, primitive painting on wood of an aerial view, or plan, of Dartmoor Prison. Tacked on the wall above his bed (who put it there?) was a postcard of Donatello's exquisite wooden John the Baptist whom Bruno, with his sallow skin and his beautiful bald head, now closely resembled. Papa sat through each day, cross-legged or cross-ankled, keeping a vigil by Bruno's bed or sometimes outside his door, reading the New York Times, the entire section neatly folded down to one fourth or even one eighth of the broadsheet whole. Our stepfather, Dick Cornuelle, showed his solidarity mainly by hanging back, even though he was in many ways closer to Bruno, and to all of us, than our real father. When she wasn't preparing yet another delicious meal ("It's just as easy to cook a good dinner as a bad one," she protested when we protested), my mother was usually at Bruno's bedside as well, drawing. Her sketches of her dying boy are among the most moving and perceptive portraits I've ever seen. Caio, the brother who more than anyone had shared Bruno's whole life: their room with its stacked beds, their life together as students in Spain and later as colleagues bound, and isolated, by their unique training - Caio stood by, mostly speechless. Speechless, particularly after Bruno lost the ability to speak. But their communication didn't depend on words. Quina and I fell into an easy division of nursely duties - washing and changing and rolling over our heavy brother; soothing and smoothing and rearranging his pillows, protecting him against too many visitors, or visitors staying too long. Quina constantly reset the whirring pump that kept Bruno hydrated, manned the tubes, and cleaned inflamed punctures in his arm. I found, when Bruno started having seizures, that I could unsqueamishly give him shots of phenobarbital in the buttocks (Dr Sonnabend told me where and how over the phone) and, later, doses of morphine. I read a lot to Bruno, as did others. Kafka's A Hunger Artist was good almost too good - or, along with The Metamorphosis, too apposite. We got through most of Mary Renault's Persian Boy, which was terrible, but perfect in the way it transported Bruno, who was only intermittently listening anyway, back into the world of the ancients. Anke was just there, which, as Bruno's yellow-haired muse, was precisely her job and she became closer to me, which I think Bruno noticed and which would have pleased him. And, as one treatment after another failed, as we realised that no one had the information that could save Bruno, we all moved closer to Anke. Bruno's last words to me came about a week before he died, while she and I sat on his bed. "You look so much alike," he said. We don't, but perhaps what he saw was what a long way we had come from that German Christmas of "no guarantee" to our sharing of my grandmother's huge double bed, listening through the night to Bruno's breathing on the baby monitor. This was the last time in that place of the calamine lotion and the Big Lawn and the enormous trees - copper beech and elm, each with its one, famous "highest branch". This was the last time our family sat down together at that 15ft dark wood table in the brilliant blue dining room, and we were all painfully, unhungrily conscious of the confinement, a testing mix of nostalgia and claustrophobia. One morning, Papa tried to escape to the city and came back by bus the very same day. The last night, when Bruno was clearly dying - his skin colour and skin smell changed as his organs began to fail; his breathing had begun to climb in slow crescendos - we were all hovering in his room. And then, for no particular reason, everyone filed out. Everyone except Papa. And that is when Bruno died. Days later, the funeral parlour returned his ashes, or "cremains", as they insisted on calling them. They arrived in a shiny little shopping bag, as if from a smart shoe store. Inside was a small parcel, about the size of a five-pound bag of flour and just as densely packed, wrapped in newspaper (the funnies, no less). For the hell of it we put it, or him, on the kitchen scales: six pounds four ounces, his birth weight exactly. In a pink twilight we scattered his ashes from the jetty of what we called the Pink Beach. It was the same beach where, as children, we had laboured passionately under our father's expert command; ferrying buckets of water and wet sand, carefully cutting crusty sand slabs, we built with him the most fantastic, sepulchral sandcastles, in the mood and (we imagined) on the scale of the Egyptians. It was the last time for us as that family in that house. The Big House is now the regional headquarters of the Nature Conservancy in the South Fork. Six months or so after Bruno's death, Mom and I returned to his vast studio in Barcelona to begin, with Anke, to go through his things and specifically to identify whatever work we might find: paintings, sculpture, notebooks, drawings, wooden pieces, models for monuments. We didn't necessarily want to take it away (take, it where?). We didn't really want to touch his world. We might have left it as a kind of diorama of a vanished life. But we also wanted to climb into the display (which extended to Bruno's immediate neighbourhood), to be with him, to be with all the him there was ever going to be. Around that time our mother decided, comically, that Bruno was not dead after all. "He's just in Barcelona." She would say. "I never saw him anyway. He's just in Barcelona." Like everyone else in the family, Bruno was a hoarder. Whatever hadn't been lost in the street would be here, five floors up a steeply coiled staircase, many of the treads completely worn away to reveal the vertigo-inducing caracole elevation below. One category of Brunoiana that I had expected to find, and did find in wholesale quantities, was his letters: written in a romantic, looping, leaning, hard-to-read 19th-century hand, each one customised (and therefore made uniformly, unmistakably, instantly recognisable as his product) with endless figures and doodles in the margins. Most were unfinished and without any apparent intention of being sent to the addressee. These letters were really a place to try out ideas, to weigh the escapades of the heart, no different from letters written to oneself (indeed there are some in Bruno's notebooks frankly addressed, "Dear Notebook" or "Dear Letter"). Read the second part of Dear Brother here

webTitle: Isabel Fonesca on her brother Bruno (part 2)

fields.headline: Dear Brother (part 2)
fields.body:
Bruno did also send many letters (he hated the phone and tended to shout into it as if he had actually to project his voice long distance). His letters were eloquent, badly misspelled, sometimes stream-of-consciousness documents covering dozens of pages. Occasionally you would receive in an envelope an entire (usually very small) notepad, inscribed to you from start to finish. Letters to me were often posted in England (where I live) by someone he chanced to meet: perhaps a sailor on his way home, as if Bruno were stranded in a remote outpost of the Empire and had to avail himself of a passing traveller. We found numerous decks of cards - old-fashioned souvenir decks from minor Spanish resorts. Bruno was terrific at card tricks, a skill he developed around 13 or 14 to offset his adolescent stuttering. Perhaps these decks were just attractively packaged symbols of leisure for someone incapable of taking a vacation. They also had a vaguely occult resonance, which would have appealed to him Scattered throughout the studio there was also a distressing amount of medical detritus: notes taken in front of doctors, documents from the local clinic, requests for samples, reminders in three languages (German, Spanish, English) about tests, books, newsletters (from Heal, from BodyPositive), notices of meetings of "support groups" (outside of family and a few friends Bruno never did find his natural support group). There were heaps of boxes, bottles, vials, loose pills.

Inside one of his great junk trunks I found a dozen enormous Manila envelopes containing the slides of his MRIs and CAT scans. I pulled a couple of the wobbly negatives halfway out of the first envelope to have a look at Bruno's head. Instantly I saw it was not Bruno: the wrong-shaped head, a round head, not a long head. I looked at the small typed lines of information above the pictures, and sure enough these slides were not of Bruno but of one Jose Lopez Merino. So who was he? Or who is he? Is he dead or alive? Did he have Aids, too? Or were his negatives negative? Was he a friend of Bruno's? An important friend? Does he have a message for me? Or were his MRIs accidentally mixed in with Bruno's by a sleepy technician at the Centre Mèdic de Ressonància Magnètica on Monestir, 3, Barcelona 08034?

Among all that was uniquely and familiarly Bruno in the rubble of his habitat of nearly 20 years, there was one important surprise: the extraordinary quantity of work. No one knew - certainly he had no idea. Bruno was always so fretful about not working, so ready to be distracted, maybe already down at the cafe, working on his second cafe con leche, bien caliente. Bruno always carried a notebook (tucked into the waistband of his trousers at the back) and he left them everywhere. He must have lost hundreds, and still we found over a hundred. Rolls and rolls of paintings. Racks and racks of paintings (as well as paintings caught under boxes, stuffed behind doors, squashed into cupboards). The person I most urgently wanted to share this information with was Bruno. He had really seemed not to know it - he was so hard on himself, as stern as he was gentle and forgiving with everyone else.

Bruno had just turned 36 when he died (though he tried to stretch it out, to make it sound like a respectable age to die, "I'm nearly 40, you know"). Despite the diagnosis, he was of course only ever looking forward. It was impossible to do otherwise. Except for little stabs at it in his letters to himself, there had been no taking stock, no serious making of inventories, no retrospectives - though Bruno always seemed convinced he had achieved nothing. Work was unquestionably the thing that mattered most to Bruno, and he was ambitious enough to think mainly in terms of immortality, that is, of the pantheon of true colleagues, beyond the transient cafe of his peer group. But if he didn't realise how much work he had done, and much more importantly, how very good it mostly was, how well did he know himself? This is the central sadness of an early death: not just the time lost to make, but the time lost to acknowledge, to grasp that making.

I think the dead would want us
To weep for what they have lost.
I think our luck in continuing
Is what would affect them most.
But time would find them generous
And less self-engrossed.
And time would find them generous
As they used to be
And what else would they want from us
But an honoured place in our memory,
A favourite room, a hallowed chair,
Privilege and celebrity?
And so the dead might cease to grieve
And we might make amends
And there might be a pact between
Dead friends and living friends.
What our dead friends would want from us
Would be such living friends.

James Fenton, from For Andrew Wood

I have taped to the large glass doors of the room where I work, some of the actual MRIs of Bruno's head, taken at the time of his brain tumour. They are familiar and strange. They are medical. Some of the black-and-white negatives are of the skull seen from above: the generic; neatly bifurcated walnut-shaped brain-squiggly white stuff encased in a bone egg. Others are taken in profile and evenly sliced in all directions. I would recognise that silhouette if I saw it for a split second on an escalator passing in the opposite direction. I know his head as I know my child's, I know it better than I know my own.

But I don't know what those slices mean. I don't really know about the shadows and the cartoon concavities, about the Spiderman eye sockets with their thick perimeter of white (what is that? Is it normal?). You can really see the whitish smudge of the tumour, but what is all that grey matter we talk about it as if it were fabric, like the material of Anke's wedding dress, something we can see and describe and have a sense of, an opinion about either way. What is all that stuff beneath the familiar lip of his brow, a brow just like my own? Looking now at these MRIs, thinking back on that revelational first sampling of those stacks and stacks of paintings in Barcelona, I can't help thinking, who was he? He was the closest person to me and how well did I know him?

This is of course the recognition that the work is not the same as the person, which sounds obvious but feels startling. We went to Barcelona because we wanted to be with all the Bruno there was ever going to be. It took me the next five years to accept that this was in fact another, and more awesome, him altogether. A second recognition came a little quicker: that the work was also the best of Bruno, the most "him" of him. This is true for every artist. It is this discovery that now accompanies Bruno, or rather his work, out into the world. Which is also to say that nothing of his biography matters at all. When after several years of agony and illness and the unwelcome and exhausting reckonings that were the bitterest of the many pills he had to swallow, Bruno died, my first thought was (as no doubt it was for so many others in the mythical support group), "He's free." The same now seems freshly and unequivocally true of his work, separated, finally from its maker

Extracted from Bruno Fonesca: The Secret Life of Painting by Alan Jenkins, Karen Wilkin and Isabel Fonseca.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: The Derwent was in angry mood as we came down from the flank of Bamford Edge the other day. No glimmer of sunshine, no ladder-like sunbeams raked the sullen cloud curtain: even so, the riotous colours of the riverside trees took our breath away. The deep canopy of beech and ash overhanging the lower part of Lees-side Road (the steepest public road in the Peak District) threw heavy shades from its dull bronze-and-gold overhangs as we came down to the village. A few minutes later we came to the river's edge at the great textile mill built by Christopher Kirk in 1780 and destroyed by fire 11 years later. It was rebuilt and continued in use until comparatively recently The straight weir still directs some of the Derwent under the building that no longer resounds to the clack of spinning frame The great stone edifice now reclines in the comparative silence of luxury apartments.
fields.body:
The Derwent was in angry mood as we came down from the flank of Bamford Edge the other day. No glimmer of sunshine, no ladder-like sunbeams raked the sullen cloud curtain: even so, the riotous colours of the riverside trees took our breath away. The deep canopy of beech and ash overhanging the lower part of Lees-side Road (the steepest public road in the Peak District) threw heavy shades from its dull bronze-and-gold overhangs as we came down to the village. A few minutes later we came to the river's edge at the great textile mill built by Christopher Kirk in 1780 and destroyed by fire 11 years later. It was rebuilt and continued in use until comparatively recently The straight weir still directs some of the Derwent under the building that no longer resounds to the clack of spinning frame The great stone edifice now reclines in the comparative silence of luxury apartments.

The river was certainly high; it defied our attempts to get over the stepping stones below the weir, so we detoured downstream, to cross by the bridge leading to the former headquarters of the Derwent Valley Water Board. Here, beside the dark gritstone facade of this former administrative building reached the abandoned track of the railway built to deliver one and a quarter million tons of stone for the construction of Howden and Derwent Dams between 1901 and 1916. When the job was finished the track was lifted and taken to the Western Front to help with troop movements for a couple of years. Nowadays the trackbed makes a useful footpath along the eastern foot of Win Hill.

As we traversed Thornhill Carrs, high above Yorkshire Bridge, a break in the cloud canopy heralded improving weather; and by the time we crossed Win Hill Pike only streaky vapours hid the sun. Suddenly they, too, blew away and we spent the rest of the day in glorious autumn sunshine. Up here on the summit of this popular Peakland hill there's a tremendous view towards the north, straight up Derwent Dale. Down below is the newly refurbished Ashopton Viaduct spanning one of the arms of Ladybower Reservoir. The refurbishment of this bridge (and its shorter brother spanning Ladybower Cough) has recently been shortlised in the British Construction Industry Awards 2000. Beyond that the reservoir arm would up the dale, fringed with the green and gold and bronze of mixed plantations. Derwent Edge lifted clear as a bell beyond them, to the cloudless sky.

webTitle: Cliffhanger at the top of the world

fields.headline: Cliffhanger at the top of the world
fields.standfirst: In 1865 Edward Whymper led the first team to conquer the Matterhorn but, Fergus Fleming writes, the triumph soon turned to tragedy and the disaster was to haunt him for the rest of his life
fields.trailText: n 1865 Edward Whymper led the first team to conquer the Matterhorn but, Fergus Fleming writes, the triumph soon turned to tragedy and the disaster was to haunt him for the rest of his life
fields.body:
In the 16th century the Alps were as distant from the normal world as was the moon. To many they represented hell, combing the freezing conditions of a Nordic Niflheim , the Nordic mythological underworld, with, in summer, the roasting inferno of Christianity. Here was a realm whose upper reaches were, by all accounts, home to a race of malformed and malevolent sub-humans. The peaks above were inhabited by demons and witches were well attested. Croz, an experienced guide, and Young Peter Taugwalder scouted ahead and returned with the news that there was "not a difficulty, not a single difficulty!... We could have gone to the summit and returned today easily!" Everybody went to bed in good spirits. The next day Whymper handed the lead to Croz. Croz joined him and together they wrestled lumps of crag down the cliff. Whymper crowed: "The Italians turned and fled."

Then came the flag-planting. One of the tent poles had been removed that morning - against Whymper's protestation that they were tempting providence - and it was now embedded on the northern end of the ridge with Croz's shirt tied to it as a flag. It was visible from all directions.

Around 3pm on July 14, Hudson and Whymper agreed on their order of descent. While they were roping up, Whymper spent a last few minutes sketching the summit and then, darting back up to put their names in a bottle, he took his place in the chain. The adrenalin which had carried them to the top was gone, leaving them shaky-legged and exhausted. They took exaggerated care on the rocks they had bounded up so eagerly that morning. Hadow, who was the weariest of them all, had his feet guided into position by Croz. Their precautions were standard practice for any well guided party coming home after a new conquest, save for one important difference - although the leaders were tied to one of the stronger ropes, Old Peter and Douglas were linked by the weakest of the lot.

Croz put his axe to one side so that he could assist Hadow on a tricky slope. What occurred next could only be guessed at. Whymper's theory was that Croz had helped Hadow into a safe position and had then turned round to pick up his ice axe. As he did so, Hadow slipped and knocked Croz over. Whymper did not see it happen, his view being blocked momentarily by a rock, but he witnessed every moment of the subsequent tragedy.

"I heard one startled exclamation from Croz, then saw him and Mr Hadow flying downwards; in another moment Hudson was dragged from his steps, and Lord F Douglas immediately after him. All this was the work of a moment. Immediately we heard Croz's exclamation, Old Peter and I planted ourselves as firmly as the rocks would permit: the rope was taut between us and the jerk came on us both as one man. We held; but the rope broke midway between Taugwalder and Lord Francis Douglas. For a few seconds, we saw our unfortunate companions sliding downwards on their backs, and spread ing out their hands, endeavouring to save themselves. They passed from our sight uninjured, disappeared one by one, and fell from precipice to precipice on to the Matterhorngletscher below, a distance of nearly 4,000 feet. Whymper and the two Taugwalders did not move for half an hour. Old Peter burst into tears. Young Peter cried, "We are lost! We are lost!" With difficulty Whymper persuaded Young Peter to leave his perch - they were still roped together and unless he moved they were stuck - then guided father and son back to Zermatt. They went down slowly and carefully, searching for their companions' bodies as they went, sometimes calling out in the vain hope that one of them might have survived. Whymper later wrote to a friend. "For two hours after the accident I thought every moment that the next would be my last... the two guides were unnerved to such an extent that I suspected every minute one or the other would have slipped, and then it would have been all over."

At 9.30pm, Whymper chose "a wretched slab, barely large enough to hold the three", on which to spend the night. Six hours later there was enough moonlight for them to continue the descent. They went down in silence, met the first chalets, and then ran all the way to Zermatt. Whymper burst into the Monte Rosa hotel and made for his room, pursued by an inquisitive landlord. As he closed the door he announced "The Taugwalders and I have returned."

The landlord roused the village and 20 men went on their way to the base of the north face. When they reached the scene they found Croz and Hadow lying next to each other on the snow, with Hudson some 50 yards distant. The bodies had been stripped almost naked during the fall and were so battered that they were barely recognisable - Croz was missing the top half of his head and was identified only by his beard and by a rosary cross. Of Douglas there was no trace, save a pair of gloves, a belt and a boot. His body had either caught on a ledge or had been shredded as it bounced from rock to rock. Apart from a single coat sleeve, nothing more was ever found of him.

The news broke slowly, inaccurately and piecemeal. Whymper wrote a description of the tragedy in the visitors' book of the Monte Rosa, which was stolen almost immediately, but it was August 8 before he published a definitive account in the Times. Until then, wild rumours circulated that made Zermatt, briefly, the most famous place in Europe. Climbers from every nation rushed to the village, impelled by the desire to help, to offer condolences or simply to gawp.

On July 19, the British consul in Geneva sent his chaplain to conduct a private inquiry and on July 21, Zermatt opened its own inquest. Midway through its deliberations, a wrenchingly ignorant telegram arrived from Douglas's mother, Lady Queensbury: "Is it not possible to seek in the rocks above or to let down food?"

Meanwhile, Whymper was giving his deposition to the local court. He told everything as it had happened and blamed the fall entirely on the use of the weak rope. Looking at the piece he had retained as evidence, the officials accepted his deposition without question. It was flimsy beyond belief and had clearly snapped. (Sections of all three ropes are preserved in Zermatt's Alpine museum. The one that broke is little thicker than a washing line.) The verdict was accidental death.

What was not explained (or asked), however, was why the weak rope had been used in the first place. "We have been greatly distressed at Mr Whymper's letter in the Times and the leading article which I was sure would follow," he wrote on August 10. "He might have spared those unnecessary remarks about poor Hudson, which have brought blame on him for want of prudence and caution." Emily Hudson, Charles Hudson's wife, felt the same. Lurid reports were already circulating and she was angry that Whymper should have cast her husband as the wrongdoer. "I cannot tell you how it has distressed me," she wrote. "I am very much surprised that Mr Whymper should have been a party to it. Whymper was released from the inquest on July 22 1865 and came home to find himself the most talked-about person in London. A fellow Alpine club member wrote that he was "most truly to be pitied, for his name is so connected with the Matterhorn, and rather wild designs upon it, that people are sure to blame him for the accident".

In 1870 an entire party of 11, led by a Scot, the Rev G MacCorkendale, got lost in a blizzard and perished on Mont Blanc. The bodies of six of the climbers were never found. According to his sister, "his unfortunate habit of sleeplessness had become fixed, and he practically turned night into day". His main preoccupation was writing up his journals for publication. But he did not stop exploring: he made two expeditions to Greenland, he climbed new peaks in the Andes and the Rockies and, his funds having been exhausted by these forays, wrote guidebooks to Zermatt and Chamonix. He received the Royal Geographical Society's gold medal and was proposed for - but was not granted - membership of the Royal Society. The disaster was a topic he returned to again and again in lecture halls, magazine articles and private correspondence for the 46 years until his death, but he seemed interested only in proving that he was not to blame.

Whymper's relations with women had not been successful, but in 1899 he fell in love with Charlotte Hanbury, one of the few women climbers active in the Alps. She was 10 years his senior and died unexpectedly the following October. The news reached him just as he was starting a lecture tour in America. "My beloved friend gone!" he wrote to his sister. "My memory has gone !... [I am] a Wreck without Brains." His memory returned but he was concerned that he was losing fitness and, when he visited Zermatt a few weeks after the crash, it appeared that he was losing his fame as well. The union did not last. The couple had a daughter and divorced in 1910. The separation was bitter. "Her sole aim is money," he wrote to his sister. He sold his house, his books and even his climbing equipment to stay financially afloat. The following year he visited Zermatt, from where he went to Geneva and then up to Chamonix. It was to be his last Alpine scramble, and perhaps he knew it.

At Chamonix he checked into a hotel where the staff were accustomed to his preference for being left alone. He visited a few bookshops and made arrangements to help find the corpses from the 1870 Mont Blanc disaster which were expected soon to emerge from the glacier. Then, suddenly, went back to his hotel and locked himself into his room. During the next two days, Whymper died. The whole village turned out to watch his funeral.

All the great mountains were subsequently conquered one by one, by insouciant public schoolboys and dogged tradesmen alike. By the end of the second world war the Alps had changed irrevocably. Ski resorts proliferated as entrepreneurs devoured the empty spaces.

Gradients were bulldozed and forests were cut down to create pistes. Ropes were pinned to the Matterhorn to make life easier for those wishing to conquer the Big Rock. This well-groomed wilderness was no place for dragons. Yet its upper levels retained a strange fascination. Climbers still strode across passes, clambered over glaciers and struggled with dangerous new routes. Far fewer in number than the thousands who rushed to the Alps every winter, they preserved a glimmer of the old romance. Like their predecessors, they were trespassers in a hostile environment; they were adventurers in an old tradition.

He sold his house, his books and even his climbing equipment to stay financially afloat. The following year he visited Zermatt, from where he went to Geneva and then up to Chamonix. It was to be his last Alpine scramble, and perhaps he knew it. At Chamonix he checked into a hotel where the staff were accustomed to his preference for being left alone. He visited a few bookshops and made arrangements to help find the corpses from the 1870 Mont Blanc disaster which were expected soon to emerge from the glacier. Then, suddenly, went back to his hotel and locked himself into his room. During the next two days, Whymper died. The whole village turned out to watch his funeral. All the great mountains were subsequently conquered one by one, by insouciant public schoolboys and dogged tradesmen alike. By the end of the second world war the Alps had changed irrevocably. Ski resorts proliferated as entrepreneurs devoured the empty spaces. Gradients were bulldozed and forests were cut down to create pistes. Ropes were pinned to the Matterhorn to make life easier for those wishing to conquer the Big Rock. This well-groomed wilderness was no place for dragons. Yet its upper levels retained a strange fascination. Climbers still strode across passes, clambered over glaciers and struggled with dangerous new routes. Far fewer in number than the thousands who rushed to the Alps every winter, they preserved a glimmer of the old romance. Like their predecessors, they were trespassers in a hostile environment; they were adventurers in an old tradition.  Adapted from Killing Dragons: the Conquest of the Alps by Fergus Fleming (Granta, £20). fields.headline: In good spirit
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: I told her I had recently become a tree worshipper and asked if there was an organisation I could join
fields.body:
Friday, October 27, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

Ivan Braithwaite is home from the mental hospital and is now confined in the box room at Wisteria Walk. My mother is acting as his nurse. I say "acting" because she is most ungracious about her new role. I overheard her talking on the phone to her brother, Pete, who lives in Norwich. It was a self-pitying monologue which I reproduce here, though it gives me no pleasure . . .

"When I married Ivan I expected my life to change. As you know, Pete, Ivan is upper-lower-middle-class and he promised to stretch my horizons, but the only horizons I've seen lately have been the view from the fourth floor of the mental hospital and the vista of the back of my own back garden. I've blown it, Pete. I've turned into a bleddy nursemaid. I'm looking after our Adrian's kids as well, while he's at work.

[Pause]

"No, he's not paying me! He bought me a bunch of forecourt flowers last night and then complained because I'd given the kids lobster nuggets and oven chips for their tea instead of the stupid health stuff he'd brought round in the morning. They're growing lads, Pete. They need more than a few beansprouts and a lump of tofu. Anyway, I'd better go. I'm sorry we've not spoken for over 20 years, Pete, but Mum did promise me her charm bracelet when she died and your wife, Yvonne, had no right to claim it and wear it on her fat wrist at Mum's funeral.

[Pause]

"No! Mum promised it to me, Pete!

[Sobbing]

"She hated Yvonne. She used to call her Nixon . . .

[Pause]

". . . because of her five o'clock shadow, that's why!

[Pause]

"Oh, I'm sorry, Pete, I didn't know that Yvonne had died recently. How recently?

[Pause]

"Yesterday! Oh, my god! Oh, Pete. That's awful!

[Pause]

"So, you'll send me that charm bracelet in the post will you, Pete? Remember to register it." At this point the call was disconnected at the Norwich end.

Saturday, October 28, The Dome, Greenwich

I am sitting here in Harry Ramsden's, waiting for Glenn and William, who are in the queue for the Body Zone. The waiting time is an hour and a quarter. When I suggested an alternative - that we visit the Prayer Zone, which did not have a single visitor - Glenn said, "You go in an' do a prayer, Dad. Me and Will'll catch you later."

The boy is getting to be more assertive by the day. He has already taken over the cooking at home and this morning I found a note in a milk bottle on our doorstep: "No milk today. Gone to the Dome. Cheers milkman, Glenn Bott-Mole". How long has Glenn had a double-barrelled name? And why is "Mole" second? Glenn Mole-Bott has a much more refined ring to it.

The Prayer Zone was still empty. The woman vicar in the pastel tracksuit was obviously grateful to see me and hear my religious views. I told her I had recently become a tree worshipper and asked if there was an organisation I could join. She looked through her index of the Book Of World Religions, without success before saying, "The Liberal Democrats may be your best bet."

Sunday, October 29

The scenes at St Pancras Station were pitiful last night, as desperate East Midlanders milled around on the concourse before setting off on their detours around the broken rails of Midland Main Line.

Monday, October 30

I woke at 3.30am to find that a twister was spiralling down our street. Several wheelie-bins were overturned and a lousy, stinking tree demolished my shed.

webTitle: Review: Poisoning the Minds of the Lower Orders by Don Herzog

fields.headline: Amongst the gargoyles
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on Poisoning the Minds of the Lower Orders by Don Herzog, an academic with the gift of readability
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Poisoning the Minds of the Lower Orders by Don Herzog, an academic with the gift of readability
fields.body:
Poisoning the Minds of the Lower Orders
Don Herzog
Princeton, £12.50
Buy it at BOL

Rather a find, this one. While it appears under an academic imprint, it seems as though the author is not exactly following the brief that his discipline would suggest. Herzog teaches law and political philosophy at the University of Michigan; but he appears to have written a book about British politics, prejudices and manners between 1790 and 1830. Moreover, he has done so with a scholarly thoroughness that one would not have suspected from someone writing, so to speak, left-handedly.

But an air of carnival infects his book. His subject may seem dry, but he handles it with almost mischievous élan. And this subject? Largely, the beginnings of modern conservatism; and particularly as it manifests itself in reaction to the French Revolution. We have a parade of all the gargoyles of the day getting themselves into a lather about the number and influence of new-fangled newspapers; the inadvisability of people from the working classes discussing politics in coffeehouses and (worse) alehouses; the question of whether Jews, blacks and women were to be admitted into the thinking classes, or indeed even the human classes.

Herzog reminds us of some uncomfortable facts. Cobbett, the radical, was offensively anti-negro, even by the standards of the day; whereas Johnson, the Tory, could see no justification for discrimination on the basis of skin colour. Byron was disgustingly anti-semitic, as was, indeed, the whole culture: "Eager vocalists turning to The Universal Songster could learn the words to some fifty songs featuring Jews, among them the ever memorable ... 'The Jew Pedlar Selling a Pig, 'Jabesh Ham; or, the Catastrophe of a Pork-Chop Dinner', and 'De Chinkling of de Cash'. Somehow these aren't the sort of deep sea treasures that surface when social historians want to wax romantic about popular culture." This is not cut-and-dried partisan history. Look at the swipe he gives EP Thompson, for instance.

Herzog's tone is sceptical, constructively flippant, mordant - and, above all, readable. He is even more fun to read than our own Roy Porter, a social historian who has crossed over into a relatively widespread readership. Herzog deserves the same, and if he is a bit too fond of the word "squelched", as in what usually happens to human rights, we can forgive him that in the wider scheme of things.

What makes this book truly special is the way that you can start thinking "that reminds me of something ..." without Herzog's having had to spell it out at all, or even hint at it. The patrician concern about the proliferation of newspapers is echoed in today's reactions to the internet; the justifications for state secrecy and misinformation are as alive now, with the persecution of David Shayler and others, as they were then; and stirring up the mob for illiberal, if not sinister, purposes, is something that we should research with the impending fuel blockade in mind.

That Herzog allows these connections to form without the slightest nudge on his part is something almost magical. I know that many people out there would rather eat one of their own feet than read a supposedly academic work like this; but do give it a go. You'll find it's worth it.

fields.headline: Twisted tales of one man and his cat
fields.standfirst: Kinky Friedman tells Phil Daoust how detective novels saved his life
fields.trailText: Kinky Friedman tells Phil Daoust how detective novels saved his life
fields.body:
In 1985 Kinky Friedman was a failing country-and-western singer, bearings lost in a blizzard of cocaine. "A lot of my friends were dying of drugs," he recalls. "I was doing enough Peruvian marching powder to decorate a large nativity scene, and my career was tanking. No one wanted to book me."

One of Friedman's heroes, Hank Williams, had gone through the same mill three decades before: "He'd had a string of number one hits, yet nobody would book him because he was a drunken idiot who would never show up or would fall off the stage."

Williams went to Jesus full of whiskey and morphine in the back of a speeding Cadillac one New Year's Day. "But I didn't have a perfectly timed country-music death," Friedman says. Instead, he latched onto a remark made by his sister Marcie: since he was so fond of detective stories, why not write one?

That was 15 years ago, and Friedman's first novel, Greenwich Killing Time, has been followed by 12 others. He has kicked the nose candy and is now published in more than a dozen countries. His fans include Bill Clinton, who asked him to write more books - "I need the laughs" - and tried to fix up a Hollywood deal for him.

Friedman didn't look far to find the character who animates all his novels. Both he and his amateur detective are Jewish Texans with dodgy 'taches and an unhealthy attachment to cowboy hats. Both love animals and cigars and once fronted country bands. Both show an immaturity about women and gays that seems more like wind-up than genuine attitude. Both are relentless, often irritating wisecrackers. "I'm good for about three minutes of superficial charm," Friedman admits, "then it begins to go downhill." Oh, and both go by the name of Richard "Kinky" Friedman. The K-word apparently refers to their hair.

"I wrote the first book using my own name, but planned to change the details before sending it to a publisher," he explains. But then he thought: "Jesus, you got a name like Kinky Friedman, you really ought to run with it."

For good measure, Friedman stuck in friends, family, other members of his old band, the Texas Jewboys, the family ranch in the Lone Star State, his temporary home in the Big Apple, his cokehead past, the women he had the hots for and, most memorably, his beloved cat Cuddles. Most gave him permission to use their names; Cuddles seems to have declined, as she is referred to only as "the cat".

Friedman, 55, will never rival Agatha Christie for suspense or obfuscation. He may initially interest you in a murder or disappearance, but by the time his blundering alter ego has solved the case, you probably won't give a damn. He readily admits that his latest novel, The Mile High Club, "is one of the few books I've written that has a plot".

But none of that matters. For a thoroughgoing smartass, "the Kinkster" is surprisingly vulnerable and open to beauty. The Mile High Club finds him paraphrasing Oscar Wilde's The Happy Prince for his feline friend. "It takes a brilliant and troubled homosexual poet," he comments, "to write a story about a statue and a bird that is so beautiful it can reach across an ocean and a century just to touch a man and a cat."

There was the same mix of crassness and sensitivity in the songs Friedman wrote for the Texas Jewboys. They ranged from Get Your Biscuits in the Oven and Your Buns in the Bed, for which the National Organisation of Women named him male chauvinist pig of the year, to Rapid City, South Dakota, perhaps the first country song to touch on abortion, and the Holocaust spiritual Ride 'Em Jewboy.

Friedman's novels combine a rough affection for his old chums with a general suspicion of humanity. Perhaps it dates back to that mid-1980s crisis; perhaps it's the result of being born "the bastard son of two races" - a Jew in America's most redneck state. Anyway, he says, "People always let you down, as Jesus found out. And Van Gogh. And Mozart. And Anne Frank. And Oscar Wilde. Five of my heroes, all of whom died in paupers' graves, or no graves at all."

Animals alone get unconditional love. The Texas ranch where he now lives is home to several dogs, a cat and an armadillo named Dilly, which surfaced in the novel Armadillos and Old Lace . He still writes about Cuddles, though she had to be put down in 1993. "She was as close to me as any human being I have ever known," he declared in the epilogue to Elvis, Jesus and Coca-Cola . "I dug her grave with a silver spade, in the little garden by the stream behind the old green trailer where both of us lived in summertime. Her burial shroud was my old New York sweatshirt and in the grave with her is a can of tuna and a cigar."

As Friedman's writing career has taken off, so has his music. Willie Nelson, Tom Waits, Dwight Yoakam and Lyle Lovett covered his songs in a tribute album last year, and he's now in the middle of a European tour. "Music is fun now that I don't have to do it," he says wryly.

Even so, time may be running out for the character that gave Kinky Friedman his second chance at fame. "I've written 15 books about the Kinkster now, including a couple that are not yet published. Perhaps it's time to try something different. So I'm seriously thinking of killing him off in a kind of Reichenbach Falls suicide. And if the literary community start clamouring for him to return ... well, we'll see."
Buy The Mile High Club at BOL

webTitle: The Saturday poems: Meeting the British by Paul Muldoon

fields.headline: Meeting the British
fields.trailText:
We met the British in the dead of winter.
The sky was lavender...
fields.body:
We met the British in the dead of winter.
The sky was lavender

and the snow lavender-blue.
I could hear, far below,

the sound of two streams coming together
(both were frozen over)

and, no less strange,
myself calling out in French

across that forest-
clearing. Neither General Jeffrey Amherst

nor Colonel Henry Bouquet
could stomach our willow-tobacco.

As for the unusual
scent when the Colonel shook out his hand-

kerchief: C'est la lavande,
une fleur mauve comme le ciel.

They gave us six fishhooks
and two blankets embroidered with smallpox.

As for the unusual scent when the Colonel shook out his hand- kerchief: C'est la lavande, une fleur mauve comme le ciel. They gave us six fishhooks and two blankets embroidered with smallpox.

fields.headline: What's selling in sport
fields.trailText: The top ten sport books.
fields.body:
Should David Beckham's "autobiography" be registered as sport or showbiz? One half of it is apparently aimed at Spice Girlies (luscious lifestyle prose to match those peachy body shots), the other punches home the points about the wild man of Man U. It stands out in this chart for being at least interestingly ambivalent about its intended market. There can be no such doubts with autobiogs such as Foggy (superbiking) or Redgrave - A Golden Age (rowing), which inhabit that profitable niche where, bafflingly to most of us, a minority sport suddenly acquires a mass following. Unsurprisingly, the chart is dominated by soccer books - perhaps more surprising is that two of them are by West Ham players (Di Canio and Stuart Pearce). The start of the steeplechasing season sees Richard Dunwoody making good running, along with Mark Howard's handy, self-published tipster's bible, One Jump Ahead.

webTitle: The Saturday poems:  Musée des Beaux Arts by WH Auden

fields.headline: Musée des Beaux Arts
fields.trailText:
About suffering they were never wrong,
The Old Masters: how well they understood...
fields.body:
About suffering they were never wrong,
The Old Masters: how well they understood
Its human position; how it takes place
While someone else is eating or opening a window or just walking dully along;
How, when the aged are reverently, passionately waiting
For the miraculous birth, there always must be
Children who did not specially want it to happen, skating
On a pond at the edge of the wood:
They never forgot
That even the dreadful martyrdom must run its course
Anyhow in a corner, some untidy spot
Where the dogs go on with their doggy life and the torturer's horse
Scratches its innocent behind on a tree.

In Brueghel's Icarus , for instance: how everything turns away
Quite leisurely from the disaster; the ploughman may

Have heard the splash, the forsaken cry,
But for him it was not an important failure; the sun shone
As it had to on the white legs disappearing into the green
Water; and the expensive delicate ship that must have seen
Something amazing, a boy falling out of the sky,
Had somewhere to get to and sailed calmly on.

fields.headline: Water party
fields.trailText: As regular readers of the Loafer will have gathered, one of the secrets of a well-attended literary party lies in the rarity value of its venue, the canapé brigade loving a good gawp at a swanky interior
fields.body:
 As regular readers of the Loafer will have gathered, one of the secrets of a well-attended literary party lies in the rarity value of its venue, the canapé brigade loving a good gawp at a swanky interior. The Folio Society grasped this point admirably and booked the Cabinet War Rooms for the launch of a new edition of Churchill's History of the Second World War. But the War Rooms had suffered in the recent floods, and the party had to be cancelled. Having gamely attempted to warn invitees, the dutiful hosts stood guard on the night lest any would-be revellers turned up. No doubt Churchill (whose wax effigy sits inside) would have been amused that an office that survived the Blitz should be sunk by a bit of rainwater.

 Odds report: Still 6-1 at Ladbroke's, the Loafer's top Booker wager Trezza Azzopardi has come into 7/2 at William Hill's. Matthew Kneale at 5-1 is also worth a punt. Margaret Atwood is favourite with both firms - but if she wins, the Loafer will eat John McCririck's hat.

 In the latest murmurings from the rights scene, we learn that gangster chic is still bankable: Jake Arnott has cut a deal for two more novels - for the traditional "substantial six-figure sum" - with publishers Hodder, just as his debut, The Long Firm, is being made into a BBC TV series. Of course, Arnott may have colonised a new genre, but the Loafer doubts it. How different can a book called He Kills Coppers be?

 We are indebted to the Bookseller magazine for the following Frankfurt soundbite, in which an American publisher vents his frustration: "Every year the German publishers try to sell books by fiftysomething philosophers with bags under their eyes. They are usually called either Memoirs 1914-1933 or The Crisis in Germany. I mean, so what? Who cares?" That's them told, then.

 Fans of Alan Bennett eagerly anticipating a run of celebratory programmes on the Beeb will find more to delight them in the current issue of the London Review of Books. In a nostalgic essay, Bennett describes his fruitless struggle to lose his accent, finally conceding: "The truth is that anyone from the North who ventures south of the Trent contracts an incurable disease of the vowels; it's a disease to which weather forecasters are particularly prone, and, for some reason, lecturers in sociology."

webTitle: Review:  The Beatles Anthology by the Beatles

fields.headline: Will you still read me?
fields.standfirst: Andrew Rissik  wonders if the Beatles can throw light on their own legend with their joint book,  The Beatles Anthology
fields.trailText: Andrew Rissik wonders if the Beatles can throw light on their own legend with their joint book, The Beatles Anthology
fields.body:
The Beatles Anthology

the Beatles

368pp, Cassell

£35
Buy it at BOL

It is a pity The Beatles Anthology isn't a more exciting book. Sumptuously produced, with satin-smooth, psychedelic page layouts and rare, deep-saturated colour photos, but also bloated and, often, irritatingly digressive, it really isn't much more than a long-overdue fan-magazine souvenir issue, an astute retrospective commercial cash-in on a phenomenon which, if it was going to receive this sort of autobiographical attention, deserved it a quarter of a century ago.

Paul, George and Ringo give their own accounts of what they did and said at the time and therefore of what they believe that the Beatles were all about, while the voice of John Lennon speaks as best it can from the accumulated garble of old press and television interviews. The result has the official-imprimatur feel of an extended South Bank Show special without any complementary sense of inquisition or revelation. The intense, drug-accentuated extremes of love, ambition, self-interest, boredom, anger and outright hatred which other more readable accounts have evoked dwindle here into a careful, guarded hindsight. The story is told at too low a psychological temperature to be convincing. It seems false not because it is necessarily untrue factually, but because it isn't true to our collective emotional memories.

Mainstream rock music as we understand it today is still largely what the Beatles created between 1963 and 1970. Underneath their playful, prodigious musical sophistication there lay a fundamental simplicity of feeling, a lightly worn but profound emotional eloquence that represented a broadening of the whole psychological palette of popular song. Quite early on, probably at a musically instinctual rather than intellectual level, they understood that rock'n'roll needed to be more than just a combination of rhythm and sensuality, sex and sass.

The 1950s rock'n'rollers - even Elvis and Buddy Holly, their two most important predecessors - had lived in the moment and traded in off-the-peg emotion. To start with, the Beatles simply revamped the old formulas. Their first chart hits were almost completely atmospheric. Nothing mattered except the mood of screaming, head-shaking, hair-waving, tight-harmonised ecstasy, the gleaming, electric vibrancy of the sound. Realising this, their producer and collaborator, George Martin, apparently persuaded them to begin "She Loves You" with its bombarding drum-led chorus, the roaring noise which inaugurated Beatlemania.

At first the Lennon and McCartney lyrics didn't pretend to be anything other than hip phrases arranged in some make-do intuitive sequence for immediate emotional impact - a kind of cleaned-up Teddy Boy delirium. They had a modish swing, a communicated giddiness and enjoyment, which was more important than anything the songs actually said. But by the time that Rubber Soul and Revolver were released in 1965-6, there was a deliberate artistry evident in what the group was doing, a desire to make mundane experience into a thing of beauty, which drew near-unanimous cultural approval. Sir Michael Tippett, in his book Moving into Aquarius, quoted an unnamed critic who'd written: "Their unique quality was to know at which points a scrap of ordinary language needed to be touched in order to make it sing."

During those hot, marijuana-scented summers of the mid-1960s, the Beatles did something that only great public poets can normally do. As the decade ran its shambolic, casualty-strewn course, they punctuated it with music that reflected the world's insanity and attempted to resolve it, to bring the warring tribes together. Out of the mood of romantic dejection and poignancy in which songwriters routinely deal, they began to construct something more rounded and complex: a sense of life's persistent arc of disappointment, of falling short.

It is extraordinary now how little hatred there was in them. Barely political, except in a basic-decency sort of way, they tried on identities like afghan coats. Pot, acid, girls, Bob Dylan, art in general mattered more to them than revolutionary politics ever did. By the time of the fabled summer of love in '67 they had turned into four whiskery Edwardian fops, velveteened and brocaded, droopy in all but the sexual sense. They defined the era, but as aesthetes, not activists. Much wider social forces were responsible for creating it.

In truth, Sergeant Pepper was probably the beginning of the end. It's clear, even from the relatively tactful interviews in The Beatles Anthology, that the Lennon-McCartney partnership became increasingly darkened by competitive tensions. As Lennon yielded to heroin and the closed world Yoko Ono provided, McCartney's restless, organising spirit itched to take over. By the time of the Let it Be sessions the Beatles had lost their finely balanced inner cohesion. Lennon's stroppy, introverted, art-schoolish temperament had created the group. Now McCartney's disciplined, sanguine, extroverted personality imposed stresses that tore it apart.

The problem lay with the nature of McCartney's musical talent. His genius was for song, for seamless melodic originality, more than for rock'n'roll. His harmonic sweetness leads back to Elgar and the English hymnal. But there was an easy-listening, crowd-pleasing fatuity to it - a "Maxwell's Silver Hammer" element - that Lennon understandably abhorred. It was always unnervingly easy to imagine McCartney functioning outside the Beatles, in other musically successful incarnations - as a Sacha Distel or a John Barry or a Burt Bacharach. It's hard to imagine Lennon doing anything other than what he did.

The unity of the Beatles' songs is a unity of variety - of continual, corrective changes of mood and pace. The different tracks answer or modify each other, just as the four Beatles did themselves in those famously droll early press conferences. "Eleanor Rigby", with its images of an urban loneliness as sad as a black-and-white photograph, is framed by the jangling, shut-out-the world self-absorption of "I'm Only Sleeping" or the buoyant, nursery-rhyme knees-up of "Yellow Submarine". The glittering cameos of Sergeant Pepper contract, in the end, to the savage weariness of "A Day in the Life" - to a fatalism that is partly a return from drugs, partly a deeper despair at a life that gives us nothing but work, sensation and exhaustion.

After the breakup, McCartney sadly became what he'd often threatened to be - the pert elfin Tom Bombadil of rock, a carefree multimillionaire minstrel-vagabond making music indiscriminately out of anything that came to hand. Emotionally, the final Beatles track - the one that epitomises the spirit of the group - isn't a McCartney song like "Band on the Run"; it's Lennon's dreamy 1971 solo track "Imagine". "Imagine" completed the journey into anthem-like simplicity that began with "Hey Jude" and "Let it Be". It was a resurrection of every loving, utopian, crackpot-individualist ideal Lennon had meant the Beatles to stand for.

After paying £1.45m for the piano at which "Imagine" was composed, singer-songwriter George Michael said recently: "My feeling is that 'Imagine' will one day be seen as the symbol by which we remember a zenith in the humanity of popular culture, a time when people expressed a naive but genuine belief that they could change the world with music and conviction." The Beatles Anthology is a cool, long, detailed and even-handed account. But what is needed is something more, something that can capture what George Michael describes - this sense of history, this fine, loving, intense, disputatious creative ferment, this achievement.

webTitle: Review:  In Defence of TS Eliot by Craig Raine

fields.headline: No ideas please, we're British
fields.standfirst: Craig Raine's  In Defence of TS Eliot proves that he  is a trenchant but anti-intellectual critic, says  Geoff Dyer
fields.trailText: Craig Raine's In Defence of TS Eliot proves that he is a trenchant but anti-intellectual critic, says Geoff Dyer
fields.body:
In Defence of TS Eliot

Craig Raine

516pp, Picador

£20
Buy it at BOL

As a poet the youngish Craig Raine was on fire, metaphorically speaking. With their "shark-infested" rose stems and dogs grinning "like Yale keys", the first simile-fuelled instalments of his Collected Poems (Picador, £25) - The Onion, Memory and A Martian Sends a Postcard Home - have lost none of their capacity to astonish. This is all the more impressive given that Martian ingredients have since become staple parts of the national poetic diet. Raine played an executive role in this: taking up TS Eliot's old job as head chef at Faber, he became an acknowledged legislator of the way British poetry should be cooked.

Raine has also been a trenchant and busy critic. In Defence of TS Eliot, his second haul of literary essays, comes without any contextualising intro (or outro, for that matter: no index, no notes about where the pieces first appeared); this brusque lack of preliminaries suggests that the talents exercised here need no introduction. If a poem is "a handwritten manuscript", the critic's task is "to set it up in clear, readable type". Given the image-richness of Raine's poetry, one might have expected his criticism to display more of "the talent for metaphorical encapsulation" he admires in Hopkins. Orwell's "draught-excluder moustache" makes a cameo appearance, but as a critic Raine is more concerned with diligence than brilliance. Texts are examined with forensic scrutiny, especially when previous investigators are suspected of tampering with the evidence by trimming quotations. This is painstakingly done in his defence of Eliot (though the amount of energy spent cross-examining his Oxford cronies James Fenton and Tom Paulin has the side effect of making Eliot's anti-semitism seem a strangely local issue).

Eliot warned that the poet-critic is always trying to defend his own output, and Raine, naturally, pounces on writers lacking his own high degree of linguistic resolution and independence. The citizenly impulse behind these arresting critical interventions is usually commendable. One gets the impression of a man simmering in long silence, coming reluctantly to the boil because someone has to speak up and point out exactly how far Bruce Chatwin, Toni Morrison, Edmund White ("can't write") and Paul Auster ("poisoned with clichés") fall short of their reputations. Raine is right to damn much of Joseph Brodsky's output, but his failure explicitly to exempt A Part of Speech from this judgment indicates a willingness to fudge in the interest of polemical cudgelling. Yes, phrases like "on the whole" and "to say the least" are "incessantly deployed in Brodsky's poetry and prose", but these ostensibly redundant parts of speech act like springs, coiled with imaginative force subsequently released.

It is the assertion that as a thinker Brodsky is "by turns fatuous and banal" that is most telling. Raine twice quotes Eliot's admiring observation that Henry James possessed "a mind so fine that no idea could violate it". This question of ideas is central to any discussion of Raine and his position in English letters. As mediated by Raine, Eliot's subtle remark is used - coarsely - to suggest that a preoccupation with ideas is a symptom of artistic coarseness. Critical of Orwell for his "approximations", in thrall to the imperious precision and verve of Nabokov, Raine champions the exacting style of wordplay at which he was national champ. Thought, in this event, is something like - or, as Raine in professorial mode cannot resist putting it, "cognate with" - a knack for setting and solving your own crosswords. Sharing Nabokov's impatience with perceived woolliness, Raine shows how fuzzy the Nabokovian vision becomes when required to look up from and beyond the page.

Auden liked juggling with words but, for Raine, was "easily infatuated" by ideas, constantly "indulging his weakness for notions". The notion that writers should not have notions is a pretty weak one, but towards the end of his Auden essay Raine comes straight out and - echoing a favourite bleat of John Carey's - declares: "We need ideas, but not in our art." This belief - and it is hard not to think of Oxford as its heartland - is a serious blot on the English literary landscape. It means we have tended to rely on exotic foreign imports (Borges, Calvino, Kundera and, most recently, Sebald) to do the idea stuff for us, thereby - the parallel with football is irresistible -impoverishing the development of the domestic game. The corollary of this is that someone like Chatwin, who had a few (half-baked) ideas, is radically overvalued almost as a compensatory reflex.

Compare the relative reputations of EM Forster and Rebecca West, who described the former as "a self-indulgent old liberal with hardly a brain in his head", and you see the extent to which assumptions about literary form conform to what is little more than a prejudice masquerading as refinement. To put it crudely: the minor Where Angels Fear to Tread basks in its uncontested status as a work of art, while Black Lamb and Grey Falcon , one of the great books of the century, is, well, an ungainly history of Yugoslavia or something.

In her teens, West was drawn to Ibsen, who "corrected the chief flaw in English literature, which is a failure to recognise the dynamism of ideas". Characteristically, she later declared that he "cried out for ideas for the same reason that men cry out for water, because he had not got any", but the point still stands: "That ideas are the symbols of real relationships among real forces that make people late for breakfast, that take away their breakfast, that make them beat each other across the breakfast table, is something which the English do not like to realise." Raine, the author of the poem "Bed and Breakfast", would do well to give this some ... (seven letters, begins with T, rhymes with bought).

 Geoff Dyer's book of essays, Anglo-English Attitudes, is published by Abacus.

Critical of Orwell for his "approximations", in thrall to the imperious precision and verve of Nabokov, Raine champions the exacting style of wordplay at which he was national champ. Thought, in this event, is something like - or, as Raine in professorial mode cannot resist putting it, "cognate with" - a knack for setting and solving your own crosswords. Sharing Nabokov's impatience with perceived woolliness, Raine shows how fuzzy the Nabokovian vision becomes when required to look up from and beyond the page. Auden liked juggling with words but, for Raine, was "easily infatuated" by ideas, constantly "indulging his weakness for notions". The notion that writers should not have notions is a pretty weak one, but towards the end of his Auden essay Raine comes straight out and - echoing a favourite bleat of John Carey's - declares: "We need ideas, but not in our art." This belief - and it is hard not to think of Oxford as its heartland - is a serious blot on the English literary landscape. It means we have tended to rely on exotic foreign imports (Borges, Calvino, Kundera and, most recently, Sebald) to do the idea stuff for us, thereby - the parallel with football is irresistible -impoverishing the development of the domestic game. The corollary of this is that someone like Chatwin, who had a few (half-baked) ideas, is radically overvalued almost as a compensatory reflex. Compare the relative reputations of EM Forster and Rebecca West, who described the former as "a self-indulgent old liberal with hardly a brain in his head", and you see the extent to which assumptions about literary form conform to what is little more than a prejudice masquerading as refinement.
