webTitle: Review: A Certain Genius by Barbara Belford

fields.headline: The original Wilde child
fields.standfirst: On Wilde's centenary,  Neil Bartlett  revisits Oscar  in Barbara Belford's A Certain Genius  - and meets Wilde's niece in Joan Schenkar's Truly Wilde: The Unsettling Story of Dolly Wilde
fields.trailText: On Wilde's centenary, Neil Bartlett revisits Oscar in Barbara Belford's A Certain Genius - and meets Wilde's niece in Joan Schenkar's Truly Wilde: The Unsettling Story of Dolly Wilde
fields.body:
A Certain Genius
Barbara Belford
500pp, Bloomsbury
£25
Buy it at BOL
Truly Wilde: The Unsettling Story of Dolly Wilde, Oscar's Unusual Neice
Joan Schenkar
457pp, Virago
£20

Buy it at BOL

Oscar Wilde famously claimed for himself a symbolic relationship with his historical epoch. And with some reason: for more than 10 years, certainly from 1890 to 1900, what you thought about Wilde was a reliable indicator of what you thought and felt about a whole range of emotive issues, ranging from specifics such as sodomy, interior decoration and the West End to more obscure yet fundamental notions of cultural and personal identity. His rise and fall made a front-page drama out of the meanings of masculinity and effeminacy, respectability and fashion, and modernity itself. This symbolic status has not faded over the intervening 100 years. Wilde has continued to function as a kind of cultural litmus test, his name a shorthand for all kinds of surprising allegiances.

Every decade of the last century found a different way of using Wilde to express its own concerns. In the era when his name was literally considered unspeakable, at least in this country, paperback copies of The Ballad of Reading Gaol and The Soul of Man under Socialism were badges of political radicalism. Meanwhile Strauss's operatic Salome of 1905 maintained Wilde's reputation as the ne plus ultra of decadence. EM Forster's Maurice, cowering unpublished in the closet in 1914, miserably branded himself "an unspeakable of the Oscar Wilde sort". Each of the very different theatrical and film Wildes reinvented him in turn as the image of their own times. In the 1970s, his name was taken in vain by a new kind of badge-wearer; a popular button among stroppier queens of Liberation-era London read simply "Avenge Oscar". In our own time Stephen Fry, launching a film that, despite noble intentions, gave us the Wildean pill sugared with a 1990s mix of cost-free sympathy and celebrity, unblushingly compared Wilde to Christ.

So to what new uses will this brilliant and fascinating artist be put in our new, millennial and - as you have no doubt noticed - centenary decade? Who is Wilde now, in the year 2000? Sadly these two new titles, optimistically published to cash in on the festivities, fail to discover any new echoes or resonances in the magic name. The only sound generated is the rather ugly one of the barrel being scraped. Greedy publishers and lazy editors, rather than the poor besotted authors, must, I think, take the primary blame for this. Both Barbara Belford and Joan Schenkar have, in their different ways, fallen under the Wilde spell; but Virago and Bloomsbury might have done well to dampen or at least discipline their infatuations.

The idea of a new biography so soon after Richard Ellmann's magisterial heavyweight has an appealing chutzpah. Indeed, Belford is right to take him to task for his omissions, and my hopes rose when she promised to illuminate Wilde anew by grounding him securely in the context of both homosexual life and theatrical practice in the late 19th century. The problem is, she doesn't deliver. Although she repeatedly mentions that Wilde had sex with other men, she does nothing with the available historical facts. Picturesque but unsubstantiated speculation that things may have been rather neoclassical between the sheets - early exposure to Graeco-Roman statuary in the National Gallery of Ireland having led directly to intercrural copulation with Robbie Ross in the study at Tite Street in 1887 - really won't do.

Her account of late Victorian theatre is hopelessly clogged with irrelevant detail. I was happy to be told that the New York theatre was revolutionised in 1882 by Steele Mackage's invention of the tip-up seat, but unsure what this had to do with Wilde's attempts to stage a hit there. The effect of ill-digested research is pervasive: there are lots of things that need to be said about Wilde's father, but was such a dramatic account of his illegal acquisition of a set of mummified ibis ("sacred, long-legged, white wading birds") while on holiday in Egypt really necessary? Despite the promise that this is a "fresh look" at Wilde, the only really distinctive thing about this book is Belford's occasionally startling turn of phrase. I was frankly amazed to learn that in fin de siècle Algeria "boys showed their availability by scrambling up men's trousers". Belford claims that she has spent five years "getting to know the inner Wilde", and that the familiar material is delivered "with a new, centenary spin". Truth is, this is just a rehash: she has nothing new to say, and says it clumsily.

Joan Schenkar can at least claim to be first in the queue. Her contribution to the Wilde centenary is an oblique one: the first biography of Oscar's previously undocumented niece, Dolly. Although Dolly is the ostensible subject, Uncle is named at least once on every page; the constant comparison and overshadowing matches that which dogged Dolly all her life. By the time she hit the saloons of 1920s Paris, she was the last Wilde. This was her entrée, and she made a point of talking and looking like her uncle whenever she could. She was, according to girlfriends, both a notable wit and an uncannily convincing lookalike when in Oscar drag. Trouble is, she was precious little else; she took a perverse pride in never writing a word of fiction despite constant assurances that she was destined for literary greatness by virtue of the family aura. True, she dined with, borrowed from, insulted or slept with almost everyone in the astonishing rue Jacob lesbian salon, sliding into major addictions (fast cars, drink, drugs and "emergency seductions") before ending up face-down in a rented Belgravia flat at the age of 46. But while simultaneously injecting under the table and dishing the dirt on duchesses may have been chic, it hardly adds up to a career.

Schenkar tries hard to argue that this absence of achievement is itself significant, and that underneath the surface dazzle of proto-It Girl outrage there is a serious book about how the Wildean iconography of self-destruction was replayed in a feminine, feminist, modern and modernist world. I wasn't convinced. The opening chapters are spirited and inventive, but although this biographer is commendably besotted by her subject, and often stylishly successful in evoking an extraordinary lost world of Vionnet frocks and detox clinics, Dolly quickly began to pall. Her uncle's achievement was to lodge himself, for better or for worse, permanently in the public imagination. Dolly lived off his myth, rather than substantially elaborating or elucidating it. The same, I'm afraid, might be said for both these biographies.

 Neil Bartlett's new play about Wilde, In Extremis, is at the National Theatre.

webTitle: Review: Only Human by Jenny Diski

fields.headline: Divine comedy
fields.standfirst: Carol Birch on the jealousy of God in  Jenny Diski's Only Human: A Comedy
fields.trailText: Carol Birch on the jealousy of God in Jenny Diski's Only Human: A Comedy
fields.body:
Only Human: A Comedy
Jenny Diski
215pp, Virago
£14.99
Buy it at BOL

At the beginning of Jenny Diski's meticulously imagined retelling of Genesis chapters 11-22, we are addressed alternately by the unformed consciousness of a newborn child, and by God. God is twitchy and hurt, anxious to present his side of the whole messy business of creation. The babe becomes Sarai, destined to be matriarch of Israel and wife to Abram, chosen one of God.

Diski subtitles her book "a comedy", but there are no belly laughs; this is irony at its driest. Diski constantly slows her readers down to have a little think about the nature of time, posterity, love or guilt, or to contemplate a sentence such as: "Before the beginning, when they were nothing, when nothing was, before the word, before the number and the chapter, before before and after, before he, she and us, before I am that I am, before I will be what I will be - I was, and before I was, I was, when nothing was." At this stage many will turf the book aside muttering "God stuff", which is a pity because, as the title implies, it is a wholly human story.

Most of the comedy centres around the seething, misunderstood God, a character whose deviant behaviour and barmily inconsistent ways stem from the wish to be loved. There's something of the teenager about him as he sulks and stays in his room for days on end refusing to speak, then when no one notices throws a furious, heel-drumming tantrum in which he destroys Sodom and Gomorrah. Also well caught are Abram and Sarai, whose lifelong marriage is the serious core of the book. Childless at a time when to die without an heir was tragic and it was permitted to take more than one wife, Abram has nevertheless remained faithful to Sarai and the couple are devoted to each other.

However, when her periods stop and a child is finally impossible, a simple remark - "Now there can be no surprises" - triggers a shared mid-life crisis that plunges Abram into the dark night of the soul. God, needy and jealous, brooding on the edge of his unruly creation, speaks to Abram, and Abram hears. God loves Abram simply because he hears. Sarah, however, does not, and Diski paints a wonderful portrait of a long-suffering woman coming to terms with a barmy but beloved old husband.

Whenever Abram reports one of his conversations with God, you can sense Sarai mentally battening down the hatches with a barely suppressed here-we-go-again sigh. Even when confronted with hard evidence of her rival (a personal appearance, her pregnancy in old age after a lifetime of infertility), she exercises her right to choose, and chooses to ignore him.

God and Sarai's elaborate battle for the love of Abram focuses on the issue of a child. The exploitation of Hagar, the slave girl who bears Abram a proxy heir at Sarai's command, is a move in this battle. So too is the birth of Isaac, adored child of Sarai and Abram's old age. And so is God's terrible final demand that Abram offer Isaac as a sacrifice. This is God's nuclear bomb, winning him the war but at an unbearable price, breaking all hearts including his own.

"Whoever the story belongs to, the events took place in the world," says Diski, and, in spite of its ethereal beginnings, this is very much the world as we know it. There is no attempt to emulate Biblical speech and the tone is often deliberately anachronistic. Occasionally this grates; but overall the book succeeds remarkably in bringing to life one of the world's first great family sagas.

webTitle: Review:  The Prime Minister: The Office and its Holders Since 1945 by Peter Hennessy

fields.headline: Gerbil power
fields.standfirst: Peter Henessy's  The Prime Minister: The Office and its Holders Since 1945 impresses Ian Aitken
fields.trailText: Peter Henessy's The Prime Minister: The Office and its Holders Since 1945 impresses Ian Aitken
fields.body:
The Prime Minister: The Office and its Holders Since 1945

Peter Hennessy

704pp, Allen Lane

£25
Buy it at BOL

It must be tremendous fun being one of Professor Hennessy's pupils: he is the antithesis of the dry-as-dust academic historian. He laughs a great deal, and punctuates his writing with cheery and illuminating anecdotes. But he is also intensely scholarly, peppering his books with the kind of footnotes that all dons treasure.

And yet he might easily have been a simple hack, labouring as a lobby correspondent in the steam-heated vineyards of the Palace of Westminster. He was saved from this fate by the fact that when the Financial Times sent him into the lobby in 1976, he loathed it and more or less invented the job of Whitehall correspondent to escape.

He did the Whitehall job superbly - none of his many imitators was half as good until the Guardian's own David Hencke appeared on the scene. But Hennessy's rummaging in the closets of Whitehall generated a fascination with the workings of the government machine that led him inevitably into a new career as a teacher and researcher. We - not to mention his students - must be grateful for his (in my view) over-fastidious rejection of the lobby system, for it has given us a stream of high-quality books about the corridors of power, the most famous of which is used by the civil service as the standard "teach yourself" text for new recruits. Now we have another one which could easily be called "teach yourself how to be prime minister".

Or perhaps I should amend that to "how not to be prime minister". For the lesson here, intentional or not, is that virtually all post-war prime ministers have tried to turn the government machine into an instrument of their own aims, and all have failed to a greater or lesser degree. But whatever the book's overall message, it is the splendid stories and one-liners about the 10 men and one woman who have held the premiership since 1945 that keep you turning the pages.

Try a few for size: which of the 11 had "all the presence of a gerbil"? Attlee. Who said "I was always a shit. My son wouldn't be one, and that's why he didn't get on in politics"? Macmillan. Who had the cabinet seats re-upholstered so that they wouldn't snag a lady member's tights? Wilson. And whose private secretary got the sack for shouting "grub's up" when delivering late-night sandwiches to the cabinet room? Heath's. There are more. Such as: of whom did George Wigg say "He's filleted again; send in a new backbone"? Callaghan, as chancellor. And who said: "When I retire I shall run a business called 'Rent-a-Spine'"? Mrs Thatcher, on the foreign office.

I share a lot of Hennessy's verdicts. He thinks Attlee was wonderful, which is possibly just a tiny bit OTT, but only a bit. He clearly approves of Macmillan's great con-trick on his own party, leading them deeper into consensus politics while saying the opposite. He is quite enthusiastic about Heath, insisting that he didn't start as a premature Thatcherite, and reckons Callaghan was a good prime minister defeated by impossible circumstances.

But he is quite beastly about Wilson, perhaps because (as he readily admits) he fell hook, line and sinker for all that "white heat of the technological revolution" stuff at the start. Those of us who were sceptical at the time were not quite so disappointed later, and can now look more kindly on little Harold.

I have bigger reservations, however. His assessment of Blair - that he has imported the White House to Number 10 - omits the key role of the chap living next door. If it is true that one man seems to be running the government from Downing Street, then that man is Gordon Brown. That, I suppose, is the risk in writing instant rather than contemporary history: events overtake you.

But my biggest complaint is that Hennessy's real heroes aren't the prime ministers but their civil servants. With rare exceptions, it is Sir Humphrey who turns out to be right, especially when he is reining in some overambitious Whitehall reformer. But then, Sir Humphrey is the professor's best source, so perhaps he is just being - well, shall we say prudent?

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  searches for the essence of civilization in Felipe Fernandez-Armesto's Civilizations
fields.trailText: Steven Poole searches for the essence of civilization in Felipe Fernandez-Armesto's Civilizations
fields.body:
Civilizations

Felipe Fernandez-Armesto

636pp, Macmillan

£25
Buy it at BOL

Civilization is a knotty word. The good Doctor Johnson, for example, was not about to let it through the hallowed portals of his Dictionary, as Boswell tells us: "He would not admit civilization, but only civility. With great deference to him, I thought civilization, from to civilize, better in the sense opposed to barbarity, than civility."

Today we no longer reach so comfortably for words like "barbarity". But, as Boswell rightly points out, the word "civilization" is derived from the verb "to civilize", so what it can usefully denote is a process rather than a congealed achievement. Civilization, properly, is the process of rendering a society more civil. It is a political concept, deriving ultimately from the Latin "civis", citizen of a community, and the idea of what is proper to a citizen, which is "civilitas" or courtesy. It is in this sense that a beautifully sardonic Gandhi murmured that western civilization "would be a good idea".

Felipe Fernandez-Armesto, however, claims to believe that the idea of a civilizing "process" - whereby societies might learn to live together more peacefully and productively - is tainted irrevocably by the horrors of 20th-century dreams of "progress": fascism and Soviet communism. This is rampant nonsense. The fact that some dreams of progress have been wicked is no good reason to abandon the idea of progress itself. It is undeniable that universal suffrage and the abolition of the death penalty have contributed to the civilization of this country in the past century. And we ought constantly to demand more civilization, rather than to abandon the idea completely out of a misguided world-historical pessimism.

But then, the key to understanding the deliberate eccentricity of Fernandez-Armesto's book lies in his hysterical anti-liberalism. He is a man complacently "waiting for the conservative nirvana", and seriously claims at the book's climax that "liberal principles become the forerunners of death camps and eugenics". Such nasty pottiness bookends this fat work: at the start, he smears the work of Arnold Toynbee with the following disgustingly uncivil innuendo: "Toynbee's enthusiasm for 'pioneer' leaders, steering civilization towards collective goals, seems chilling in a work published just after Hitler came to power." Another theorist of civilization, Kenneth Clark, is dismissed for what Fernandez-Armesto calls his "warped perspective". But Clark's perspective - his preference for a marble Apollo over an African mask - was no more "warped" than any other: it was simply a perspective. It would seem hard, indeed, to write from no perspective at all; unless, perhaps, you can attain the godlike objectivity of a Fernandez-Armesto.

Our author's claim is that civilization is fundamentally a measure of how man refashions his environment to his own ends. He solicits both praise for this idea's novelty ("This is an experimental work ... meant to be ... unprecedented") and respect for its venerability ("The usage I advocate is justified by tradition"), thus setting a rigorously maintained precedent of having his cake and eating it. He notices that Toynbee had the idea in 1919, but dismisses his formulation on a technicality and then conveniently forgets about it. He promises grandly that his revolutionary new recategorisation will open up fresh vistas of historical truth.

Up to a point. The central 500 pages are devoted to a grand tour of world history by environment: hostile wastelands of desert, tundra and ice; swathes of uncultivable grassland; tropical and temperate forests; alluvial soils; highlands, islands and "seaboard civilizations". The plurality of the book's title emphasises that civilization is not confined to western Europe or other lucky pockets of geography: human ingenuity ensures that it happens pretty much anywhere humans can stay alive. Great structures have been built in rebarbative rainforest or on shifting mud. Fernandez-Armesto's scheme enables pretty juxtapositions (the Aztecs, Ethiopians and Tibetans are seen to have overcome similar problems of altitude) and provocative revaluations (the Aztecs, again, seem more heroically competent in "civilizing" their environment than the classical Greeks).

But Fernandez-Armesto, in the interest of covering all bases, is so systematically self-contradictory as to be almost comically incoherent. Environment shapes civilization; no, it doesn't; yes, it does; er, OK then, civilizations are "neither determined nor uninfluenced by environment". Well, who is going to argue with that? Temporary and mutually exclusive criteria of civilizational "success" flash past. The Inuit, for example, are less "civilized" than modern Europeans because they have adapted themselves to their icy environment rather than attempting to change it; then again, maybe civilization would be an "irrational strategy" in such terrain, "at least where long-term survival is the goal". But if long-term survival really were a valid criterion, that would imply that the Inuit have been more successful than, say, the imperial Romans, because the Inuit are still here.

Fernandez-Armesto's definition of what sort of behaviour constitutes "civilizing" an environment becomes so loose at times - just eating bits of it and constructing ramshackle shelters seems to be enough - that it could accommodate badgers, nest-building birds and termites just as well as it does humans. Stretch the word that thinly and it becomes useless. Some part of him seems to recognise the explanatory poverty of his thesis, for he regularly has recourse to "civilization" and its cognates in their old senses, lapsing into the usage he has derided: specifically, city-building societies with complex political cultures.

Civilizations, though stuffed with what ought to be fascinating historical facts and comparisons, is the sheerest drudgery to read, because Fernandez-Armesto only rarely remembers what he is supposed to be arguing and instead indulges in reams of irrelevant armchair tourism and purple-hued narration. Were his theory a coherent and useful one, in fact, he would have been able to write a much shorter book. The reader at least ought to be grateful that he thinks "culture" cannot explain anything (at least, about half the time he does; as with most of his sweeping statements, he denies it about as often as he asserts it), because his own swerves into that territory are quite shatteringly banal. "Plato fancied himself as a political thinker," we are told facetiously; "Confucius was part of a vibrant world of ideas"; Romanticism is "a scale of values which put emotion above reason"; and Japanese religion "surely represent[s] the way human minds work more typically than westerners of the present generations". What on God's sweet earth can that mean?

Oddly, for all his carefully burnished self-image as a pioneering, multicultural, iconoclastic historian, Fernandez-Armesto's prose is that of a parodic 19th-century buffer, an Anglophile gentleman amateur who congratulates himself on having written his book "in something of a frenzy" informed by "no mature deliberation", who rails constantly against the "gimcrack rubbish" of newfangled inventions such as the electronic watch and (I kid you not) the zippered fly, and who observes the dusty gleam of ancient societies with a patronising inverted snobbery, excusing what was violent, brutish and - yes - uncivilized about them.

Civilizations is, finally, a useful book in one way only: it defines the sensible limits of multiculturalism by overstepping them. Fernandez-Armesto is of course right to emphasise that modern western civilization is not the historically privileged summit of human evolution, but to doubt that it is in every way better than a superstitious ancient culture of South America that regularly sacrificed newborn babies is the most irrational cant of all.

fields.headline: Adventures in perception
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery is duly rewarded by Lobster Moth and looks at other new fiction: Semi-Detached, Miss and Irish Ghost Stories
fields.body:
Lobster Moth
Niall Duthie
(Fourth Estate, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

If, as the father of one of Duthie's narrators remarks, "Good novels are adventures in perception", then this is a very exhilarating trip indeed. An Edwardian lepidopterist and the actor who is to play him in a film 80 years later explore ways of seeing through observations noted in their pillow books. These are not diaries, everyday records of Robert Gilmerton convalescing in 1916 from a shrapnel wound or of David Orr slowly coming to inhabit the role of Gilmerton, but commonplace books in which events, memories and justifications are noted in 10-minute segments. Duthie demands the reader's absolute concentration, but rewards it tenfold.

Semi-Detached
Cynthia Holz
(Piatkus, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Does this herald the 50-something novel? Barbara and Elliot Rifkin make it from being teenaged sweethearts, through marriage, kids and carriage clocks only to find that they can't stomach each other's company 24 hours a day. They decide to split the house horizontally: Barbara has the basement and takes up pottery, Elliot, upstairs, masters cookie-baking and Tai Chi. Not surprisingly, their daughter is angry and their son bewildered; friends don't get it and new acquaintances get the wrong idea. Holz catalogues their progress in an undemanding narrative which is redeemed by an unconventional take on middle-aged marriage.

Miss
LE Usher
(Quartet, £7)
Buy it at BOL

Miss, a London bookshop-owner with an unconventional past in Australia, befriends Edmunde Maskelyne, a well-known author with the most proper of English literary pedigrees, over Thursday afternoon herbal tea off Marylebone High Street. Then Miss buys a library of books on murders of women and sees a possible way to prick Maskelyne's complacency. Usher confronts the slender boundary between deep love and intense hate within the format of a highly intellectual mystery. The flick of the tale's end is almost redundant given the sly evocation of the self-satisfied minor literati, the sensuous pleasures of books and the dangers of self-absorption.

Irish Ghost Stories
ed David Marcus
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Someone has no doubt written a thesis on why we like an unnerving story, but this collection tries hard to go against the grain, presenting unconventional ghosts who hang around the central heating, haunt the TV set, inhabit gloves and get pulled from graves by comic witches. There is conventional stuff from Elizabeth Bowen and Jennifer Johnston and, if you are in a mood to be frightened by what is beyond the curtains, Marcus's selection does the job. Don't expect too much from the writing, though. What this collection best demonstrates is that even good writers fall for traditional devices when it comes to ghost stories.

fields.headline: The age of the train
fields.trailText: Vera Rule on two steamy books: Terry Coleman's The Railway Navvies and Trevor May's The Victorian Railway Worker
fields.body:
The Railway Navvies
Terry Coleman
(Pimlico, £12.50)

Twenty thousand miles of track in this island, and in those as many hours of manpower as built our cathedrals, for the iron way was hewn by pick-axe and the rails laid by a multitude of navigators, their calorific energy generated by two pounds of beef and a gallon of ale a day. They swanked in rainbow waistcoats, slept in felt-roofed shanties, were stoic when the viaduct arches toppled in an orderly sequence, and seldom survived past 40 - their death-rate percentage being higher than that in the battle of Waterloo. Along with the long darknesses of tunnels, this reprint is their chief memorial.

The Victorian Railway Worker
Trevor May
(Shire, £3.50)

In 1905, British railway companies employed half a million workers, a third of them on maintenance: railways were the largest operators of horsedrawn transport, the first non-governmental paperwork bureaucracies, the first standardisers of national timekeeping (or how would we know a train was late?) and so reluctant to pay compensation for the one in 10 shunters killed or injured in their work that a guard told a royal commission he believed widows got only "a nice coffin". Compacted fact and brass-buttoned pix recall a past that was even so pride-filled.

fields.headline: First novels
fields.trailText: Lisa Darnell on bisexuality being the new black in Biche plus The Man Who Ate the 747, Bodega Dreams and My Elvis Blackout
fields.body:
Is bisexuality the new black? You might think so, what with Big Brother and the producers of This Life snapping up Stephanie Theobald's Paris-based debut Biche (Flame, £10.99). George, a voracious bisexual, is part of an ex-pat "gang" with whom she shares the blow-by-blow details of her many conquests. She's ferociously ambitious, brimming with self-loathing and excoriating wit: one would hope never to be the focus of her blistering attention at a party. When she unexpectedly falls in love with an athletic sloane, we know it is the real thing as her usual repertoire of sexual gymnastics palls in preference for spooning with her girlfriend, cellulite and all. When it goes wrong, alas, never-rejected George falls apart. Gratuitous sex and bohemian emotional carnage aside, George is yet another twentysomething in search of a mate. Although Theobold's bombastic delivery sets her apart from the rest, the message remains the same: you fall in love, you get your heart broken. Fin.

Even so, it seems we will do anything for love, as witnessed by JJ Smith in Ben Sherwood's stomach-churning The Man Who Ate the 747 (Picador, £12). Smith works for the Book of Records: his job is to travel the world identifying those worthy of a place in history. In small-town Nebraska, mild-mannered farmer Wally Chubb is quietly eating a jumbo jet piece by piece in order to capture the attention of the local newspaper editor. Smith is cynically keen to net the plane-eating feat for his book, but Wally prefers the power of love to worldly acclaim. American writer Sherwood has one eye firmly fixed on Hollywood, but this is still an oddly touching tale.
Buy it at BOL

Poverty and violence collide with love and apple-pie idealism in Ernesto Quinonez's sassy thriller Bodega Dreams (Serpent's Tail, £10). Set in New York's Spanish Harlem - "ugly real estate that no one wants" - Puerto Rican mafioso Willie Bodega uses drug money to fund community projects, creating for himself the role of benevolent titan. Twenty years earlier, the woman he loved left him for a wealthy, cultured Cuban; propelled by this betrayal, Bodega believes that by becoming larger than life he can recapture what has "been lost, stolen, or denied to him and his people". Quinonez is a rare beast among his peers, a street-smart writer who has not only insight and sensitivity, but also a social conscience.
Buy it at BOL

In counterpoint to the world's freakish predilection for Elvis-as-hero and back-from-the-dead fantasies, philosopher Simon Crump has concocted the surreal and often grotesque My Elvis Blackout (Bloomsbury, £10). In an unnervingly bizarre series of vignettes, Elvis and his friends (and a monkey called Scatter) go on the rampage, exterminating fans and enemies alike with a range of lethal weapons. Like an episode of South Park, where just as you get into the story something goes splat, Crump's contorted imagination is alarmingly enjoyable.
Buy it at BOL

webTitle: Too Far Afield by Günter Grass

fields.headline: After the fall
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi  on Günter Grass' warning to the new Germany in  Too Far Afield
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi on Günter Grass' warning to the new Germany in Too Far Afield
fields.body:
Too Far Afield
Günter Grass

trans Krishna Winston

658pp, Faber

£25
Buy it at BOL

Günter Grass's first novel after the Berlin Wall fell, The Call of the Toad (1992), took its title from Baltic lore - it invoked a cry of warning, a prophecy of doom for Germany's dawning age. Seen by some as a lugubrious party pooper for his refusal to share the euphoria attending German unification, Grass followed that cautionary tale three years later with the novel Too Far Afield, published now in English translation.

Set in Berlin between the fall of the Wall in November 1989 and the aftermath of unification in October 1990, it probes and laments, largely through the eyes of East German characters, what Grass has elsewhere disparaged as "unification without unity". While The Tin Drum (1959) - the novel cited when Grass was awarded last year's Nobel Prize for literature - was a forceful reckoning with Germany's Nazi past, Too Far Afield explores the warnings encrypted in a longer, repetitious national history.

Its protagonist is Theo Wuttke, a cultural functionary and itinerant lecturer known as Fonty for his obsessive identification with Theodor Fontane, the 19th-century Prussian balladeer and novelist of Huguenot origins, who was born 100 years to the day before him and whom he reveres as "the Immortal". Fonty's family has been sundered since the Wall was built in 1961, his three sons having defected, leaving him, his wife and daughter in "three and a half rooms" in Berlin's Prenzlauer Berg district. As he observes the "wallpeckers" hacking saleable souvenirs from Berlin's crumbling edifice, Fonty dourly celebrates his 70th birthday in McDonald's with his friend Hoftaller, apparently a reincarnation of a 19th-century spy, Ludwig Tallhover.

Hoftaller is Fonty's minder, his "day-and-night shadow" with whom he is "glued together for an eternity". Both now work for the "Handover Trust", the agency charged with the privatisation of East German state property (euphemistically termed "winding down"). But though Fonty now serves different masters, and can navigate Berlin districts that were off limits for decades, he remains aloof from the bursts of Beethoven's Ode to Joy at the Brandenburg Gate and the "brief pause scheduled for profound emotion" that mark the end of the "Workers' and Peasants' state". As he sees it: "Within this world of want, we lived in a comfy dictatorship."

Grass, a defeated advocate of gradualism and federation (though also a critic of the East German state), writes scathingly of how the velvet revolution segued into what he portrays as colonial annexation. As one Berliner says of the post-unification hangover: "Y'know, you wish for a thing, but when it comes it's like someone hit you over the head." With the advent of the Deutschmark ("whose very hardness might well turn against us") and a tide of joblessness, the Easterners are "leftovers, good only for scrap". They are prey to "Parvenooskis" and "Nogoodniks", smart westerners "on the prowl for real estate, sticky-fingered and unification-drunk". This crew is embodied by a builder turned speculator who marries Fonty's daughter; a marvellously comic wedding scene flays "stuck-up Wessies" for looking down their noses at their poor-relation, second-class-citizen "Ossies".

Fonty, for whom "the centuries were fluid" and whose fevers mirror political crises, recognises the events of the present as Germany's second unification. As the old man imagines a lifetime "double woven" with that of his Bismarck-era hero, Grass traces parallels across German literature and history, between the founding eras of 1871 and 1989. He links the betrayals and clampdowns of the 1848 revolution and 1953 East German uprising with the architects of unity, whom he deems "colossal tricksters"; the Iron Chancellor with the "watered-down Bismarck" Helmut Kohl. Through echoes between Bismarck's three unification wars and Hitler's aggression, or between the St Bartholomew's Night Huguenot massacre and Kristallnacht, on whose 51st anniversary the Berlin Wall falls, Too Far Afield warns insistently of the "idiotic pride in 'Deutschland' that has always gone hand in hand with violence", the "weather-resistant anti-semitism" and the recurring xenophobia that makes Turks "the new Huguenots".

The return of "one-fatherland-indivisible" invokes a dangerous mythology in a country "where, for all eternity, Buchenwald lies down the road from Weimar". Grass underlines this historical continuity through Fonty's workplace, the Luftwaffe HQ turned GDR ministerial complex now housing the Handover Trust, and through the shape-shifting of Hoftaller, a chameleon at his ease whether in Prussia's police state, Hitler's Reich or the Stasi. Hoftaller's spying does not end with the defeat of communism: he merely dons a baseball cap and trainers.

The leaps across centuries, sometimes within a sentence - a technique Fonty calls "double-entry bookkeeping" - make for a complex and at times mystifyingly allusive novel, which can approach tedium for those not steeped in 19th-century German literature. Yet Fonty's high-flown language, mirroring Fontane's, is interspersed with the mundane voices of his womenfolk - who, though scarcely rounded as characters, offer linguistic relief (a switch well caught by the translator, Krishna Winston). As Fonty's wife sighs during his imaginative flights: "My Wuttke, he's personifying."

Though Fonty is its central character, the novel is narrated by "We Archivists", anonymous "footnote slaves" charged with keeping the archive on Fonty's beloved "Immortal". They commandeer Fonty's letters when their own "field research" proves inadequate, steeping the book in an atmosphere of surveillance. Betrayal runs in Fonty's family, though often with good cause: his son in Bonn turns informant to save his parents behind the iron curtain, while the Wall's fall reunites Fonty with his French granddaughter, the result of a wartime affair in Lyon when he worked with the French resistance. In tracing what a united Germany means for a family and a "fatherland", there is surely symbolism in Fonty's discovery of kinship beyond German borders.

Fonty lectures on "the shadowed writer's position in society", and the novel is also about the writer's freedom, the forces that constrain it and the impulse to escape. Fonty and Hoftaller are sides of the same coin: "Spies are immortal, like the poets they spy on ... sometimes poets are spies, too." Grass, who defended Christa Wolf when she was ostracised for having informed for the GDR, argued against the opening of Stasi files and the post-unification "witchhunts" Fonty sees as "writers pillorying other writers ... small minds judging others".

While Too Far Afield is over-long and difficult (particularly the uphill trek of its first 100 pages), its pervasive scepticism offers a salutary gloss on the heady exhilaration and uncertainty of the period. It is scepticism without pessimism; a final scene on a ferris wheel - an explicit echo of The Third Man, in which the spy calls it quits - suggests a sanguine leap of faith. The novel is also leavened by a drily off-beat humour, as it returns repeatedly to an image of the two old men that owes something to Beckett or to the comic pathos of a silent movie. The gentle comedy of Fonty, his moustache trembling as he fights to save his old-fashioned ministry lift, is part Kafka, part Chaplin.

webTitle: Review:  Bettany's Book by Thomas Keneally

fields.headline: Weight of the world
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  struggles through Thomas Keneally's global inventory,  Bettany's Book
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom struggles through Thomas Keneally's global inventory, Bettany's Book
fields.body:
Bettany's Book

Thomas Keneally

400pp, Sceptre

£16.99
Buy it at BOL

The first thing to be said about Thomas Keneally's new novel, Bettany's Book - indeed, the first thing to be said about almost any Keneally novel - is that it is very long. Keneally can always be depended upon: wherever and whenever they are set, his books are reassuringly thick and dense. There is nothing dilletantish, frittering or minor about them.

In Bettany's Book the familiar steady pace is set by around page five. "A graduate of the military academy in Modena and an officer in Mussolini's armies in Libya, Lorenzo had been a prisoner of war in Australia during the second world war. Meeting Dimp during an informal press conference when he revisited Australia on the verge of old age, this professional soldier had told her how appalled he had been when his platoon, and the battalion they were a part of, and the division of which the battalion was part, showed very little resoluteness in defending Mussolini's Libyan coastal fortress of Bardia from the Australians long before, in 1941." The sentences, like the book, creep forward with a relentless caterpillar tread.

Plot summary is pointless: an inventory might be more appropriate. Bettany's Book consists of two centuries, the 19th and 20th, and two continents, Africa and Australia. To both there is some slight damage; the contents include Jews, evangelical Christians, Catholics, and Muslims of many kinds. We find first-world riches and third-world poverty, some parties, a famine, torture, fighting and protest. Country is contrasted with city and Australia ("the Sudan of the southern hemisphere") compared with Africa.

There are books within the book, letters within the books within the book, poems, songs, marriages, births, deaths, sex, art, universities, schools, governments, non-governmental organisations, numerous migrations, false starts and new beginnings. At one point Keneally describes the bodies of camels: "Across the strip of tar itself, the limbs of fallen camels were indolently and hugely strewn." Indolently and hugely strewn indeed.

What connects these disparate parts are two sisters, Prim and Dimp Bettany. Their parents die in a car crash when the girls are in their teens. Dimp works in the Australian film industry; Prim is a graduate student in anthropology who goes to work for an aid agency in the Sudan, where she falls in love with a local doctor. The sisters correspond rarely and have little in common, but are united by their fascination with a journal by their ancestor, John Bettany, and with the letters of his wife Sarah. It is through reading Bettany's book - a huge catalogue of information about life in New South Wales in the 1830s and 1840s - that they learn to forget themselves and so come to self-knowledge. This obviously takes some time. And the same goes for reading Bettany's Book .

fields.headline: Fox among the lab rats
fields.standfirst: Daughter of poor immigrants in the US, she made 'spectacularly good' as a biologist and physicist. But she has attacked male domination of science and has now produced a controversial book arguing that the concept of the gene is obsolete.  Andrew Brown on a fearless feminist who likes to paddle her own kayak
fields.trailText: Daughter of poor immigrants in the US, she made 'spectacularly good' as a biologist and physicist. But she has attacked male domination of science and has now produced a controversial book arguing that the concept of the gene is obsolete. Andrew Brown on a fearless feminist who likes to paddle her own kayak Daughter of poor immigrants in the US, she made 'spectacularly good' as a biologist and physicist. But she has attacked male domination of science and has now produced a controversial book arguing that the concept of the gene is obsolete. Andrew Brown on a fearless feminist who likes to paddle her own kayak
fields.body:
Professor Evelyn Fox Keller lounges in a swivel chair in her office at Massachusetts Institute of Technology , with her sockless feet in battered Reeboks on the desk in front of her; from time to time, when agitated, she spins round and rests them on the desk behind her, as sturdy and cluttered as the other one. It's a nice metaphor for the way she fits into the angular world of professional science. She is on top of several subjects, as a pioneering feminist critic and philosopher of science, who has also been a working biologist, but ostentatiously comfortable only on her own terms.

Tom Wilkie, adviser in bio-medical ethics at the Wellcome Trust, says that her kind of criticism of science is something that this country badly needs: "As the BSE crisis shows, we tend to treat scientists as disembodied experts in this culture, but her stuff fills out a fuller picture of the relationship between science and the world around it."

Her honours as a scientist are numerous: she has been a fellow at the Institute of Advanced Study, where Einstein worked, and has won a MacArthur "genius" award. But she is also famous for an attack on Harvard (where she gained a doctorate in theoretical physics in 1963) and as a feminist scholar of science. To find her in the splendour of MIT - Nerd Central itself and just up the road from Harvard - is something of a surprise.

It is as a feminist critic of science that she is best known. According to the American writer Pamela Weintraub, Keller's work has "cast a pall on science and its glorious priesthood, whose powerful political bias affects the 'description of nature' emerging from the lab".

Keller was born in 1936, one of three children in a poor Jewish New York City family, first-generation immigrants from Russia. Her father worked in a delicatessen. The children "made spectacularly good," she says: her sister Frances Fox Piven is a political scientist and poverty campaigner; her elder brother Maurice is a biologist at MIT. Evelyn attributes some of their success to the New York public school system - "It was wonderful. It really was."

Her original ambition was to be a psychoanalyst: "I heard about the unconscious when I was 12 from my older sister, and I thought it was the neatest thing I had ever heard." It's a big swerve from there to theoretical physics, especially as psychoanalysis is now discredited as about the most unscientific theory that could ever have existed. But she retains a huge admiration for Freud.

Maurice was a physicist by then, but it was Evelyn's comparative failure in English composition that tipped the balance. "No matter how I tried, I couldn't get better than a C in English. I was reading the George Gamow books [popular science of the 50s in which the ordinary hero, bored by physics lectures, falls asleep and understands what is said in the course of vivid dreams] and my older brother was a scientist. So I started to write my English essays about physics topics. All of a sudden I got As."

She moved into physics, intending to return to psychoanalysis after she had got a degree, but at Brandeis University, something extraordinary happened. Instead of cleverness being a means in itself, or at least a means of escape from the circumstances of her upbringing, it suddenly became something unselfish. She fell in love with theoretical physics.

This is not a metaphor, says Keller, but a literal description of her experience. She once expanded on it in an article: "I fell in love simultaneously and inextricably, with my professors, with a discipline of pure, precise, definitive thought, and with what I conceived of as its ambitions. I fell in love with the life of the mind. I also fell in love, I might add, with the image of myself striving and succeeding in an area where women had rarely ventured. It was a heady experience." This idealism is part of a fierce romantic quality that friends detect in her. Gillian Beer, president of Clare Hall, Cambridge, says, "She's full of a sort of dark life: there's tremendous intensity in her relationships, and even in her laughter. She's a very loyal friend, though she also has enemies, whom she rather relishes."

As a young scientist, Keller believed she was part of the greatest adventure that humans had ever embarked on: "I thought it was a cooperative venture in which people wanted to find out what the world was made up of"; and that the people she worked with were, by definition, working for the benefit of humanity - though perhaps, in those days, she would have said "mankind". Years later she wrote: "I believed not only in the possibility of clear and certain knowledge of the world, but also in the unique and privileged access to this knowledge provided by science in general and physics in particular. I fully accepted science, and scientists, as arbiters of the truth - physicists were, of course, the highest arbiters."

She graduated in 1957, a year when the prestige of American scientists was as high as it would ever be. She wrote her undergraduate thesis on the work of Richard Feynman [the Nobel Prize winner regarded as the purest example of idiosyncratic genius among all the discoverers of quantum mechanics] and wanted to go to California to study with him. But in the end she went on a state scholarship to Harvard, and almost at once her dreams collapsed.

She had no trouble with the work, but she found the atmosphere unendurable. "Harvard was a disaster," she says now. "It was a very difficult time to be a woman in a physics department." There were only three women among the 100 postgraduate physicists. Several months into her first year, a teacher offered her a lift and asked how she was getting on. As she started to tell him, she almost burst into tears; then realised that admitting her feelings filled him with acute discomfort, as if, instead, she had started to take off her clothes. The experience made her even more buttoned up, even more miserable. It is hard to believe now that this confident woman in steel-rimmed spectacles with a huge gleeful smile could ever have been embarrassed about anything. But she was, and she was deeply miserable. She felt persecuted by the faculty and by her fellow students, and bitterly disappointed by the work she was doing.

"I went to graduate school to learn about... the nature of space, time, and matter... I was taught, instead, how to do physics. In place of wisdom, I was offered skills. Furthermore, this substitution was made with moralistic fervour. It was wrong, foolhardy, indeed foolish, to squander precious time asking 'why?'. Proper humility was to bend to the grindstone and learn techniques."

She found this narrowing of the boundless horizons of science quite mystifying, and was still more puzzled that the people who did it were proud of their narrowed horizons. "I didn't fully understand that in addition to the techniques of physics, they were also learning the techniques of arrogance." She toyed with the idea of going to medical school, but a certain stubbornness kept her going even after she had passed her first set of exams early and felt she had little more to prove.

It was chance and family connections that showed her the way out in the summer of 1960. Her brother Maurice, newly married, was spending the summer at Cold Spring Harbor, a small village on the north shore of Long Island which is one of the capital cities of modern biology; it houses a permanent government funded research laboratory and hosts a series of influential science conferences. "I went there for the summer, because he had a spare room - well, half a spare room, because he had a baby."

These were the years in which it seemed that all life could be understood by probing at its simplest structures: bacteria and the viruses that prey on them; and most of this work was done by men who had trained as physicists. The structure of DNA had been unravelled by Crick and Watson in 1953, but its code - the syllables spelt out by the letters Crick and Watson had discovered - was not cracked until 1963; and, of course, the task of turning those syllables into intelligible words, and then deciphering the grammar and syntax of their language still continues. Max Delbruck, one of the leaders of this revolution, was working at Cold Spring Harbor, and got her to work in a lab there: "they were all on the lookout for smart young things, especially from physics", she says with an unselfconscious acceptance of her own smartness.

She switched her attention entirely to biology, and persuaded the physics department to let her take a doctorate in theoretical physics with a dissertation that was in molecular biology: she had thought of a technique which would make it possible to decide whether one or both strands of DNA were used to make proteins: she thought the task would take weeks. It took more than a year in practice, and she left with a doctorate and a conviction that she was not really cut out to be an experimental scientist. "I couldn't stand it when I'd see three weeks of work go down the tube because someone brushed against the water heater and the temperature went up. There were just so many variables out of control."

Matt Meselson, the professor under whom she took her PhD, remembers her as a young woman in a hurry. "She just wanted to get her doctorate quickly and get out. Most of the other students were less impatient. She worked hard. But she didn't really have the patience."

So she moved to New York, working again as a theoretical physicist at New York University, and in 1964 married her boss, Joseph B Keller, a mathematician of great distinction. Shortly there after, they had two children - a son and a daughter. Jeffrey, now 35, is a software engineer; Sarah, 34, is a university teacher.

Evelyn started work in yet another field, this time mathematical biology. She was happy. Two of the papers she wrote are said to be classics in the field: working with the mathematician Lee Segel, she produced equations to describe an extremely puzzling phenomenon: how it is that some single-celled amoebas can change, when times are hard, into a single, multi-cellular organism, without any one cell being responsible for the transformation. "This was all very nice, but in 1969 I followed my husband to California. [where he still is] Lee was going round the country talking about our work, and he was getting more and more excited, and I was sitting at home getting more and more bored. So I started thinking about women and science." In fact she started to study her own predicament as a mathematical biologist with the tools of mathematical biology. She got hold of all the data she could find about women scientists: how many there were, and how long they lasted in their profession. "The attrition rate was really shocking."

Four years later, when she was invited to give a lecture series on mathematical biology, "I felt I could not in good conscience give six lectures without making some reference to my being a woman. So in the last lecture I developed an epidemiological model for women in science using the data I had collected in Stanford in 1970. I showed them the equations, and the birth and death constants" - which predicted the rate at which women scientists would abandon their profession - "and then I devoted the last few minutes to a review of the reasons for these difficulties. I decided that probably the most serious obstacle to the success of women was the widespread belief that science was an inherently masculine endeavour. Where did it come from? What consequences did it have?"

It was the first time she had asked those questions out loud and the consequence was a huge sense of personal liberation. Even telling the story 26 years on, much of her face disappears in a huge grin. "In 1974 these were not polite questions. I went back to the motel that evening and wrote up the talk. It was the first story I ever sold" - she shakes her hand in the air in a jubilant, cheque-waving motion.

That was the beginning of her career as a feminist critic of science. Gillian Beer says, "What's important is that she asks new questions, and she holds on to them in ways that other people don't. She will start with very bold, sometimes odd - I'd say maybe absurd, if that wouldn't be misunderstood - questions, and moves in from there with that great weight of intellect until she carry them through. We met because I wrote a rather mixed review of her Reflections On Gender And Science and she wrote back and we became friends It's very typical of the way she listens to how people respond to her ideas. But of course it is the sheer intellectual stamina that is most impressive."

There is certainly a ferocious energy about Keller which the relaxed posture belies. She has a house on the edge of Cape Cod that she loves and where she gardens, and she keeps a kayak for voyages on the chilly Atlantic.

One of her happiest memories is of teaching cross-disciplinary courses with her colleagues in the humanities at a small university town in New York State in the 70s. "Since it was the 70s, you could ask any question you wanted. We were rethinking everything, including a new educational system"; and in the process she caught up on all the things her scientific education had missed out, reading literature, anthropology, and philosophy. She talks as if this period of blossoming radicalism was about the most fun she ever had in her life.

Today, walking through the streets round MIT, once a centre of radicalism, she seems a figure from a long-past era among the hurrying, brightly efficient students, some of whom greet her respectfully. "They are all so entrepreneurial these days" she says. "But when an MIT student goes radical, they really are radical," and she laughs at the thought.

But even though it is a powerhouse of capitalism now, the atmosphere at MIT remains extraordinarily informal, in ways she fits right into. The faculty lunchroom is a kind of 50s cafeteria, with some of the smartest people in the world eating off paper plates at plain deal tables; after lunch she took a cardboard mug of coffee outside and sat on a bench to enjoy the autumn sunlight, asking a student to move up and make room for her. This mixture of sensual relish and intellectual stringency makes her company rather disconcerting; it would not be very pleasant to be a student who she decided was not trying.

The trouble is that like so many revolutionaries she sees her followers going further than she thinks they should. For she still believes in science. It's no use saying , as some do, that science is a purely cultural construct, like art or fashion, because that does nothing to explain why it works and helps us change the world with a precision and power that no other human activity can approach. She doesn't even think there is any special way that women do science differently from men. On the other hand, she believes it is grossly misleading to pretend that science has no cultural element in a way that actually holds back scientific progress.

Language which is seen as transparent becomes impervious, she says, and holds people back from the complexity of the phenomena they are trying to understand. The consequence is that both men and women do science less well than they might. These arguments came together, in a huge stroke of good luck, in her study of the maverick geneticist Barbara McClintock, who won the Nobel Prize for physiology and medicine in 1983, whom she had seen, as from a great distance, in her lab at Cold Spring Harbor in the summer of 1960, when Keller was converted to molecular biology.

McClintock had worked there, solitary among the crowds, since 1945. Her speciality was the genetics of maize, a plant to which she remained faithful throughout the decades when almost every other geneticist had moved on to simpler and faster-growing organisms. But, by the detailed and patient study of patterns in individual plants as they grew, McClintock had been able to discover, on her own, two hugely important parts of the genetic mechanism: she identified genes which controlled the activity of others, placed further along the chromosome; and she saw how these regulated genes could "jump" from one part of a chromosome to another. She called this "transposition".

It took her six years to work it all out, and when she presented her results to her peers, no-one understood them. Nearly 15 years later, they were independently rediscovered in bacteria by molecular biologists, and McClintock was acknowledged as a pioneer; but by this time the habit of solitude was well entrenched and she continued to feel isolated by her interests and understanding of the world.

Keller's biography of her, A Feeling For The Organism, started off as a study for the New Yorker. But it grew into a full-scale biography, which appeared five months before McClintock won her Nobel Prize (she died in 1992). The moral seemed simple: that women could only succeed in science, as McClintock had, by sacrificing everything else in their lives.

Keller says: "By her own account, even as a child, McClintock neither had nor felt any need of emotional intimacy in any of her personal relationships. The world of nature... became the principle focus of both her intellectual and emotional energies. From reading the text of nature, McClintock reaps the kind of understanding and fulfilment that others acquire from personal intimacy." But Keller was also interested in whether McClintock gained a deeper intellectual understanding of the world through this emotional connection. This is sometimes also a plea for a more holistic understanding of the world, not because it is spiritually improving, but because it is in some respects scientifically enlightening. It can make our knowledge of the world more precise and reliable, which is, of course, the opposite of what holistic normally means - fuzzy and new age.

Keller's latest book, The Century Of The Gene, argues that the idea of the gene, which carried science through to such huge advances in the last century, will not do so well in this one, as more and more is learnt about the ways in which strings of DNA actually work in the world, and the complexities of their interactions with surrounding cells.

On one level it is a beautifully illustrated examination of the arcane ways in which particular, meaningful stretches of DNA are pulled out of a chromosome which is, so far as we know, 97% meaningless "junk", and assembled into the kind of genes that actually specify the proteins that build people and every other living thing. On another, it is an attack on the view that genes are agents which do things to the passive world around them and are solely responsible for changing it. Lewis Wolpert, professor of biology at London University, a conspicuous opponent of Keller, attacks her for talking "junk" and "bullshit"; but at the same time says her thesis is "what everybody knows" and cries "So what!" when specific points are raised.

The row between Wolpert and Keller is a wonderful example of the kind of antler-locking into which academics of all sexes naturally fall in a world where simply agreeing with someone can seem an unforgivable insult. One of Wolpert's themes is that the philosophy of science has absolutely nothing to teach working scientists. So when he gave a talk to this effect in Cambridge, England, and cited all the wonderful work which was going on in the laboratory without any help from philosophers, Keller rose at the end and said she agreed entirely with the importance and interest of this work - but why had he left his own laboratory to join in the science wars? The consequence was, first, that he heckled her next lecture in London, and then wrote a pamphlet attacking it.

"I suppose she wants a feminist interpretation of the gene," says Wolpert.

But the only thing feminist about Century Of The Gene is that she works in the territory familiar to another woman philosopher, Mary Midgley, an admirer of her work, where the metaphors that scientists use are taken seriously. These are dangerous borderlands; metaphors such as "selfish genes" can take on a life of their own among non-scientists, who take them to meant things that their creators never intended. But Keller, as a scientist herself, is more interested in the effect that metaphors have on the way that scientists see the world, and the sort of possibilities that they lead them to explore, or to exclude.

This is, if anything, even more unpopular among working scientists than are questions about the effects of their language on the outside world. It's quite easy to come to terms with the idea that stupid, ignorant people - non-scientists - might misinterpret the language that scientists use. It is more threatening to suppose that scientists themselves might be misled. Yet this has been the thrust of all Keller's recent work; and in The Century Of The Gene, she looks at the possibility that the word "gene" itself has outlived its usefulness. For the century she has in mind is not the one just opening, with its promise that genetic engineering will transform the world and our understanding of it, but the 20th century, just over, when all the theoretical discoveries were made.

"At the very moment in which gene-talk has come to so powerfully dominate our biological discourse, the prowess of new analytic techniques in molecular biology and the sheer weight of the findings they have enabled have bought the concept of the gene to the verge of collapse," she says. "It's been a growing conviction of mine that biologists have a whole other way of talking to each other in the lab than they do to the public."

All the information in a cell is contained in its genes, or at least in its DNA.
