fields.headline: Bent's brutal, chilling play
fields.standfirst:
Accomplices
Crucible, Sheffield
****
fields.trailText:
Accomplices
Crucible, Sheffield
****
fields.body:
Thirty-five years ago Edward Bond wrote a searing play called Saved including a scene in which a gang of lads stoned a baby to death because they had nothing better to do. In a brave piece of programming, that play's direct descendant can now be seen on Sheffield's main stage. If anything it is even more chilling.

Set on a Northern housing estate plagued by vandalism, threats of violence and thieving, Simon Bent's brilliant play, written with a Bondian economy, shows how poverty of education, expression, expectation and fellow feeling leads to appalling violence.

Part of the power of Bent's play is its ambiguity. Who exactly are the accomplices of the title? There is no doubt about the perpetrators of the crime: we watch Nicky and Stuart kicking a teenager to death. Afterwards they feel no remorse, no fear, no guilt. In fact Stuart quite fancies a shag. Both young men have a self-justifying swagger.

But others are implicated. Gary doesn't aim a single kick, but he is a Judas, betraying his former school friend and corrupted by his need for Nicky's friendship. Eddie, the dead boy's father, stands by, paralysed by fear and indecision, watching his son being murdered. His wife, Doreen, is one of those spry no-nonsense women full of moral certainty, who when it comes to ferreting out the truth from her sons makes the Spanish inquisition look amateurish.

Seven years earlier Doreen had started a petition to get the police to act against the estate's troublemakers. Now she regrets it. "If I'd done nothing... I should have kept my mouth shut." Yet this play is about the consequences of saying and doing nothing. Everyone is implicated, even the audience. We hold our tongues and avert our eyes as Nicky taunts Eddie while father watches son die: "You looking for help? Forget it dad, nobody helps anyone."

This is a brutal, clear-eyed, understated play that demonstrates what happens when people are stripped of hope and community, and neighbours become enemies.

Paul Miller's exquisitely judged production is played on an almost bare stage that becomes stained by blood and despair. It suggests all the frustration, tension and menace that lurks beneath the surface of everyday life. The cast play it to perfection, particularly Kenny Doughty as Paul, the son torn between his family and his own self-preservation, and Dylan Brown and James Weaver, both inadequates who become a lethal combination.

 Until November 18. Details: 0114-249 6000.

webTitle: A look at the modern day millionaire's row

fields.headline: A look at the modern day millionaire's row
fields.standfirst: Almost 400 homes have been sold for more than £1m this year. Elizabeth Langton investigates what's on offer in this price range
fields.trailText: Almost 400 homes have been sold for more than £1m this year. Elizabeth Langton investigates what's on offer in this price range.
fields.body:
In the spoof spy movie Austin Powers, one of the biggest shocks to greet 60s villain Dr Evil when he resurfaces in the 90s, is how £1m is no longer the awesome sum it once was. Far too little for a ransom demand, the confused baddie is told by his fellow gang members.

In today's currency, the offer of £1m is unlikely to prevent the destruction of the world as we know it, but it still buys quite a grand house. Between April and June 1999, 198 homes costing more than £1m were sold in England and Wales, according to official figures. During the same period this year, the figure had increased to 394.

There are more millionaires than ever before. So what do game show and lottery winners and dot.com millionaires get for their money when they go househunting? The capital is littered with penthouses on offer for telephone number prices, but outside London buyers have to hunt a little harder for million pound houses. Many set out on a search for a mini Versailles but find such properties thin on the ground.

New £1m homes, on the other hand, are going up in some of the most desirable areas. On a former school playing field in Beaconsfield, Buckinghamshire, developer Charles Church is building 31 homes with a price tag of more than £1m.

So what do you get for £1m? For buyers at the top end of the market, security is essential, says Matthew Nash, sales manager for Charles Church. The development, Ledborough Gate, has its own 24-hour concierge operating from a lodge to keep out unwelcome visitors (and announce welcome ones) and each home has a video entry phone and intercom connection to the lodge.

A gated development gives buyers a ready-made community, says Mr Nash. "If one partner is at work all day and the other is at home with children, they're not stuck on their own in a house miles from anywhere - which is what you'd get if you spent a million on an older house."

The detached family homes are designed in the English country house style, currently favoured by upmarket housebuilders. There are properties in arts and crafts, rural and Georgian styles. They have double-glazed sash windows. Modern touches include underfloor heating throughout the ground and first floor and stone or marble-style fireplaces with surround and hearth. Some homes have an inglenook fireplace.

The kitchens have granite worktops and De Dietrich appliances. There's a range oven, five-ring gas hob, vented extractor hood, integrated fridge/freezer, dishwasher, microwave and waste disposal. The homes are cabled for the internet, satellite TV and monitored alarms and up to eight computers can be connected.

Mr Nash says buyers are falling into two categories: rental investors and private owner-occupiers. For investors, he says: "The rental returns are quite good. They can be rented out on a corporate let basis and bring in about £8,000 a month. The return is reasonably good even if you don't take into account capital growth," he says.

Private buyers, are usually "new money rather than old money. People who have done well out of jobs in the IT sector or in the City. They tend to have made money early on in life and are under 50," he explains. The development is about a mile from the station, from where residents can be in London in half an hour.

Developer Nicholas King says house hunters attracted to Beaconsfield have little time for old-style country life with Aga cookers and dark and dusty rooms. Instead, they want the type of interior currently available in a Thameside apartment.

The company is building eight homes under the tag Curvare in Beaconsfield. The homes are built with a curved theme and include turrets, en-suite circular baths and showers and swirling staircases. Like the Charles Church homes, the development will have a gated front. Prices start at £1m and they include wine cellars that will be stocked with bottles chosen by Michel Roux to greet buyers when they move in.

Personalised service is also very much part of the package at the Ledborough Gate. Charles Church is offering buyers a year's worth of support from a company that offers personal assistant-type services. Once a week, it will run errands to and from London for residents. And they'll find someone to do the ironing, washing or gardening.

The homes are cabled for the internet, satellite TV and monitored alarms and up to eight computers can be connected. Mr Nash says buyers are falling into two categories: rental investors and private owner-occupiers. For investors, he says: "The rental returns are quite good. They can be rented out on a corporate let basis and bring in about £8,000 a month. The return is reasonably good even if you don't take into account capital growth," he says. Private buyers, are usually "new money rather than old money. People who have done well out of jobs in the IT sector or in the City. They tend to have made money early on in life and are under 50," he explains. The development is about a mile from the station, from where residents can be in London in half an hour. Developer Nicholas King says house hunters attracted to Beaconsfield have little time for old-style country life with Aga cookers and dark and dusty rooms. Instead, they want the type of interior currently available in a Thameside apartment. The company is building eight homes under the tag Curvare in Beaconsfield. The homes are built with a curved theme and include turrets, en-suite circular baths and showers and swirling staircases. Like the Charles Church homes, the development will have a gated front. Prices start at £1m and they include wine cellars that will be stocked with bottles chosen by Michel Roux to greet buyers when they move in. Personalised service is also very much part of the package at the Ledborough Gate. Charles Church is offering buyers a year's worth of support from a company that offers personal assistant-type services. Once a week, it will run errands to and from London for residents. And they'll find someone to do the ironing, washing or gardening.

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: The best of this week's cyber cinema. From tampon-tossing teases, menacing balloon men and marshmallow paste to Liverpool luvvies Craig Charles and Alexei Sayle
fields.trailText: Tampon-tossing teases, menacing balloon men, marshmallow paste, and Liverpool luvvies Craig Charles and Alexei Sayle
fields.body:
Bus Hell
With the fuel protestor's deadline only days away, refresh your memory about the perils of public transport with this realistic tale of teen torture on the top deck. Forget Halloween, these tampon-tossing teases are every little (and big) girl's nightmare. [KS]

Make Myself a Snack and Relax
Set to the luscious sounds of Barry White, New York-based video artist Jenny Horn smears herself with a soft, sticky marshmallow paste. It is oddly beautiful, as Horn raises self-indulgence in to an art form. Why she is coating herself in this stuff is never explained, and Ifilm have, strangely, categorised this film as being both 'experimental' and 'erotic'. And while the film has a certain sensuality to it, its display of wanton gluttony stops it from ever being sexy. Cynics might claim this is no more than a single gag, and the kind of pun-based work that so dogged contemporary art in the early 90s, but nonetheless, it works a treat. [SD]

Rick and Steve, The Happiest Gay Couple in the World: Cum and Quiche
Etiquette quandaries and jolly jack-off japes with the Lego gay-and-lesbian set this week. Rick and Steve's dinner party takes an unexpected turn when Dana and her partner ask for sperm instead of coffee, with hilarious consequences, as they used to say in the Radio Times. [KS]

Don't Walk
'Never run away from the scene of a crime. Always walk, that way you attract less attention'. Talented but inept bagsnatcher Larry tries hard to follow hitman Uncle Henry's advice, before he discovers that everyone has to find their own speed in life. Liverpool luvvies Craig Charles and Alexei Sayle also feature in this accomplished British comedy short. [KS]

Nosepilot
A gentle flash animation with a choice of French or English versions. A collation of two earlier animations, Home Alone and Cool Jive Burn, the series of simple animations follow no coherent narrative, but are is well worth a look because the whole effect is simply so gorgeous. The soundtrack, of old ragtime blues coupled with bespoke pieces created on a mixture of an accordion, salt shakers, bags of coins and a juice harp, makes it a particularly beguiling experience. Wonderful, gratuitously indulgent and stylish - quite simply, a shockwave dream. [SD]

Pump-action
Phil 'Captain 3D' McNally's spoof of the infamous ear cutting scene from Reservoir Dogs has already won heaps of animation awards in the US. His version has the characters made from balloons, but the scene is everything as nasty as the original. Well observed, especially the characters' movements - it's incredible how much menace McNally can get out of a balloon man. [SD]

fields.headline: Fanclub back with a bang
fields.standfirst:
Teenage Fanclub
Dublin Olympia
****
fields.trailText:
Teenage Fanclub
Dublin Olympia
***&#42
fields.body:
Outside, in the sky above the Georgian heart of Dublin, a Halloween fireworks display brings a touch of pagan festivity into the heart of a city once in thrall to the Catholic Church. Inside the hallowed halls of the city's glorious Olympia, however, Glasgow's ghosts of rock'n'roll past are casting a spell of their own.

Teenage Fanclub have never been short of the stuff of magic - they started the 90s as the British band most likely to slay America, critically lauded first for their feedback-stained debut A Catholic Education and then for their Creation debut Bandwagonesque, a record that had some believing they would be bigger than Nirvana and a soft-loud, fuzzy-guitared template for everyone from Oasis to Radiohead.

Their Dublin gig, the first for three years, sees them with their sixth LP, the restrained tunefulness of Howdy, in stores. The last two years recording the album - during which their label Creation died a long and confused death - hasn't seen much change apart from drummer Paul Quin giving way to ex-BMX Bandits sticksman Francis McDonald. Singer/guitarist Norman Blake even has the shaggy pageboy cut that used to adorn photos in those Next Big Thing previews a decade ago.

Blake, guitarist Ray McGinley and bassist Gerard Love have not a jot of celebratory showmanship about them, just cheery hellos and thank yous, and two hours heavy on Howdy. Blake's Accidental Life is warm and yearning, McDonald joining from the drumkit on dizzying, delirious harmonies. The Beach Byrds comparisons are given more weight on Love's Ain't That Enough, a breezy, naively endearing belief in the best things in life being free. That's before they launch into the tidal wave guitars of God Knows it's True, a gem from the days when Fanclub were in step with the coruscating volume of Sonic Youth.

Fanclub's good-natured, businesslike approach to live shows hasn't changed: Blake introduces new tracks for the benefit of those who haven't got the album. The harmonies haven't been weathered. The chorus during the encores, Sparky's Dream and Starsign, indeed sound like a host of angels singing in the shower. Travis, who've had the genial, tuneful band from Glasgow territory to themselves for the last couple of years, had better start worrying again.

 Teenage Fanclub are at Wolverhampton's Wulfrun Hall (01902-552121) tonight, then tour.

fields.headline: Bank merger scuppered
fields.standfirst:
Abbey National and Bank of Scotland fall out over who would run the show
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A clash over which management team would run a combined Abbey National-Bank of Scotland scuppered £23bn merger negotiations between the two banks, both of which were cited last night as vulnerable to takeover.
fields.body:
A clash over which management team would run a combined Abbey National-Bank of Scotland scuppered £23bn merger negotiations between the two banks, both of which were cited last night as vulnerable to takeover.

Although Abbey National is the larger of the two, it is expected to be more likely to fall prey to a rival bidder, with Lloyds TSB regarded as the most likely to start a new wave of consolidation in the sector. Analysts at Commerzbank described Abbey as "in play" although Abbey's chief executive, Ian Harley, last night made clear he wanted to continue talks with BoS.

Senior industry executives also regarded Barclays, fresh from its acquisition of Woolwich, and HSBC as potential bidders. Both are thought to be more interested in BoS. Royal Bank of Scotland is less likely to enter the fray.

The sharp rise in Abbey's shares to £10.40, up 71p yesterday, was said to reflect the City's view that a rival bid would emerge. BoS rose 14p to £6.90. Abbey was thought to be prepared to offer £7.50 for each BoS share.

Abbey and BoS made statements to the stock market about their approaches to one other after details emerged late on Thursday. Both spent yesterday hastily trying to persuade the market they would not fall victim to rival approaches.

Their official statements to the stock exchange reflected the sharp divergence of views between Peter Burt, the chief executive of BoS, who was in New York yesterday, and Ian Harley, the Abbey chief executive.

While Abbey confirmed its approach and said it would give rise to "an opportunity to create value for both sets of shareholders", BoS tersely retorted that it "seems unlikely that Abbey National's approach will lead to a satisfactory transaction."

It emerged yesterday that BoS, which led an audacious but ultimately ill-fated hostile takeover bid for NatWest a year ago, had instigated talks with Abbey in the early summer. But these led to nothing after Abbey decided it would rather pursue an "organic" approach to growth.

Abbey, after buying Scottish Provident in September, reinstigated talks last week when its chairman, Lord Tugendhat, met his counterpart at BoS, Sir John Shaw.

Gavin Masterton, the managing director of the BoS, said yesterday that the institution had decided against re-entering negotiations when Abbey offered a "takeover" rather than "merger".

"That changes the context," Mr Masterton said. "If it went back to a merger we'd be prepared to talk about it." He stressed that it was not an issue about the top job in a combined entity but an entire management team. "It's a very serious point. It's not a personal point, not just about three or four people."

However, with the talks at such an early stage Ian Harley, Abbey National's chief executive, who many City sources believe has been subjected to a "whispering campaign", insisted that talks about top jobs had not yet taken place.

"The issue is about clarity and a lack of fudge," he said. But he did indicate that he would be eager to take a senior role should any combination take place.

The value of huddling together in a cold market

Ian Harley of Abbey National yesterday said he wanted to take over Bank of Scotland because it would create "value" for shareholders by playing to both banks' strengths, writes Jill Treanor.

Abbey is the second biggest mortgage lender while BoS is smaller, around 7th in size, but with a wider spread of businesses. Mr Harley said Abbey, which is taking over Scottish Provident, would be able to sell more life and pensions products through BoS's 300 Scottish branches while BoS would boost Abbey's position in business banking. The City will also hope the banks would try to save costs by merging their headquarters and computer functions, although senior bankers pointed out that BoS's decision to outsource IT functions might reduce savings.

Pressures

The talks between Abbey and BoS were at such an early stage that Mr Harley said the size of cost reductions and additional profit generation had yet to be calculated. Large-scale bank closures appeared unlikely given Abbey's locations in England and Wales and BoS's in Scotland. Nevertheless, analysts calculated that a combined bank might be able to save about £350m a year.

Analysts said competitive pressures in the mortgage and savings market, where Abbey's history lies but out of which it has been diversifying, were one reason for a deal.

"In a particularly cold market in retail financial services it makes a world of sense to huddle together," said Alex Potter, banking analyst at Commerzbank.

Following Royal Bank of Scotland's takeover of NatWest this year and Barclays' move to buy Woolwich, the City has been predicting further consolidation. Unless Mr Harley can woo Peter Burt back to the negotiating table, he may have to consider a hostile bid.

webTitle: Caught in the web of deceit

fields.headline: Caught in the web of deceit
fields.standfirst: If you shop on the net be extra careful checking your credit card statements. As Rupert Jones and Phillip Inman report, the number of dodgy dealers running suspect sites is on the increase - and you may be too embarrassed to make a fuss
fields.trailText: If you shop on the net be extra careful checking your credit card statements. As Rupert Jones and Phillip Inman report, the number of dodgy dealers running suspect sites is on the increase - and you may be too embarrassed to make a fuss.
fields.body:
Credit card companies are privately slapping hefty fines on rogue websites for misusing people's card details amid a big jump in complaints about internet fraud, it emerged this week.

Much of the problem centres on "adult" websites and other disreputable merchants, most of which tend to be based in America or offshore locations such as the US Virgin Islands, that are fleecing credit card-holders in the UK and around the world.

Britain is a mecca for credit card fraudsters. Incredibly, more than half of all credit card transactions in Europe take place in the UK and more than half of Europe's card fraud happens here too. And the growth of shopping on the web has the potential to make matters worse.

This week, British and US regulators added to fears over net purchases when they warned web users to watch out for internet fraudsters. Officials said they were taking action against more than 250 cyber conmen, mainly in the US, who have been tricking gullible web users.

Mastercard/Europay, the international payments organisation, disclosed to Jobs & Money that since June it has fined around 30 websites, many of them sites selling pornographic images and goods, which have generated the largest number of disputed online transactions.

Mastercard/Europay carried out research into where credit card disputes - such as alleged fraud and complaints about unsent goods - were arising, and found that about 50% of them related to e-commerce. And about half of these e-commerce disputes related to adult websites.

One of the most popular scams operated by US-based adult sites involves requests for users' credit card details, either to pay a "one-off" subscription fee or simply to act as proof that customers are over 18. The individual does this, and then he or she finds they are being charged $25-$30 every month by the site - a regular payment they clearly haven't agreed to. Attempts to get the unauthorised payments stopped run up against toll-free phone numbers that only work in America, with no address to write to.

Other sites, some of them auction and holiday websites, are taking credit card numbers and passwords and using them to go shopping at major online retailers that might have been visited by the customer. Research shows that people tend to use one password for all their online shopping and rogue sites exploit this fact. They take the card details and password and visit sites that only need a password before allowing customers to shop. CDs and other goods can be bought in large numbers and sent on to an address in another country.

So what can the victims do? The fact that it may involve porn means some people will be too embarrassed to contact their bank or credit card company to try to get the matter rectified. Some will simply cut up their card, which is immensely frustrating for the card companies, for whom losing customers is an expensive business.

MasterCard/Europay is now hitting back, and earlier this year put in place a policy where if the number of disputed transactions exceeds a certain amount for two consecutive months, it fines the website's bank (it can't fine the sites directly). And these are no token penalties either - the fines start at $5,000 and rise to a hefty $100,000. The October fines were the most severe yet imposed, and are expected to lead to a crackdown on guilty sites.

"Nearly all the people on the list [of those fined] have been what you would call disreputable merchants," says Paul Lucraft at Mastercard/Europay. They are all based in America or offshore America.

Mr Lucraft stresses that Mastercard/Europay is not mounting a moral crusade against adult websites. "It just happens to be that a number of the people who are ripping off the system are hiding behind these sites." It probably costs the porn sites "a few cents" to post images on the net and they are collecting perhaps $30 a month from hundreds or thousands of individuals, he adds.

Lack of confidence in net security is deterring millions of people from buying on-line. Future Foundation, a think-tank, says that security topped the list when it asked people what they consider the most important service criteria. It quizzed 1,000 people and found that 76% of non-internet shoppers say that when they do come to make their first online purchase, they will want to deal with brand names they trust - not least because of widespread fears about security.

Measures are being put in place to give consumers greater protection against online fraud. Government rules came into force this week which give new rights to people who shop via the internet, phone or mail order.

Ministers have amended the Consumer Credit Act so that people are no longer liable for the first £50 when someone uses their credit or debit card to make fraudulent purchases. There is also a new seven-day cooling-off period during which you can change your mind and have your money refunded.

In this climate of concern, some companies are now offering nervous net shoppers peace of mind for a price. A company called CPP (Card Protection Plan) recently launched "e-shopsafe", described as the first comprehensive insurance policy designed to protect internet shoppers against fraud. It costs £10 a year and covers shopping done via any secure site worldwide - but it may only be worth con- sidering if you do a lot of shopping from over-seas websites because some of the protection it offers is already provided within the new UK rights that came into force on Tuesday.

Ms W, a marketing manager from York (she didn't wish to be identified), took out an e-shopsafe policy after she bought a book about environmental volunteer holidays over the internet - but later found her credit card details had been used by a fraudster to buy pornography.

Two months later, three transactions appeared on her statement for amounts under $30 that she most definitely didn't recognise. "When I looked closely I was horrified to see the name of the retailer I had supposedly shopped with. There was no doubt as to what they sold."

She was eventually reimbursed for the fraudulent transactions but the incident has severely dented her confidence. "I was surprised at how easy it all seemed for the fraudster. It has also made me more vigilant in checking my credit card statements."

Parool Patel, a freelance public relations director, was the victim of a similar (non porn-related) incident earlier this year when his statement showed US dollar purchases he had not made. He wondered if it might be internet-related as he had only recently been browsing the net for books and CDs. He contacted the card company which put the transaction into a "dispute account" and has heard nothing since. "I presume they have resolved the fraud or absorbed the cost," says Mr Patel.

In the longer term, a number of further measures are planned to combat card fraud, both online (which accounts for a small but growing percentage of total card fraud losses) and offline. The UK banking industry is currently rolling out a new generation of "smart" credit and debit cards containing computer chips but it's proving to be an agonisingly slow process. Though the roll-out commenced 18 months ago, currently only around 10m of the 120m cards in circulation have chips.

These new cards are more difficult and costly to counterfeit than traditional cards with a magnetic strip on the back, which are falling foul of a fast-growing problem called "skimming", where fraudsters copy data from a genuine card on to a blank card without your knowledge.

This might happen in a restaurant or bar where a crooked waiter takes your card away when you pay and secretly copies it. This is what happened to Adam Mason, 26, a consultant at a London sports marketing company. A few weeks ago he suddenly found he couldn't obtain cash from an ATM with his Barclaycard. When he called the company, they said they had put a block on his card because its fraud office had noticed his plastic had been used simultaneously in London and Morecambe - someone had run up a £400 bill in two days at various stores in the Lancashire town using a counterfeit card containing his data.

Adam had only recently made his first online purchase and initially believed this to be the source of the fraud, but he now reckons it was a result of a visit to "a particularly dodgy bar" where he had put his card behind the counter and had never received a receipt. Barclaycard fully reimbursed Adam and also recovered the counterfeit card, and he is full of praise for the way it sorted out the matter so quickly.

Tips for foiling fraudsters

Here we identify the online fraudsters' tricks of the trade and offer some advice on how to avoid their clutches.

 The password trick: A crook running a rogue website takes a customer's credit card number and password to go shopping at major online retailers that might also have been visited by that person. Many people use the same password for all their online shopping, so the crook will go to sites that only need a password before they allow customers to buy goods. Armed with the person's credit card details, they can then go on a shopping spree.

Tip: Use different passwords on different sites. Also, just as you wouldn't give your credit or debit card details to someone you don't know, make sure you trust the online retailer, says CPP, a company specialising in credit card protection. "Check out an unfamiliar site before you buy," it adds. "Do they have a secure site? Do they provide full address and contact details, not just a mobile phone number? Which trade organisations is the company a member of?" Secure sites typically display a padlock symbol on your screen when you are entering your details.

 The multiple debit trick: Asking visitors to the site to pay a "one-off" fee which turns into a regular amount charged to your credit card every month.

Tip: As we explain in the main article, the sites notorious for doing this are US-based porn sites, so you're clearly dabbling in dangerous waters and some people will have little sympathy for your predicament if this happens to you. If you are going to deal with a website that asks for such a one-off fee, make sure there is a contact phone number that works and check for a full address on the site.

 The undelivered goods trick

Tip: The advice above applies here too. You've got a better chance of sorting the matter out if the site is in the UK - at least it will be covered by our laws. As we have highlighted, new rules came in this week giving greater protection to people who shop online. One of the new rights is that if you haven't received the goods within 30 days, you are entitled to your money back, unless both parties have agreed to a longer period or alternative goods/services are supplied and you accept them.

 The email sales trick: A site that has your card details emails you with an offer to "upgrade" the service you receive. It says this will cost you perhaps an extra $19.99 a month and that if you don't reply within X days it will automatically start deducting the amount from your credit card. You do not get the message in time - it might be an old email address or you're on holiday - and you end up with a regular payment going out that you haven't authorised.

Tip: Check your emails regularly if you subscribe to a site that has your card details. And go through your credit card statement with a fine-tooth comb.

Britain is a mecca for credit card fraudsters. Incredibly, more than half of all credit card transactions in Europe take place in the UK and more than half of Europe's card fraud happens here too. And the growth of shopping on the web has the potential to make matters worse. This week, British and US regulators added to fears over net purchases when they warned web users to watch out for internet fraudsters. Officials said they were taking action against more than 250 cyber conmen, mainly in the US, who have been tricking gullible web users. Mastercard/Europay, the international payments organisation, disclosed to Jobs & Money that since June it has fined around 30 websites, many of them sites selling pornographic images and goods, which have generated the largest number of disputed online transactions. Mastercard/Europay carried out research into where credit card disputes - such as alleged fraud and complaints about unsent goods - were arising, and found that about 50% of them related to e-commerce. And about half of these e-commerce disputes related to adult websites. One of the most popular scams operated by US-based adult sites involves requests for users' credit card details, either to pay a "one-off" subscription fee or simply to act as proof that customers are over 18. The individual does this, and then he or she finds they are being charged $25-$30 every month by the site - a regular payment they clearly haven't agreed to. Attempts to get the unauthorised payments stopped run up against toll-free phone numbers that only work in America, with no address to write to. Other sites, some of them auction and holiday websites, are taking credit card numbers and passwords and using them to go shopping at major online retailers that might have been visited by the customer. Research shows that people tend to use one password for all their online shopping and rogue sites exploit this fact. They take the card details and password and visit sites that only need a password before allowing customers to shop. CDs and other goods can be bought in large numbers and sent on to an address in another country. So what can the victims do? The fact that it may involve porn means some people will be too embarrassed to contact their bank or credit card company to try to get the matter rectified. Some will simply cut up their card, which is immensely frustrating for the card companies, for whom losing customers is an expensive business. MasterCard/Europay is now hitting back, and earlier this year put in place a policy where if the number of disputed transactions exceeds a certain amount for two consecutive months, it fines the website's bank (it can't fine the sites directly). And these are no token penalties either - the fines start at $5,000 and rise to a hefty $100,000. The October fines were the most severe yet imposed, and are expected to lead to a crackdown on guilty sites. "Nearly all the people on the list [of those fined] have been what you would call disreputable merchants," says Paul Lucraft at Mastercard/Europay. They are all based in America or offshore America. Mr Lucraft stresses that Mastercard/Europay is not mounting a moral crusade against adult websites. "It just happens to be that a number of the people who are ripping off the system are hiding behind these sites." It probably costs the porn sites "a few cents" to post images on the net and they are collecting perhaps $30 a month from hundreds or thousands of individuals, he adds. Lack of confidence in net security is deterring millions of people from buying on-line. Future Foundation, a think-tank, says that security topped the list when it asked people what they consider the most important service criteria. It quizzed 1,000 people and found that 76% of non-internet shoppers say that when they do come to make their first online purchase, they will want to deal with brand names they trust - not least because of widespread fears about security. Measures are being put in place to give consumers greater protection against online fraud. Government rules came into force this week which give new rights to people who shop via the internet, phone or mail order. Ministers have amended the Consumer Credit Act so that people are no longer liable for the first £50 when someone uses their credit or debit card to make fraudulent purchases. There is also a new seven-day cooling-off period during which you can change your mind and have your money refunded. In this climate of concern, some companies are now offering nervous net shoppers peace of mind for a price. A company called CPP (Card Protection Plan) recently launched "e-shopsafe", described as the first comprehensive insurance policy designed to protect internet shoppers against fraud. It costs £10 a year and covers shopping done via any secure site worldwide - but it may only be worth con- sidering if you do a lot of shopping from over-seas websites because some of the protection it offers is already provided within the new UK rights that came into force on Tuesday. Ms W, a marketing manager from York (she didn't wish to be identified), took out an e-shopsafe policy after she bought a book about environmental volunteer holidays over the internet - but later found her credit card details had been used by a fraudster to buy pornography. Two months later, three transactions appeared on her statement for amounts under $30 that she most definitely didn't recognise. "When I looked closely I was horrified to see the name of the retailer I had supposedly shopped with. There was no doubt as to what they sold." She was eventually reimbursed for the fraudulent transactions but the incident has severely dented her confidence. "I was surprised at how easy it all seemed for the fraudster. It has also made me more vigilant in checking my credit card statements." Parool Patel, a freelance public relations director, was the victim of a similar (non porn-related) incident earlier this year when his statement showed US dollar purchases he had not made. He wondered if it might be internet-related as he had only recently been browsing the net for books and CDs. He contacted the card company which put the transaction into a "dispute account" and has heard nothing since. "I presume they have resolved the fraud or absorbed the cost," says Mr Patel. In the longer term, a number of further measures are planned to combat card fraud, both online (which accounts for a small but growing percentage of total card fraud losses) and offline. The UK banking industry is currently rolling out a new generation of "smart" credit and debit cards containing computer chips but it's proving to be an agonisingly slow process. Though the roll-out commenced 18 months ago, currently only around 10m of the 120m cards in circulation have chips. These new cards are more difficult and costly to counterfeit than traditional cards with a magnetic strip on the back, which are falling foul of a fast-growing problem called "skimming", where fraudsters copy data from a genuine card on to a blank card without your knowledge. This might happen in a restaurant or bar where a crooked waiter takes your card away when you pay and secretly copies it. This is what happened to Adam Mason, 26, a consultant at a London sports marketing company. A few weeks ago he suddenly found he couldn't obtain cash from an ATM with his Barclaycard. When he called the company, they said they had put a block on his card because its fraud office had noticed his plastic had been used simultaneously in London and Morecambe - someone had run up a £400 bill in two days at various stores in the Lancashire town using a counterfeit card containing his data. Adam had only recently made his first online purchase and initially believed this to be the source of the fraud, but he now reckons it was a result of a visit to "a particularly dodgy bar" where he had put his card behind the counter and had never received a receipt. Barclaycard fully reimbursed Adam and also recovered the counterfeit card, and he is full of praise for the way it sorted out the matter so quickly. Tips for foiling fraudsters Here we identify the online fraudsters' tricks of the trade and offer some advice on how to avoid their clutches.  The password trick: A crook running a rogue website takes a customer's credit card number and password to go shopping at major online retailers that might also have been visited by that person. Many people use the same password for all their online shopping, so the crook will go to sites that only need a password before they allow customers to buy goods. Armed with the person's credit card details, they can then go on a shopping spree. Tip: Use different passwords on different sites. Also, just as you wouldn't give your credit or debit card details to someone you don't know, make sure you trust the online retailer, says CPP, a company specialising in credit card protection. "Check out an unfamiliar site before you buy," it adds. "Do they have a secure site? Do they provide full address and contact details, not just a mobile phone number? Which trade organisations is the company a member of?" Secure sites typically display a padlock symbol on your screen when you are entering your details.  The multiple debit trick: Asking visitors to the site to pay a "one-off" fee which turns into a regular amount charged to your credit card every month. Tip: As we explain in the main article, the sites notorious for doing this are US-based porn sites, so you're clearly dabbling in dangerous waters and some people will have little sympathy for your predicament if this happens to you. If you are going to deal with a website that asks for such a one-off fee, make sure there is a contact phone number that works and check for a full address on the site.  The undelivered goods trick Tip: The advice above applies here too. You've got a better chance of sorting the matter out if the site is in the UK - at least it will be covered by our laws. As we have highlighted, new rules came in this week giving greater protection to people who shop online. One of the new rights is that if you haven't received the goods within 30 days, you are entitled to your money back, unless both parties have agreed to a longer period or alternative goods/services are supplied and you accept them.  The email sales trick: A site that has your card details emails you with an offer to "upgrade" the service you receive. It says this will cost you perhaps an extra $19.99 a month and that if you don't reply within X days it will automatically start deducting the amount from your credit card. You do not get the message in time - it might be an old email address or you're on holiday - and you end up with a regular payment going out that you haven't authorised. Tip: Check your emails regularly if you subscribe to a site that has your card details. And go through your credit card statement with a fine-tooth comb.

webTitle: Run for cover in the bad weather

fields.headline: Run for cover in the bad weather
fields.trailText: Insurance premiums could rise by as much as 60% over the next six months as a result of this week's storms, according to some industry experts.
fields.body:
Insurance premiums could rise by as much as 60% over the next six months as a result of this week's storms, according to some industry experts.

Jeffrey Salmon, of insurance assessors Salmon Assessors, says: "We predict that rates will go up by between 40%-60% in six months time and will stay up for the next 12-15 months, provided no other incidents occur in that time."

The tone of this message was confirmed this week by the executive director of CGNU's UK general insurance division, Mike Biggs. He says that although insurers made provisions in their financial forecasting, for abnormal weather events, those living in certain areas, on flood plains or in river valleys, are likely to have to pay more.

But the Association of British Insurers refutes claims of generalised increases. Spokesman Malcolm Tarling says: "If this sort of weather continues on a regular basis, this could affect premiums.

"But we don't expect premiums to rise on the back of one event. In terms of insurance, this storm is not an exceptional event and early indications point to damage being in the area of the low hundreds of millions rather than the billions reported."

However, Mr Salmon says: "The ABI will try to play this down because they do not want the public to think there is just a knee-jerk reaction that every time something bad happens, rates go up. In fact, insurers love this kind of thing.

"It's like when there's a $1m payout in Las Vegas, the casinos love it because everyone wants to go there. If the insurance companies pay out £500m this time, they will get £1bn back by raising premiums to a totally and utterly unreasonable level."

Rebecca Hadley, of the AA Insurance Services, feels these arguments are too simplistic. "Premiums have remained pretty flat in recent years even though we have seen plenty of floods. The UK is pretty well mapped by geologists and so they know where the water is and where the risk of flooding is, almost on a house by house basis," she says.

"Selective rates are likely to go up, which means you could see a house on one side of the road paying more while there will be no change for the house opposite."

fields.headline: Roche's Beast is a burden
fields.standfirst:
Poor Beast in the Rain
Chester Gateway Theatre
**
fields.trailText:
Poor Beast in the Rain
Chester Gateway Theatre
**
fields.body:
The way the weather's going at the moment, the title of part two of Billy Roche's Wexford trilogy could allude to any one of us, but instead we're safely transported to a dry and homely betting shop in a small town not too far from Dublin. What evolves is a parochial drama of lost loves and opportunities as the six characters choose whether to reassess or ignore the misfortunes that have kept them together.

Of those who decide to disturb the dreary status quo, Molly, the shop's cleaner, is the most vehement, and she is afforded all the bitchy looks and gestures of a seething resentment by Rebecca Egan. Dumped in the past by a local hard man, Danger Doyle, Molly does her utmost to resist sentiment when he returns to the town to persuade his stepdaughter, Eileen, to visit her mother. Instead, Molly attacks those who, like her, have been stuck in the town all their lives.

Two betting-shop stalwarts, Joe and Georgie, are among those who suffer her tongue. Eamon Maguire is good as the naive, middle-aged Joe, who has never had much luck with women, or indeed much luck at all; but he plods on, hiding his insecurities behind a cloying wit and a stack of embellished memories. His bemused sidekick, Young Georgie (Hugh O'Conor), is hopelessly in love with Eileen, but equally inept when it comes to doing anything about it.

Both cling to the notion that "a man without a home town is nothing". As the characters stand round telling each other self-validating tales of their spurious achievements, Wilson Milam's production soon feels a little static. Although Geoff Rose's set happily renders the bookie's interior of TV screens and form sheets, there are no scene changes, and the characters rarely develop or engage.

Eileen is an unremarkable character, while her father, Steven, played by Michael O'Hagan, is taciturn throughout, and his recalcitrance forestalls many potentially dramatic episodes. What's more, O'Hagan became quieter and quieter during his only monologue. Michael McElhatton fares better as Danger Doyle, whose constant brooding at least adds a little tension.

Unlike the other two plays in the trilogy, A Handful of Stars and Belfry, Poor Beast struggles to stand up on its own. It's a modest tale and although it has its moments, there are, alas, too few of them.

 Tonight and next Saturday. Box office: 01244-340392. Then tours to Salford and London.

webTitle: How the Names lost their shirts

fields.headline: How the Names lost their shirts
fields.standfirst:
The background Lloyd's in court
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: When Sir William Jaffray became a Lloyd's underwriter in the 1980s he was not seeking a multimillion-pound income, just a "reasonable return at a low risk".
fields.body:
When Sir William Jaffray became a Lloyd's underwriter in the 1980s he was not seeking a multimillion-pound income, just a "reasonable return at a low risk".

The former fine art dealer and loss adjuster says he was persuaded by glossy brochures extolling Lloyd's virtues as a "sound, blue chip institution" - and hoped to make up to £5,000 a year. Almost 20 years later the relationship has turned very sour, with Sir William and more than 200 fellow underwriters, known as Names, locked in a legal dispute with the insurance market.

Yesterday in London's high court the latest episode in this decade-long wrangle was played out. In a ruling which ran to more than 600 pages, Mr Justice Cresswell dismissed Names' claims that Lloyd's knew, but failed to tell them, of an impending avalanche of asbestos-related claims before they pledged their wealth.

As the judgment was read out during a 90 minute hearing there were gasps from the Names and their families, who were packed into Court 4, and laughter when it was suggested Lloyd's should establish an independent panel to assess the cases.

Many of those watching the proceedings had become involved with Lloyd's in the late 1970s and 1980s, when agents were vigorously recruiting wealthy individuals to act as underwriters. Many investors rushed to join following the introduction of supertax in the 1970s at up to 98%.

In exchange for handsome tax benefits and the promise of substantial returns, the Names pledged to cover losses which, in many cases, far exceeded their means. Today many of those who signed up are facing financial ruin as a result of either underwriting the huge asbestos-related losses or fighting Lloyd's through the courts.

Of the 34,000 underwriters who lost money as a result of the crisis, 95% chose to settle with Lloyd's in 1996 and pay back £100,000 each. More have since come to agreement, but a rebel band of 230 Names rejected settlement offers and insisted they should not be liable. Their action is thought to have already cost around £25m in legal fees.

Other overseas cases against Lloyd's are still outstanding, with action under way in Canada, Australia and Belgium, while an individual case has just been settled in the US.

The court was told yesterday that the Names are the in nocent victims of unscrupulous agents who were guilty of a "staggering" catalogue of "failings and incompetence". Lloyd's admitted there were unacceptable practices among some agents in the 1980s, but said it was up to Names to recover losses from the agents and not the regulator, Lloyd's.

Estimates for individual losses range from £120,000 to £5m, with many of the Names having been forced to sell their houses and businesses.

Life would have been tough enough without asbestos claims due to the exceptional number of catastrophes in the late 1980s, including Piper Alpha, the San Francisco earthquake and ferocious storms in northern Europe.

It was asbestos which brought the most financial devastation. In the early 1980s the volume of claims for diseases such as asbestosis and lung cancer stood at 6,000 a year. Ten years later this figure had increased fourfold to 24,000.

"I recognise that no words can adequately describe the devastation that has been caused to many individuals in financial and personal terms," Mr Justice Cresswell said.

Max Taylor, Lloyd's chairman, said dissident Names would fail if they took the case to the European court of justice. He claimed that attempts to sue a regulator for anything other than fraud would be resisted. "All other regulators are protected from legal suits in this way - including the FSA."

Mr Jaffray hopes to use the new Human Rights Act to undermine the Lloyd's claim that he must prove fraud, rather than a lesser offence of negligence.

Mr Taylor emphasised, that he was ready to negotiate with any of the 1,650 Names who have yet to make a settlement and would take into account their personal financial situations.

Loss cause Crisis at Lime Street

1970s

Lloyd's boasts 25 years of unbroken profits apart from 1966-68. Cromer report into lossmaking years partly supressed , including criticism of quality of information given to Names. Subsequent huge returns and tax breaks for investors prove attractive after Labour government introduces supertax at 98% . Rising house prices allow more investors to pass wealth test. Market begins big expansion

1980s

Syndicates underwrite health and safety insurance for US corporations. A series of scandals involving syndicates losing millions of pounds sparks Fisher report. He fails to break down conflicts of interest - underwriting agencies, which seek to insure best risks at highest premiums, continue to be owned by brokers, which seek lowest premiums for clients. US asbestosis and environmental damage claims mount

1990s

Losses reach £8bn. Some 95% of the 34,000 Names transfer to Equitas reinsurance, set up by Lloyd's, paying premiums of £100,000 each. Some 1,700 refuse to transfer and 600 are sued by Lloyd's. In 1997 group led by Sir William Jaffray counter-claim that they were recruited fraudulently. Collectively the 230 are said by Lloyd's to owe £51m

2000

February, Jaffray case begins. November, Mr Justice Cresswell concludes fraud is unproven but lambasts Lloyd's for staggering incompetence.

fields.headline: Businessman and wild man of the renaissance
fields.standfirst:
Correggio/ Parmigianino

British Museum, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Correggio/ Parmigianino

British Museum, London
*****
fields.body:
There are two probable self-portraits by Parmigianino (1503-40) in this exhibition of Renaissance drawings, none by Correggio (c.1489-1534), and this sums up the difference between the two artists. Correggio is the better draughtsman, his drawings delineating the human body with strong lines and anatomical precision.

Parmigianino's drawings are wilder, less disciplined than the older man's, yet more personal. You might almost call them romantic. Take the most securely identified self-portrait, drawn in red chalk in about 1524. Parmigianino gazes with big, sensitive eyes from under his longish hair and floppy hat. He looks every inch the young genius. Parmigianino's drawing is intensely self-conscious. Travelling to Rome, he drew the work of the previous generation of artists as well as ancient art: an improvisation on Michelangelo's Pietà, a portrait copied from the statue of Laocoön.

Correggio is the 15th century strong and neat. He worked on frescoes for Isabella d'Este in Mantua before embarking on a career painting Parma's churches. Correggio's drawings are working designs for his assistants; they are also staggeringly beautiful. He draws figures kneeling, turning, looking, crying; always, you feel, he is experimenting, seeing what someone looks like, robed or naked, when they twist their body in a certain way. His shading too is lovely: Christ (c.1522) has exquisite reddened flesh; two putti in a design for the Del Bono chapel (c.1524) are pink-toned bundles of love.

Yet it is Parmigianino, so much looser, who stops you in your tracks. This is what a change in art history looks like. Correggio employed him as an assistant on one project; Parmigianino never ran such a successful studio. When he signed a contract to fresco the church of the Stecatta in Parma in 1531, he was expected to finish in 18 months, but prevaricated until he was arrested and jailed for breach of contract in 1539. Released on bail, he vandalised his own work at the church.

Given his wilful disposition, you can see why drawing became more than an exercise; he practised it as an art, a place for fantasy to flourish. His line is serpentine, his bodies weirdly elongated. He sees the body as an engine of drama, drawing a fragmented stone torso with sinister violence, and nature as a vast theatre in a drawing of Trees on a Bluff (1522-24). He drew erotica too: Priapus and Lotis (c.1530-40) allows us to spy on a sleeping nymph.

In Parmigianino's second probable self-portrait, A Man Holding a Pregnant Bitch (c.1530-40), he sits holding up his dog on her hind legs. It's a funny little piece, perhaps done for a friend. The fact that he thought it worth his while makes Parmigianino an extraordinarily fresh artist. You can't imagine Correggio wasting his time on such a thing.

 Until January 7. Details: 020-7636 1555.
fields.bodyText: There are two probable self-portraits by Parmigianino (1503-40) in this exhibition of Renaissance drawings, none by Correggio (c.1489-1534), and this sums up the difference between the two artists. Correggio is the better draughtsman, his drawings delineating the human body with strong lines and anatomical precision. Parmigianino's drawings are wilder, less disciplined than the older man's, yet more personal. You might almost call them romantic. Take the most securely identified self-portrait, drawn in red chalk in about 1524. Parmigianino gazes with big, sensitive eyes from under his longish hair and floppy hat. He looks every inch the young genius. Parmigianino's drawing is intensely self-conscious. Travelling to Rome, he drew the work of the previous generation of artists as well as ancient art: an improvisation on Michelangelo's Pietà, a portrait copied from the statue of Laocoön. Correggio is the 15th century strong and neat. He worked on frescoes for Isabella d'Este in Mantua before embarking on a career painting Parma's churches. Correggio's drawings are working designs for his assistants; they are also staggeringly beautiful. He draws figures kneeling, turning, looking, crying; always, you feel, he is experimenting, seeing what someone looks like, robed or naked, when they twist their body in a certain way. His shading too is lovely: Christ (c.1522) has exquisite reddened flesh; two putti in a design for the Del Bono chapel (c.1524) are pink-toned bundles of love. Yet it is Parmigianino, so much looser, who stops you in your tracks. This is what a change in art history looks like. Correggio employed him as an assistant on one project; Parmigianino never ran such a successful studio. When he signed a contract to fresco the church of the Stecatta in Parma in 1531, he was expected to finish in 18 months, but prevaricated until he was arrested and jailed for breach of contract in 1539. Released on bail, he vandalised his own work at the church. Given his wilful disposition, you can see why drawing became more than an exercise; he practised it as an art, a place for fantasy to flourish. His line is serpentine, his bodies weirdly elongated. He sees the body as an engine of drama, drawing a fragmented stone torso with sinister violence, and nature as a vast theatre in a drawing of Trees on a Bluff (1522-24). He drew erotica too: Priapus and Lotis (c.1530-40) allows us to spy on a sleeping nymph. In Parmigianino's second probable self-portrait, A Man Holding a Pregnant Bitch (c.1530-40), he sits holding up his dog on her hind legs. It's a funny little piece, perhaps done for a friend. The fact that he thought it worth his while makes Parmigianino an extraordinarily fresh artist. You can't imagine Correggio wasting his time on such a thing.  Until January 7. Details: 020-7636 1555.
